DIV1.P: THE ANTIQUITIES OF BERKSHIRE.
By ELIAS ASHMOLE, Es{que}
WITH A large APPENDIX of many valu∣able Original Papers, PEDIGREES of the most considerable FAMILIES in the said County, and a particular Account of the Castle, College, and Town of WINDSOR.
In THREE VOLUMES.
LONDON: Printed for E. Curll in Fleetstreet. M.DCC.XIX.

DIV1.HEAD: DIRECTION to the Book-Binder.
DIV1.P: THE Second Volume begins at SHRIVENHAM Hundred, Page 195.

DIV1.HEAD: SOME MEMOIRS OF THE LIFE OF ELIAS ASHMOLE, Es{que}
DIV1.P:
THE Compiler of this Work, Mr. Ashmole, was a Person who was so well known, and much esteemed in his own Time, and bore many publick Offices, which he ac∣quitted with so much Honour to himself, and Justice to his Country, that it is something surprizing no Account (besides an Article in the Supplement to the Learn∣ed Mr. COLLIER's Historical Dictionary)
of him has been ever attempted: For many Years last past it has been expected, and indeed, as some say, promised, from the accurate Pen of a Prelate who makes no inconsiderable Figure in the Church of England, and owes his present Gran∣deur, and future Hopes, to the Generosity of Mr. Ashmole, who assisted and encouraged him by a liberal Education at School, and in the University, by which he was fitted for the Mitre, he now deservedly wears. This neglect is the more to be wonder'd at, when he has left so many Materials be∣hind him in his own Musaeum at Oxford, and elsewhere in private Hands, who would communicate to the Undertaker many Hints worthy his Knowledge. The Diary it self, printed about a Twelve∣month since (though too much crowded with Trifles, altogether beneath the No∣tice of the Publick, nor ever designed for them, however it has crept into the World) will be of great Use to such Bio∣grapher; but seeing nothing of this Sort has yet appeared, the Reader may take candidly the following Extracts from the Diary, and other Papers of Authority, to be depended on.

ELIAS ASHMOLE, Es{que} was the only Son of Simon Ashmole, of the City of Litch∣field,
Sadler, and Anne, the Daughter of Mr. Anthony Bowyer, of the City of Coven∣try in Warwickshire, Draper, born 23d of May, 1617. He was educated at a Gram∣mar School in Litchfield, and having some Inclination to Musick, he was instructed in it, and placed as a Chorister in that Cathedral: This was his beginning, by the Interest of Mr. Thomas Pagit, second Son of James Pagit, sometimes Puisne Baron of the Exchequer, who married his Mother's Sister, who was, says Mr. Ashmole,See pag. 3. of the Diary. the chief Instrument of my fu∣ture Preferments, which I acknowledge with all Gratitude to his Memory. In June 1634. he lost his Father, of whom, though like a dutiful Son, he gives a good Cha∣racter Ibid. pag. 5., yet he freely tells us, Though he was an honest fair conditioned Man, and kind to others, yet through ill Husbandry he be∣came a great Enemy to himself and poor Family. He was married young, at Twen∣ty Years of Age, to his first Wife, Eleanor, Daughter of Mr. Peter Mainwaring, of Smalwood in Cheshire, who he tells usIbid. pag. 6. proved a vertuous good Wife, but soon left him a sorrowful Widower on 5 Decem∣ber, 1641.Ibid. pag. 9. to his awn Grief, and the Grief
of all her Friends, and was buried at the West End of the South Ile, near the en∣trance into the Church of Astbury in Che∣shire. Upon the News of her Death, which he heard not till some Days after, being absent at London, he declares, That Ibid pag. 9. she was a virtuous, modest, careful and loving Wife; her Affection was exceeding great towards me, as was mine to her, which caused us to live so happily together. By her he had one Female Still-born Child, 19 May, 1640. In Michaelmas Term, 1639. he became a Solicitor in the High Court of Chancery, andIbid pag. 6. had in∣different good Practice, and being admit∣ted of Clement's Inn, was sworn an At∣torney in the Court of Common Pleas, 11 February, 1641. In 1644. he was made a Commissioner of the Excise, but was opposed in the Execution of his Office by Collonel Bagott, Governor of Litch∣field, and was afterwards put into another Commission of the Excise at Worcester, 15 December, 1645. which Commission was again renewed, and Mr. Ashmole con∣tinued, and elected Register to the aforesaid Commission, 27 April, 1646. On May 9, 1645. by Sir George Wharton's Interest,
then a Captain in Defence of the Royal Cause, he was entred one of the Four Gentlemen of the Ordnance in the Gar∣rison at Oxford, and on 12 March, 1646. was constituted a Captain in the Lord Ashley's Regiment. While he was thus firmly engaged in the King's desperate Affairs at Oxford, and elsewhere, the ad∣ditional Stroke of his Mother's Death happened in July, 1646. who died of the Plague at Litchfield, and of whom he has given an Account in the following Expres∣sions, Ibid. pag. 15. She was a discreet, sober, provi∣dent Woman, and with great Patience en∣dured many Afflictions. Her Parents had given her exceeding good Breeding, and she was excellent at her Needle, which (my Fa∣ther being improvident) stood her in great stead. She was competently read in Divi∣nity, History, and Poetry, and was conti∣nually instilling into my Ears such religious and moral Precepts as my younger Years were capable of. Nor did she ever fail to correct my Faults, always adding sharp Re∣proofs and good Lectures to boot. She was much esteemed of by Persons of Note, with whom she was acquainted. She lived in much Friendship among her Neighbours, and
left a good Name behind her: In fine, she was truly Religious and Virtuous. On October 16 he was elected a Brother of the Company of Free Masons, with Collonel Henry Mainwaring, of Kerthingham in Cheshire, at Warrington in Lancashire, a Favour esteemed so singular by the Mem∣bers, that Kings themselves have not dis∣dain'd to enter themselves into this So∣ciety, the original Foundation of which is said to be as high as the Reign of King Henry III, when the Pope granted a Bull, Patent, or Diploma, to a particular Com∣pany of Italian Masons and Architects to travel over all Europe to build Churches. From these is derived the Fraternity of Adopted Masons, Accepted Masons, or Free Masons, who are known to one another all over the World by certain Signals and watch Words known to them alone. They have several Lodges in different Countries for their Reception; and when any of them fall into Decay, the Brotherhood is to relieve him. The manner of their A∣doption, or Admission, is very formal and solemn, and with the Administration of an Oath of Secrecy, which has had better Fate than all other Oaths, and has been ever most religiously observed, nor has the World been yet able, by the inadver∣tency, surprize, or folly of any of its Mem∣bers
to dive into this Mystery, or make the least discovery. During the Rage of the Civil War our Author faithfully served his distressed Prince, and when his own Con∣cessions, and the Fury of the People had brought him to the fatal Scaffold, unwil∣ling to be a sad Spectator of the almost daily Triumphs over oppressed Loyalty in this Metropolis, he retired into this Coun∣ty, where amidst the Pleasures of a rural Solitude he prepared some Things which have since seen the Light. Here well contented with this Obscurity he tells us, “ThatIbid. pag. 17. it pleased God to put me in mind, that I was now (1647.) placed in the Condition I always desired, which was, that I might be enabled to live to my self and Studies, without being forced to take pains for a Livelihood in the World: And seeing I am thus retired, according to my Heart's desire, I beseech God to bless me in my Retirement, and to pros∣per my Studies, that I may faithfully and diligently serve him, and in all Things submit to his Will; and for the Peace and Happiness I enjoy (in the midst of bad Times) to render him all
humble Thanks, and for what I attain to in the Course of my Studies, to give him the Glory.” In the Year 1648. an Estate at Bradfield, where he was Lord of the Manor, and elsewhere in this Coun∣ty, was sequestred for his former active Loyalty, but by the Interest of some Friends among the godly, the Sequestrati∣on was taken off at Reading, 21 Nov. 1648. On Nov. 16. 1649. he was mar∣ried to Mary, the sole Daughter of Sir William Forster, of Aldermarston, in this County, Baronet, the Wilow of Sir Tho∣mas Mainwaring, Kt. late Recorder of the Corporation of Reading, and one of the Masters in the High Court of Chancery. In 1652. the Theatram Chymicum Britan∣nicum was published, the Pictures of which were engraved at Mr. Ashmole's own House, by that eminent Artist of his Profession, Mr. Vaughan. By the Interest of Sir Humphrey Forster, who claimed a Right of Presentation to the Benefice of Bradfield, our Author met with many difficulties from the Tryers, to whom he presented three different Persons to be ad∣mitted to this Living, the last of which the Committee, after some contest, con∣niv'd at. In his last Match some Matri∣monial Jars happening, and his Wife suing for separate Alimony, he tells us,
ThatIbid. pag. 34. 1657. Octob. 8. the Cause between me and my Wife was heard, where Mr. Ser∣jeant Maynard observed to the Court, that there were eight hundred Sheets of Deposi∣tions on my Wife's Part, and not one Word proved against me of using her Ill, nor ever giving her a bad or provoking Word. The Issue of this was, that the Lady was de∣livered to her Husband, and the Cause adjudged frivolous, and without Grounds. In 1657. he attended Mr. Dugdale in his Survey of the Fen Country, and was ve∣ry assistant to him in that excellent Un∣dertaking, so much for the Honour and Advantage of the Nation; and the Effects of this Journey were visible sometime after, in a large and judicious Account of those Marshy Countries. The same Year he traced the Roman Road from Weedon, by Antoninus termed Bennavenna, on Wat∣ling-street, to Litchfeld, of which he sent some AccountSee Miscellanies on several Curious Subjects, lately pub∣lished from their respective Originals, Lond. 1714. 8vo. to his inseparable Friend, Mr. Dugdale, in a Letter dated April 20. On Nov. 11. 1657. he was admitted a Member of the Middle Temple, and in May 1658. first began his Collection of Materials for the Work of the Garter
Aug. 21. 1659. his Study was broke open by the Soldiers on pretence of searching for King Charles II. Decemb. 16. 1659. Mr. John Tredescant and his Wife sealed and delivered a Deed of Gift of all their Ra∣rities then preserved at South Lambeth in Surrey. On June 18. 1660. The Church and State being restored to its antient Glory, Mr. Ashmole was introduced by Mr. Thomas Chifinch to kiss the King's Hand, with whom he discoursed some Hours the next Day, and then was con∣stituted Windsor Herald, and his Patent signed on the 22d of the same Month, and took the common Oaths of his Office on Aug. 10. following. Soon after this he was appointed by the King to make a Description of his Medals, and had them delivered into his Hands, and King Henry the VIIIth's Closet assigned for that purpose. At the same Time was also a Commission issued out for the Examina∣tion of that infamous Buffoon, and Trum∣peter of Rebellion, Hugh Peters, concern∣ing the disposal of the Pictures. Jewels, &c. belonging to the Royal Family, which were committed chiefly to his Care, and fold and dispersed over Europe, and are yet in the Closets of several Princes, who then con∣nived at, nay encouraged, the Depraeda∣tions made on the Royal Exile, and en∣riched
their own Cabinets, with the inva∣luable Curiosities of England, at a very cheap Rate, which neither Generosity, Honour, nor Justice, has ever induced them to restore, though they well knew the invalidity of the Title upon which they purchased; but crowned Heads have as little regard to Honour or Justice, when they interfere with their Interest, as the vulgar, else, how shall we account for their courting the Usurper, conceding to the most unreasonable Demands, and sacrificing all, even to the most sanguine Expectations he could entertain. This Commission was soon brought to a con∣clusion, by the Obstinacy, or Ignorance of their Criminal, who either would not, or was not able to give the desired satis∣faction: Thus was this Matter dropt, and every one left, if their own Consciences permitted, to enjoy without any mole∣station, the Plunder they had collected. Aug. 21. 1660. our Author presented to the King the Three Books he had pub∣lished during the Usurpation. viz. Fasci∣culus Chymicus, Theatrum Britannicum, and The Way to Bliss, which his Majesty re∣ceived very graciously; and soon after, Sept. 3. signed a Warrant to him for the Comptrollership of the Excise, Nov. 2. 1660. he was called to the Bar in the
Middle Temple Hall, and admitted to it on the 7th following. Jan. 15. 1661. he was admitted one of the Fellows of the Royal Society, and on February 9. a War∣rant was signed to constitute him Secretary of Surinam in the East Indies. April 13. 1661. the King gave Orders to my Lord Chamberlain to settle him as the first He∣rald, in case any dispute should happen. On February 17. 1665. Sir Edward Byshe sealed his Deputation for the Visitation of this County, which was begun on the 11th of March following. On June 9. 1668. he was appointed by the Lords Commissioners of the Treasury, to execute the Office of Accomptant General in the Excise, and Country Accomptant. On April 1. 1668. the Lady Mainwaring, his second Wife, died, and he was marri∣ed to his third Wife, Elizabeth, Daugh∣ter to Sir William Dugdale, Kt. Garter King at Arms, by Dr. Lloyd, (since Bishop of Worcester) in Lincoln's Inn Chapel. On July 9. 1669. he was by a Diploma created Doctor of Physick by the Uni∣versity of Oxford, which was presented to him by Dr. Yates, Principal of Brazen Nose College, on Nov. 3. following. In 1672 The History of the Garter was pre∣sented to King Charles II. by the Author, on May 8. for which, on June 18. follow∣ing
he received a Privy Seal for 400 Pounds out of the Custom of Paper. On July 25. 1671. he surrendred his Heralds Place. Upon the Death of Sir Edward Walker, Garter, on Feb. 20. 1677. a Con∣troversy rising between the King and Earl Marshal, upon the Right of the disposal of this Office, Mr. Ashmole was of Opini∣on, That the Right was vested in the King, which was confirmed March 30. 1677. at a Hearing before some Lords of the Council, and some Knights of the Garter. After the Determination of this Matter, Mr. Ashmole was very much importuned to accept of this High Office, which he declined, to prevent suspicion of Partiality in giving his Opinion at first for the King, and to gratify his Father in Law, Sir Wil∣liam Dugdale, who was created Garter, Principal King at Arms, on May 24. fol∣lowing. In this Matter, though assi∣stant to his Majesty in asserting his Maje∣sty, he behaved himself with so much Circumspection and Prudence, that it gave no Umbrage to the Earl Marshal, who himself publickly applauded his Be∣haviour. But let his own Reasons, why he was unwilling to sue for GARTER's Place, answer for him, communicated by a Gentleman of Worth, and inserted at full length.

MY Lord Bishop of Salisbury having been at my House in Sheere Lane (which then stood empty,Feb. 21. 1676-77. I having some Time before retired into the Country to dwell) and at my Cham∣ber in the Temple, but missing me at both Places, heard at length I dwelt at South Lambeth, whereupon the next Day he sent me an obliging Letter (Feb. 22.) to ac∣quaint me, That as soon as he heard of Sir Edward Walker's Death (which happened the 20th of Feb. preceding) he endeavour-to find me out, but being not able, he im∣mediately spoke to the Duke of York, and some other Knights of the Garter, to move the King on my behalf to succeed him, but the Duke wished him rather to move the Matter to the King, because he was pre-engaged, viz. to the Earl Marshal, and immediately gave him an Opportuni∣ty to do it. The King gave him such an Answer as caused him to believe and hope his Inclinations were very good to me; but it appeared after, that the Earl Mar∣shal had acquainted the King witha Claim himself had to the disposing of that Office, which induced his Majesty to give the Bi∣shop no positive Answer.

This Letter his Lordship sent me by one of his Gentlemen, who found me at
home under a Fortnights ill Indisposition, by whom I returned my most humble Thanks, and informed him I had no Incli∣nation to accept of the Place, and there∣fore desired him to press it no farther, and that I would attend him as soon as I was able to stir out of Doors, and then ac∣quaint him with the Reasons of my refusal.

March 3. I went to give my Lord Bi∣shop of Salisbury my personal Thanks for so real a Kindness, and told him I was re∣tired into the Country with Resolutions to take upon me no new Employments, and had (to make my Retirement more comfortable and easy) resigned my He∣rald's Place, and thrown off all other kind of Business (except the Comptrollership of the Excise) and for that reason was not willing to enter again upon any other whatsoever; and that in case his Majesty should enquire of him, why he did not present his Suit on my behalf, he should be ready to answer, that my Employment in the Excise took up my whole Time, and I was doubtful, least my Attendance at Whitehall, the Herald's Office, or else∣where, upon Matters relating to this Of∣fice, might occasion me to neglect that Service, which so nearly related to his Ma∣jesty's Profit and Advantage.

March 7. 1676-77. This Morning I went to wait upon my Lord Marshal, who told me, he heard I used Means to the King to obtain GARTER's Place, but conceived it was his Right, as Earl Marshal, to dis∣pose of it; I repeated him the Reasons I had before given his Secretary, why I was of Opinion it was the King's Right, not his, and denied that I so much as look∣ed after the Place, and therefore acquaint∣ed him first with what the Bishop of Sa∣lisbury, out of Kindness to me, had done (though without my Knowledge) next, that I had entreated him to proceed no further; and lastly, gave his Lordship the same Reasons for declining the Employ∣ment, which I had before given to the Bi∣shop. He thereupon desired me to give him leave to tell the King so much, which I readily did. He then told me, he heard Sir William Howard made means to the King for it, and asked my Opinion whi∣ther he could be GARTER, who was not of the Office of Arms; I answered there had antiently been two Persons made GARTER, who had not been Officers of Arms, but I hoped the King would not so far discourage the present Officers, as to chuse a Stranger in the Place; whereupon he asked me leave to let the King know this was my Sense, which he did; then I
acquainted him that the King had com∣manded me to assist the Chancellor in ma∣king out his Right to the Nomination of GARTER, and though I refused the Place, yet I durst not deny him that Service: This he did not very well like, but I told him, I knew not which way to avoid it.

March 31, 1677. The next Morning after the Earl Marshal's Pretensions to the Right of nominating GARTER had been heard before the Committee appointed for that Purpose, I had occasion to attend my Lord Treasurer Danby about some Busi∣ness in the Excise Office. Mr. Ch. Bertie, his Secretary, seeing me there, asked me, why I did not seek after the Place? and in∣timated, that my Lord Treasurer thought me the fittest Person for it; but I told him, I had no ambition towards it, and feared that my Attendance about this Place might occasion some neglect in the Excise Office; and though this Excuse stood me in some stead, and seemed considerable to others to whom I had made use of it, yet he presently reply'd, my Lord Treasurer would give me leave to execute my Comp∣troller's Place by Deputy. To which I had nothing to reply, but that I had many other Reasons that induced me to wave the Employment. Upon this he told me, my Lord would speak with me in the
Park, where I attended till he came thi∣ther, who, when he came, began to ask me some few Questions about the Prepara∣tions he was to make against his Installa∣tion, and who he should send for, to inform him therein; I answered, it was the Duty of GARTER to inform him, and that, that Affair being debated the Night before (where his Lordship was, and of the Committee) I presumed it would be known e'er long what was then determi∣ned. He answered, the Matter had that Night, before the Committee rose, been determined on the King's side against my Lord Marshal, upon which I told his Lord∣ship, I presumed within a few Days GAR∣TER would be nominated; and in regard it was above a Fortnight to the Day of his Installation, it would be time enough both to attend him, and make all Things ready against that time. And here I presume (by what I gathered from Mr. Bertie's pressing me to make Friends to obtain GARTER's Place) his Lordship expected I would have moved him to have spoke to the King for me, and pausing a little while, asked me, if I had any Thing to say to him. I answered no, and so took my leave.

In the Afternoon Mr. Bertie meeting me again, asked me what Discourse passed
between his Lordship and me: I told him, who wondered I would not move him to speak for me, and used many Arguments to induce me yet to do it, and told me how unfit Mr. Lee (whom my Lord Marshal intended for the Place) was for it, nor was capable of it, not being a Gentleman of Blood, as he heard the Constitutions of the Order required. I still shewed my un∣willingness, and left him. Notwithstand∣ing which, on Monday Morning, April 1. after, he set more earnestly again upon me, and told me, he heard the Place must speedily be disposed of, because the Day appointed for Installation approached, and most earnestly pressed me to apply my self to the King to obtain it; but I told him, I was unfit for the Place, at which he won∣dered I should alledge that, when it ap∣peared by my Book of the Garter, there was no Man fitter. I answered, my un∣fitness grew from Deafness encreasing on me, from decay of my Eye-sight, and greater decay in my Memory, all which considered, did very much incapacitate me from that Service; to which he re∣ply'd, he never knew any Man discom∣mend himself before, when so fair a way lay open for his Preferment. I then gave him many hearty Thanks for his kind In∣clinations to me, and so parted.

April 2. The next Meeting, my Lord Marshal coming out of the Lord's House, he told me the King had pitched upon my Father Dugdale to be GARTER, and be∣lieved that it would not displease me; I answered, I was very glad of it, and I thought it the best Choice; but he being in Warwickshire, his Lordship added, he would send for him up by that Night's Post.

I have been thus particular, because, after this Time, some of the Officers of Arms (Mr. Holford, &c.) my Lord Mar∣shal, had said (and it was most certain) I sought underhand to get GARTER's Place, though openly I seemed to decline it, which I could not but wonder at, because I had been so clear with his Lordship in averring the contrary, so also because his Lordship had told my Father upon his coming to Town, that I had carried my self very fairly in my managing the Busi∣ness against him, though both Honour and Profit lay on this Occasion before me; yet God having taken from me both Am∣bition and Covetousness, I set more va∣lue upon the retired Life I was entred into, than all the Advantage and Honour I should reap by that Office.

In 1677. he was requested to appear as a Candidate for Parliament for the City of Litchfield, by the Bailiffs, upon the Death of Mr. Dyott, their late Representative, but for some time desired to be excused, till upon repeated Letters he was prevailed on to stand, and then found it too late, and the Magistrates and Friends not so cordial as he expected, so that he drew off in time. This he had the more reason to resent, as having been a Benefactor to their Corporation, when at the beginning of 1666. he presented to them a Silver Bowl, for which their Bailiffs, in the Name of the City had made a publick ac∣knowledgment of Gratitude, as you may see in their LetterSee pag. 85. of the Diary..

In 1678. Robert Plott, L. L. D. was recommended by Mr. John Evelyn to Mr. Ashmole, who gave him ample Recommen∣dations to the University of Oxford as a proper Person for their Reader of Natural Philosophy. This Lecture has been by many said to have been founded, and en∣dowed by our Author, Mr. Ashmole; but this Mistake is built upon the Notion ge∣nerally conceived, that he designed such a Benefaction, and an ample and generous
Allowance to the Keeper of his Musaeum at Oxford; but this publick Principle was stifled in Embrio by the influence of a Per∣son who was possessed of an eminent Post in the Church, and in some of his elegant and polite Writings had dropt some Ex∣pressions savouring of Socinianism, which being not undeservedly, and unanswerably attacked by a Member of this University, it was so highly resented, that his Interest with our Author stopt the Design, and the Place still remains unendowed. In 1683. he bestowed on the University of Oxford (who had erected a handsom Re∣pository near the Theatre) a most consi∣derable Collection of Natural and Artifi∣cial Curiosities, which were many Years gathering by the two Tradescants, Father and Son, both successively Physick Gardi∣ners at Lambeth, of which there was a small Account published. This Benefac∣tion Mr. Ashmole augmented much at his Death, May 18. 1692. by the addition of his Library, consisting chiefly of Manu∣scripts, and some printed Books relating to English History, Heraldry, Astronomy, and Chymistry, with a very great Variety of Pamphlets, part whereof had been sort∣ed by himself, and the rest are methodized since, and a double Catalogue of all made, a Classical one according to their various
Subjects, and another Alphabetical. He also bequeathed to the same Place, two Gold Chains and a Medal, the one a Phi∣ligreen Chain of 90 Links, weighing 22 Ounces, with a Medal of the Elector of Brandenburgh, on which is that Elector's Effigies; and on the reverse, a View of Straelsund, struck on the Surrender of that important City. A Collar of S. S. with a Medal of the King of Denmark, also a Gold Medal of the Elector Palatine, and a George of the Duke of Norfolk, worn by his Grandfather, when he was Ambas∣sador in Germany; all which were present∣ed to him as Acknowledgments of the Ho∣nour he had done the Garter, by his La∣bours on that Subject. The other Works published by him, are, I. Fasciculus Chy∣micus, or Chymical Collections, Lond. 1650. 8vo. II. Theatrum Chymicum Bri∣tannicum, Lond. 1652. 4to. III. The Way to Bliss, Lond. 1658. 4to. IV. In∣stitutions, Laws, and Ceremonies of the Order of the Garter, Lond. 1671. Folio. Some also were left in MS. As, I. This present Work concerning Berkshire. II. Two Volumes of Collections of In∣scriptions, Epitaphs, and Arms in several of the Counties of England. III. Three Volumes of the Roman Consular, and Im∣perial Coins, now preserved in the Ar∣chives
of the Bodleian Library, and prepa∣pared for the Press, as appears by its Pre∣faceSee pag. 88. of the Diary.. IV. A Volume of King Charles the Second's Silver Imperial Roman Coins. He was interred at the East End of the North Ile of Lambeth Church in Surrey, in which Parish he led the latter part of his Life, and on a Black Marble Grave-stone placed over him are these Arms, viz. quarterly, Sable, and Or, the first Quar∣ter on a Fleur de Lis of the second; Ash∣mole empaling Dugdale, viz. Argent a Cross Malines Gules, and a Torteaux, with this Motto, Ex uno omnia, and the following Inscription.

Q.L: Hic jacet Inclytus ille et Eruditissimus
ELIAS ASHMOLE, Litchfeldensis, Armiger,
inter alia in Republicâ munera,
Tributi in Cerevisias Contra-Rotulator,
Faecialis autem WINDSORIENSIS titulo
per annos plurimos dignatus,
Qui post duo connubia, in Uxorem duxit tertiam
Militis Garteri, Principalis Regis Armorum filiam:
Mortem obiit 18 Maii, 1692. Anno Aetatis 76.
sed durante Musaeo AHSMOLEANO OXON.
Nunquam moriturus.

LIST.HEAD: A Pedigree of the Name and Family of ASHMOLE, drawn by Elias Ashmole, Es{que} 30 March, 1663. and taken from a Visitation Bood of Staffordshire.
LIST.ITEM:
John Ashmole, of Elford, in Com. Stafford.
Thomas Ashmole, twice Cheif Bailiff of the City of Litchfeld, died II Jan. 1620.
Anne, the Daughter of........ Second of........

Anne, Daughter of Anthony Bow∣yer, Citizen and Draper of Coven∣try.
Eleanor, eldest Daughter of Peter Manwaring, of Smalwood, in Cheshire, his first Wife, died....... 1641.
Elias Ashmole, of the Middle Temple, London, Es{que} and Windsor Herald at Arms, Aetat. 45. Ann. 30 Martii, 1663.
Mary, sole Daughter of Sir William Forster, of Aldermarston, in Berkshire, Bar. Widow of Sir Tho. Manwa∣ring, Kt. one of the Masters in Chan∣cery, his 2d Wife, died 1 Apr. 1668.
Elizabeth, Daughter of Sir William Dug∣dale, Kt. 3d Wife.
2. John Ash∣mole, of New∣castle Under Line, in Staf∣fordshire.
1. John, 2. William.
3. Thomas Ashmole, marri∣ed Dorcas, Daughter of Edward Hill, of the Char∣ter House near Coventry, died in 1659.
Sarah.

Maud.
Coat of Arms of Ashmole, Quart, Azure and Or, in the first a Fleur de Lis, Arg. Crest a Greyhound Cursant.

DIV1.P: The following Dedication is prefixed to the Original M. S. of Mr. Lilly's Life, and omitted in the late Edition printed at London, in 12°. 1715.

DIV2.HEAD: Excellentissimo Viro, ELIAE ASHMOLE, Armigero, D. D. D. hos vitae meae labores.
DIV2.P: PEragrationes totius vitae meae tibi (oh illustrissime ac Literatissime Armiger Elias Ashmole libenter quamvis laboriosissimos communico) cum quam plurimas ejusdem circumstantias adhuc aut ignotas, aut latentes, quae mihi per tot annorum spatium con∣tigerant, profiteor me in hisce scribendis omnem sinceritatem observasse, nec immaniter aut leviter aliquid scripsisse. Non enim nostrae intentionis fuit aliquid in lucem proferre sine maturâ delibera∣tione & consultè, scripsi eo desiderio summopere motus; ut praesentes & futuri sciant, quis fui, ubi natus, quomodo vixi quibusquè studiis versatus fui, si humanitas vestra candidé acceperit hasce sub∣sequentes chartulas, minum in modum gaudebo, sin aliter; clementiam vestram obsecro, ut qualescun∣que sint mittentur flammis. Non ignoro, sed op∣timè scio, non est una omnium ad scientiam prope∣rantium intentio, nec finis quidem unus, aliqui enim multa scire cupiunt eo tantum fine, ut sciant: Et fructum suae curiositatis unum, & in nihilo con∣sistentem recipiunt, aliicire volunt propter commo∣dum temporale, ut assequantur dignitates, divi∣tias, & honores, multiqué hodie ad scientiam se in hunc finem conferre reperiuntur. Ex numero ho∣rum non fuit

DIV1.HEAD: AN INTRODUCTION TO THE ANTIQUITIES OF BERKSHIRE.
DIV1.P:
BERKSHIRE, or BARK∣SHIRE, is bounded by Surrey on the East, Wilt∣shire on the West, on the South by Hampshire, and on the North, partly by Buck∣inghamshire and Oxfordshire, from which two last it is separated by the Rivers of Thames and Isis; it is in length from Coles∣hull to Windsor about forty Miles: within its bounds it takes in part of the South Sub∣urbs of the City of Oxford, of which, in this
Work there is no Account, it being left to some future Undertaker of the Antiqui∣ties of that City. It is likened to a San∣dal, or Slipper; and to a Lute by Fuller, Asser Menevensis, and Leland, derive the Name from Berroc, the Name of a Fost in this County abounding in Box, or Ber∣rock, a Bare Oak, under which Tees the English Saxons formerly held thei Assem∣blies. It is termed in the Saxon Chronicle Bearuscire, and Barroscire, and in length of Time corrupted to Bercesere. or Ba∣rocscire. This was formerly the Seat of the Attrabatii, and may be, perhaps, a Colo∣ny removed from the Attrebates in Gaul. But passing over the Grounds upon which these Conjectures are built, let us descend to Ages of less Obscurity. In the Divisi∣on of the Saxon Heptarchy, this County was included within the Limits of the Kingdom of the West Saxons; afterwards England being united under King Alfred, another Division was made, and when the Office of High Sheriff, or Vice-Comes, was instituted, this and the adjoyning County of Oxford were put under the same Person. The nearest Part of this County is about Twenty Miles from London, is in the Diocese of Salibury; the middle of it in the Latitude of 52 Degrees, and in Longitude 1 Degree and 20 Min. contains
22 Hundreds, 12 Market Towns, 671 Villages and Hamlets, of which 140 are Parochial, and 62 are Vicarages, and about 16906 Houses, and about 84530 In∣habitants; sends 9 Representatives to Par∣liament; is in some Parts well wooded and watered by the Rivers of Thames, Isis, and Kennet, the two first of which are already Navigable, the last is now, by Act of Parliament, to be made so from Reading to Newbury, which is already ac∣complished up to Aldermarston. This County may be rather valued for its plea∣sant Situation than its Fertility, the Air being generally healthy, even in the low∣est Vales, which may be judged to be the reason of the high Price the Land of this County bears. Its Commodities are Wheat, Flower, Barley, and one parti∣cular Species of that Grain, called Palney Barley, and all Sorts of Corn, but ex∣ceeds many other Counties in its Malting. It abounds in Wood and Cattle, but has long lost its antient Credit for the Clothing Manufacture, which was the greatest in Newbury and Reading, and supplyed al∣most the whole Nation. The Parts which seem to be most fruitful and advantagious to their Lords, are situate on the Banks of Thames and Kennet, and the Vale of White Horse, so called from the Shape of a Horse
fancied to be represented on the side of a Chalky Hill. Within this County is the Forest of Windsor, in which are several small Towns, taken Notice of by Mr. Ash∣mole, who has omitted Ockingham, per∣haps because the Church stands in Wilt∣shire, but the Town it self being in this County, I shall not judge it improper to give the following Account of it.

DIV2.HEAD: OCKINGHAM,
DIV2.P:
Called also Wokingham, is pleasantly si∣tuate on an Eminence, a large and hand∣some Market Town, the Parish is in Cir∣cumference twelve, and in Length five Miles, in Breadth three, and distant from London thirty Miles. It is bounded on the East by Easthamsted, on the West by Finchamsted, on the North by Barkham, and Southward by Hurst. Most of the Land in this Parish is Common, little arable Land, the Soil generally Sandy, some Parts clayey and swampy, the Pro∣fits arising to the Farmers chiefly from Pa∣sturage. Here are three Fairs kept an∣nually, I. On All-Saints Day. II. The Thursday after Shrove Tuesday. III. On June 11. St. Barnabas. Market Day is weekly, on Tuesday. Lord of the Manor
is Sir Robert Rich, of Sunning, Kt. and Bar. Impropriator Scory Barker, of Chis∣wick in Middlesex, Es{que} the present Vicar is the Reverend Mr. Benjamin Moody. The Parish Church is almost at the end of the Town, is antient, large, and well built, consisting of a Chancel, Nave, and two Iles on each side of the Body, sup∣ported by neat stone Pillars: At the West End is a Tower containing Six Bells.
Against the East Wall of the Chancel, on a Black Marble Table, enchased in White, in Gold Capitals, is this Inscrip∣tion.

Q.P: Memoriae S. Parentiss. chariss. Patris vere Reverendi Thomae Good wyni, S. Theol. Doctoris Aedis Christi Oxon primum, ac deinde Cantuariens. Decani Bathon.
Demum ac Wellen. Episcopi, qui hoc in oppido natus, hic etiam (dum valetudinis recuperandae gratiâ, consulentibus Medicis, huc succedit) quartanâ febre confectus mortalitatem exuit Novem. 9. 1590.
Consecr: suae A°. 7mo. et hic jacet. expectans adventum magni Dei Pos.
Fil. Franciscus Goodwyn, Exon. Sub-Decanus.

DIV2.P: On the North Side, against the same Wall, is an Oval Black Marble Tablet, enchased, and ornamented with White Leaves and Flowers, and supported by two black Marble Corinthian Pillars, and on it this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: In Memory of Edward Cotton, Es{que} (late of this Parish) This Monument was erected by Elizabeth his Wife, and sole Executrix, Obiit 28 Dec. 1682.

Q.L: This worthy Name ofSic. Orig. Squire Cotton
Can never dye, although his 'Bones ly rotten;
Eased from all Paines, removed far from Strife,
A tender Husband to his loveing Wife,
Sleeps nigh this Place, he past through Life to Death,
And won the Race, although he lost his Breath:
Hee'th pay'd the Debt, which once we must pay all,
His Vertues live, though after's Funerall.
His surviveing Relict, for a good Intent,
Hath caused to be raised this Monument.

DIV2.Q: Vivit post funera Virtus.
DIV2.P: On a Black Marble Grave-stone under∣neath, in Capitals, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lieth the Body of Edward Cotton, Es{que} eldest Son of Edward, Arch-Deacon of Exon (and Grandson to the Right Reverend Father in God, William Lord Bishop of Exon) who departed this Life the 28th Day of December, Anno Dom. 1682. and in the 59th Year of his Age.
DIV2.P: Against the South Wall, on a Black Marble Tablet enchased in White, on the Top an Urn, underneath a Pelican sable, feeding her young, Crest a Castle, both sup∣ported by two Cupids, and adorned with Festoons of Fruit and Flowers, and this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Near this Place lieth interred the Body of HUMPHREY CANTREIL, Senior, Gen. of this Parish, dcceased; and also, the Body of HUMPHREY CANTRELL, junior, Gent. deceased, to whose
Memory his tender and sorrowful Mother has erected this Monument, he having been in his Life Time a very loving and dutifull Son to her.
DIV2.P: On a White Free-stone Grave-stone, in Capitals, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth interred the Body of Humphrey Cantrell, Gent. who departed this Life the first Day of March, 1689. aged 65 Years, also the Body of Humphrey, the Son of Humphrey Cantrell, abovesaid, lyeth here interred, who departed this Life the 9th. Day of November, 1695. in his Three and Twentieth Year.
DIV2.P: On a Black Marble Grave-stone, in Capitals, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Here lyeth the Body of Sic. Orig. Gervass Berkeley, Es{que} who departed this Life the 8th Day of September,
in the Year of our Lord, 1699.
DIV2.P: Against the East Wall of the North Ile, on a Wooden Tablet in a Frame, in Black Capitals, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: William Irish, who having first served in the Warres of the Netherlands, was afterwardes a Captain at Sea, and lastly, a Magistrate of this Towne, whereof he was Alderman twice, who departed this Life the Tenth Day of October, 1623.
DIV2.P: On a White Free-stone Grave-stone un∣derneath, in Capitals, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Captaine William Irish, Gent. Alderman, which deceased the Tenth Day of October, Anno Domini, 1623.
DIV2.P:
In the middle Ile, on a Brass Plate, un∣der the Figures of a Man and his two Wives, all Three in a devotional Po∣sture, was an Inscription, now lost; out of the Mouth of the Woman, on the
right Hand, proceeds a Lemma thus in∣scribed.

Q.L: djuv nos Deus salutaris noster,
Et propter gloriam nominis tui Domine.

DIV2.P: Out of the Woman's Mouth on the left Hand.

Q.L: Libera nos et propitius esto peccatis nostris
Propter nomen tuum ne in eternum irascaris nobis.

DIV2.P: On a Brass Plate fixed within the South Wall, under the Figures of a Man and Woman kneeling opposite to each other, between them a Faldstool containing two Books, and on it this Inscription.

Q.L: Witt, Wealth, Shape, Birth lye buried here,
Thinges, while we live, we value all too dear;
But such as leave us when we leave our Breath,
Unfaithfull Freindes, forsaking us in Death;
No Covenant with the Grave, we must resign,
Some of us now, and some another Time.
He liveth not long, that many Years can tell,
But he liveth evermore, that liveth well.

DIV2.P: On this is neither Name nor Date to give any Intelligence to whom it be∣longed.
On a Black Grave-stone, in Capitals, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Under this Stone lyeth buried Michaell Townesend, and Sarah Townesend, the Children of Nathaniell and Mary Townesend, of London, 1656.
DIV2.P: On another Grave-stone is this In∣scription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Judeth Brooksbanke, Daughter of Joseph and Mary, who departed the Life August the 10th. 1689. in the Eighth Year of her Age.
DIV2.P: In the middle Ile, on a large Black Marble Grave-stone, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Mr. SIMON WEAVER, Citizen and Cutler of London, born in this Parish, who departed this Life the 25th of November, 1699. In the 76th Year of his Age.
DIV2.P: On a Wooden Tablet fixed to a South∣ward Pillar, near the Screen between the Church and Chancel, are inscribed the following Benefactions.

Mr. John Tickner, Gent. of this Parish, gave to the Poor of this Parish 5 Pounds yearly for ever, 3 Pounds in Bread, to be divided between the Poor of this Town, and the Poor of Berks, and the Poor of Wilts of this Parish; also 20s. yearly for the Schooling of two Boys, and 20 s. yearly to cloath them, to be pay'd out of the Land called Beenoak, in the Tithing of Charles Wood, in the County of Berks, bounding on the North West Lands of Richard Grape, and South West of the other Lands called Beenoak, and on the East and West lead∣ing from Pattenash, now in the Occupati∣on of Mary Cotterell of this Parish, 1715.
On another Tablet fixed to the Screen, A Catalogue of several Gifts to this Town and Parish.
Mr. Robert Ball Tenn Pounds per An∣num at Binfield.
Mr. William Thare 3 l. 8s. 4d. per An∣num, out of Houses and Land in this Pa∣rish, for decayed Tradesmen.
Mr. John Tickner 2l. per Annum, out of Land in Easthamsted, payable to the Church-Wardens.
Mr. John Planner 3 Pounds per Annum, out of Land in Hurst, for Apprenticing a Child.
Mr. George Staverton a House and Land at Staines, of 6 Pounds per Annum, to buy a Bull, and for the Use of the Poor.
Mr. Bartholomew Bromley 15l. 5s. per Annum, out of Land in Garsington in Oxon, to buy Bread.
Mr. Ralph White gave the Alms-Houses with Two Houses, and a Piddle of Land belonging to them, at Five Pounds per Annum.
Henry Lucas, Es{que} gave Two Place in the Hospital.
Mr. John Broadbank 17s. 4d. per An∣num to this Towne and Parish, after one Life it will be 2l. 12s. per Annum, for ever.
Mr. Richard Howe, at present, 1l. 10s. per Annum, but after two Lives it may be 4l. per Annum in Land in Finchamsted.
Mr. Richard Young about 1l. per An∣num in Land, in this Parish.
Mr. Francis Frewen 6s. 8d. Per Annum, out of the Catherine Wheel in Henley. Richard Palmer, Es{que} 2 Pounds per An∣num, for Ringing the great Bell Morning and Evening.
Doctor RobertSic. Orig. Chalenor 2 Pounds per Annum, out of the Farm, called Southes in this Parish.
Mr. John Merriwether about 3l. 10s. per Annum, to buy Coats.

Mr. Robert Whitelock 3 Pounds per An∣num in Land in this Parish, to Appren∣tice a Child, and Ten Shillings per An∣num for a Breakfast to the Trustees, to meet and take an Account how the Mo∣ney is disposed of.
On another large Tablet, in a gilded Frame, is inscribed the following Bene∣factions.

To the pious Memory of Charles Palmer, Doctor of Physick, who by his last Will and Testament gave to the Minister of this Town, and Parish of Wokingham, in Reversion after one Life, Ten Pounds per Annum for ever, as an Augmentation to his Salary, whose Will also was, that the said Minister shall preach a Charity Sermon in this Church, on the 15th of Fe∣bruary yearly, it being the Testator's Birth Day, and also by his said Will, gave Twenty Pounds per Annum more, for
ever, to a School-Master, to teach Twenty poor Boys to Write, Read, and cast Ac∣compts, in order to fit them for Mechani∣cal Trades, Twelve of which Boys are to be chosen out of the Town, and Eight out of the Parish of Wokingham Berks, and so to continue from time to time for ever.
Over the Chancel Door, on a Black Tablet, in golden Capital Letters, is a Catalogue of the following Gifts.
William Laud, Arch-Bishop of Canter∣bury, gave to this Town 60l. per Annum, and every Third Year 701. for Boys and Maids.

Thomas Winder, Gent. gave Ten Pounds per Annum to this Town; 2s. 6d. weekly in Bread, 10s. to the Minister for a Sermon on the 5th of November, and the same Day 20s. in Money to the poor, to be distributed; and 10s. to the Mini∣ster for a Sermon on the 21st of December, and 20s. to the Poor of this Town, and 10s. yearly to the Clerk.
William Monk, of this Town, gave 12s. a Week in Bread for ever.
Thomas Martin, Gent, of this Town, gave 6 Pounds per Annum in 1684. for clothing and teaching five poor Boys.
On a Tablet fixed to the North Gallery.
DIV2.Q: A Catalogue of Gifts to this Town and Parish.
DIV2.P: Mr. Richard Brackstone gave to this Town 5 s. per Annum; and also 3s. 4d. to the Berkshire part, and 1s. 8.d. to the Wiltshire part of this Parish for ever.
The Land and Windmill was bought and built with 100l. given to the poor of the Town by Mr. Jay, 1717.

Memorandum, The charitable Legacy of 15l. 5s. per Annum, given to the poor of this Town and Parish by Bartholomew Bromley, Gent. being lost for many Years, was, at last, redeemed and recovered by the indefatigable Care and Paines of the Reverend Mr. Robert Gunnis, Vicar of Winckfield in the County of Berks.
On a plain Free-stone Tomb, at the West End of the Church Yard, is the fol∣lowing Inscription.

Q.P: H. S. E.

Gulielmus Segory, A. M. ex Aede Christi, Oxon. olim, Industria et Disciplina Pietate eximius, linguarum Latinae, Graecae,
et Hebraicae criticè peritus, ab omni tamen uperbiâ alienus, qui Scholam privatam in hoc oppido foeliciter instituit, et informandis puerorum animis vires exhausit, tandem senio confectus Scholam et supremum diem clausit, Decembr. 12.
A. D. MDCXCVII.

DIV2.P: On another Free-stone Tomb is this Inscription.

Q.P: Here lies the Body of Mrs. Sarah Hawes, Wife of Mr. Richard Hawes of Richmond in Surry. She died Janry. the 1st. 1715-16. in the 5oth Year of her Age.
This Monument was erected by her Husband Mr. Rich. Hawes.
On a Tomb, on the North Side, is this nscription.

DIV2.Q: Here lyes interred the Body of Henry Mountague, Gent. and Mary his Wife, she departed this Life the 20th of July, 1696. aged 74 Years, and he the 3d of November in the same Year, aged 90 Years, and also one Daughter, with 4 Grand-Children near this Place.
DIV2.P: On an Octangular Sun-Dial fixed to a Post on the South Side of the Church Yard, in Capitals, is this Inscription.

Q.P: John Martine, Grocer of London, gave this Dial in Anno 1582.
Christo. Pickard, 1618.

DIV2.P:
In this Parish is LUCKLEY Green, whereon is a fair Hospital, being a Front and two Sides, founded by Henry Lucas, Es{que} Secretary to the Earl of Holland, Lord Chief Justice in Eyre, during some part of the Reign of King Charles I. of blessed Memory, the Endowment is for 16 Pensioners, who have each Ten Pounds per Annum, and for Divine Offices a Chap∣lain (not subject to the Bishop's Court or Visitation) who preaches once every Sun∣day, and reads the Morning and Evening Prayers of the Church of England daily, for which he is allowed Fifty Pounds per Annum, and is termed Master. The Estate, with which this Hospital is endow∣ed, lyes at Harlington, and thereabouts, near Ampthill in Bedfordshire. The Trustees of this Charity are the Company of Grocers in London, who elect and con∣firm the Chaplain, or Master, and Pen∣sioners, the last of which are presented to
them by the following Parishes of this County, and Surrey, alternately, as they become vacant.
Over the inward Door, in Gold Capi∣tals, on a Black Marble Stone, is this In∣scription.

Q.P:
Henry Lucas, Es{que} among other Monu∣ments of Piety and Charity, did de∣vote this Hospitail to the Glory of God,
and Comfort of the Poore, for the Benefitt and Example of Posterity. 1663.
Has Aedes Structor divino vovit honori: Vestro Posteritas vovit amica bono; Ditibus exemplum praebens, solamen egenis, Utere qui pauper, qui locuples sequere.

DIV2.P: In the West Window of the Hall is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Henry Lucas, Es{que} Founder of this Hospital, built by his Executors, Robert Raworth, and Thomas Bucks, Esqs; 1665.
DIV2.P:
Masters Names since the Foundation.
...... Hurdman.
Thomas Hodges.
Charles Cleeve, M. A. è Coll. Sidn. Suss. Cantab.
Nathaniel Johnston, M. A. è Coll. Regin. Cantab.
George Hemsworth, M. A. è Coll. Christi, Cantab.

DIV2.HEAD: LANGFORD.
DIV2.P:
This Town lyes partly in Oxfordshire, and partly in this County, bounded East∣ward by Clanfield, on the North by Brad∣well, on the South by Kencot, all in Ox∣fordshire, and on the West by Latchlade in Gloucestershire. Part of this Parish is the Corpse of a Prebendal Stall in the Cathe∣dral Church of Lincoln. The present Possessor is William Offley, M. A. Rector of Middleton Stony in Oxfordshire, who lets all Leases in Langford, and pots in Lives. Dean and Chapter of Lincoln are Visitors. Lords of the Manor are George Brodericke, of Cockerills, Es{que} and Mr. Pye. Impro∣priator, and Patron, is Mrs. Kechmie, Sister to Mr. Bray, of Barrington in Glou∣cestershire. Vicar is the Reverend Mr. Edward Davis, of Gloucester Hall (now Worcester College) in Oxford, to whom this Benefice is worth about Eighty Pounds per Annum. Part of the Church, and Coemitery adjoyning, stand in this County, and part in Oxfordshire: The Apparitor of the Deanery of Witney, in the Diocese of Oxford, always Summons the Vicar to the Oxfordshire Visitation held by the Bishop or Arch-Deacon, but the Institution is given
by the Bishop of Salisbury, as in that Diocese, which seems to confirm the Po∣sition of this Place in Berkshire, where I venture to put it; and the dubiousness of this Affair seems to be the Reason of Mr. Ashmole's Omission.
The Church is large and handsome, and has in it the following Inscriptions on Monuments, or Grave-stones, viz.

On a Brass Plate fixed to a Black Marble Grave-stone, within the Altar Rails, round the Figures of a Man in a Gown, and his Wife in a Ruff and Fardingale by him, both standing in a devout Posture, in Ca∣pitals, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth buryed the Bodyes of Wal∣ter Prunes, of Langforde, in the Coun∣tye of Berks, Gent. and Mary his Wife, Daughter to Thoby Playdell, of Greate Farrington, in the said County, Es{que} He deceased the, 25 Day of Februarye, 1594. She deceased the 22th Day of March, 1609.

Q.P: Under their Feet.
Christus mihi Vita, Mors mihi Licrum.

DIV2.P: On another Brass Plate fixed to a Mar∣ble Grave-stone, in Capitals, is this In∣scription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth buryed the Body of John Copley, the Sonne of William Copley, of this Parish, Gent, who departed this Life the 22th of December, Anno Dni. 1634.
DIV2.P: On another Brass Plate fixed to the same Stone, in Capitals, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here also lyeth interred the Body of Mary his Wife, Daughter to John Stephens, of Colchester, in the County of Essex, Es{que} who departed this Life on the XXI of August, in the LXXVth. Year of her Age. Anno Dni. 1665.
DIV2.P: Over the Altar is I. H. S. and I Corinth. chap. 11. v. 23.
In the middle Ile, on a Black Marble Grave-stone, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Francis Broderwick, Es{que} who departed this Life the 25th. Day of December, 1710. aged 44 Years.
DIV2.P: On a small White Marble Tablet, fix∣ed to a Southward Pillar, is this Inscrip∣tion following.

Q.P: M. S.

Near this Place lyeth the Body of ANNE, late Wife of THOMAS HAMERSLEY, Citizen and Draper of London; She was the eldest Daughter of THOMAS TURNER, of Kelmscott in the County of Oxon, Gent. and was twice married, first to WILLIAM WOODWARD, of Butlers Marston in the County of Warwick, Gent. by whom she hadSic Orig. noe Issue. By her second Husband she had four Sons, THOMAS, WILLIAM, JOHN, and CHARLES, who all surviv'd her, except JOHN, who lyeth here interred by her. After a long Indisposition of Body, she departed this Life the 27th. of Oct. 1694. in the 43 Year of her Age.
Nulli secunda, Cujus virtutes laudibus Marmoratis perenniores.

DIV2.P: On a Black Marble Grave-stone, under the Pews, is this Insrcription.
DIV2.Q: SAPHINA, the Wife of FRANCIS BRODERWICK, Gent. Daughter of Sir JOHN FETTIPLACE, of Swinbrook, in the County of OXON. Baront. She departed this Life the 6th. of October, 1700.
DIV2.P: On another Black Marble Grave-stone is this Inscription.

Q.P: Here lyeth the Body of Francis, the Son of Francis Broderwick, Gent. by Sophia his Wife. He was buried the 12 Day of January, 1698.
Here lyeth the Body of Sophia, the Daughter of Francis Broder wick, Gent. by Sophia his Wife; she was buried the 4 Day of November, 1699.

DIV2.P: On a White Free-stone Grave-stone, in Capitals, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth buryed the Body of Richard Broderwick, Gent. who deceased the 17 Day of January, An. Do. 1681.
DIV2.P: In the North Ile, on a White Free-stone Grave-stone, in Capitals, is the following Inscription.

Q.P: Here lyeth the Body of Frances, the Wife of Richard Broderwick, Gent. She departed the 15 Day of March, An. Dam. 1696-97.
Sic. Orig. Hear lyeth the Body of Elizabeth, the Daughter of Francis Broderwick, Gent. by Henrieta his Wife, departed the 1 Day of April, An. Dom. 1697.

DIV2.P: On another White Free-stone Grave∣stone, in Capitals, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Here lyeth the Body of Mary, the Wife of Tobias Wills, Rector of Turdeane, who departed this Life, August the 24th. 1709.
Here allso lyeth the Body of Mary Yeateman, Daughter of Alexander Yeateman, by Mary his Wife, who departed this Life June the 23. 1712.

DIV2.P: At the West End of the Church, on a White Free-stone Grave-stone, in Capi∣tals, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Thomas Pearce, Gent. who departed this Life the 9th Day of March, 1711. aged. 79.
DIV2.P: Over the South Door of the Church, without side; is the Figure of the Cruci∣fixion, attended by the two Women in Basso Relievo.
A Wake is kept here about a Fortnight before Michaelmas.

Within this Parish lyes LITTLE FAR∣RINGDON, and GRAFTON, two small Hamlets; and RADCOT BRIDGE, which is built over the River Isis, and broke down by the Earl of Derby in 1387. to hinder the March of an Army of 6000 Men under Robert Vere, 4th Earl of Ox∣ford, created by Richard II. Marquis of Dublin and Duke of Ireland, who being forced to fight the Confederate Rebel Lords, and being worsted, to save his Life, attempted, and swam this Passage.
DIV2.Q: Additions to HURST, mentioned in page 400 of the second Volume.
DIV2.P: Here is an Alms-House, founded by Sir Richard Harrison, for twelve Men and Women, who have each an Allowance of Three Shillings and Six Pence weekly, and Gowns yearly.
DIV2.Q: Additions to ALDERMASTON, men∣tioned in page 21 of the first Volume.
DIV2.P: In the Church, on a Black Marble Grave-stone, before the Altar, is this In∣scription.
DIV2.Q: In Memory of Robert DixonN. B. This Gentleman is still living, and has paved the Altar with Black and White Marble. M. A. Tenth Son of Percival Dixon, of Fenwick, in NORTHUMBERLAND. He was buried here, A. D. 17 He was Minister of Aldermaston, Years, at the same Time Rector of Woolhampton.
DIV2.P: Over the Entry into the Vault belong∣ing to the Forster's, now Lord Stawell's Family, are these Inscriptions.

Q.P: Here lyeth Mary, the Daughter of Sir Mark Stewart, married to Sir Willi∣am Forster, An. Dom. 1594. who had by him one Son and one Daughter: She was buried, An. Dni. 1661.
Sir Humphrey Forster, her Son, mar∣ried to Ann, Daughter of Sir William Kingsmill, who had by her 16 Chil∣dren, was buried here, An. Dom. 1663. aged 68.
William Forster, Son of Sir Humphrey Forster, married to Elizabeth, Daugh∣ter of Sir John Tirrell, who had by her 5 Children, was buried here, An. Dom. 1660. aged 36.
Stewart Forster, Sort of Sir Humphrey Forster, left 2 Sons, was buried here, An. Dom. 1680. aged 45.
William Forster, Son of William For∣ster, was buried here, An. Dom. 1677. aged 25. John Forster, Son of Wil∣liam Forster, was buried here, An. Dom. 1683. aged 25.

Humphrey Forster, Son of Sir Hum∣phrey Forster, Bar. eldest Son to Wil∣liam Forster, who married Judeth, eldest Daughter to Sir Humphrey Winche, Bar. was buried here, 1682. aged.... William Forster, second Son of Sir Humphrey Forster, was bu∣ried here. An. Dom. 1683 aged 7.

DIV2.P: On a White Free-stone Grave-stone is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Mrs. Isabel Lloyd, was buried here. Mar. 12. A. D. 1707. aged 66.
DIV2.P: On the South Side of the Body of the Church. In an Ile now blocked up by Mr. Thomas Leadbeater's, an Attorney's Pew, are these Grave-stones, viz.
On a White Free-stone Grave-stone, in Capitals, is the following Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here jyeth the Body of Mr. John Forster, who departed this Life, December the 10th, 1674.
DIV2.P: On another White Free-stone Grave-stone, in Capitals, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Ann, Daughter of William Forster, Esquier, who died in Infancy, and was Sic. Orig. heare buried, January the 12. 1664.
DIV2.P: On a Black Marble Grave-stone is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyes the Body of Rebekah, the Daughter of Sir Humphrey and Judeth Forster, who dyed, aged 2 Years, A•. Dom. 1676.
DIV2.P: On a Black Marble Tomb, on the South Side of the South Ile, in Capitals, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lieth the Ladie Anne Forster, Wife to the late Sir Humphrey Forster, Kt. and Bar. and had Issue 16 Children. She died Octo. the 12th. A. D. 1673.
DIV2.P: On a Black Stone, fixed against the North Wall of the Chancel, is this In∣scription.

Q.P:
Near this Place lyeth the Body of HANNAH STANTON, Second Wife of JOHN STANTON, late of this Parish, Gent.
who died February the 23d. Anno Dom. 170. aged 68 Years.
Additions WINKFIELD, men∣tioned in page 34 of the third Volume.

DIV2.P: In Windsor Forest, on the Plain front∣ing CRANBURN LODGE, is a fair Brick Building, consisting of two Schools; and in the middle is a Chapel. It was built by Richard, late Earl of Ra∣nelagh, for the Education of twenty Boys and Twenty Girls; the Master was to be a Clergyman of the Church of England, and to read her Liturgy daily, for which his Allowance was designed to be 30l. per Annum, the School Mistress to receive 25 l. yearly. On the Front is the Coat of Arms, Coronet, Supporters, &c. belong∣ing to the Founder, and under it, DONUM DEI ET DEO.
On the Right Hand is painted the Fi∣gure of a Girl, and underneath, This School for Twenty Girls to be taught Gratis.
Under the Figure of a Boy.

Q.P: This School for Twenty Boys to be taught Gratis.
Additions to BESILLS-LEE, mentioned in page 155 of the first Volume.

DIV2.P: In the Chancel, on a Black Marble Grave-stone, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Here lyes interred the Body of Sir JOHN LENTHALL, Kt. of BASSESLEIGH, in the County of Barkes, the Son of WILLIAM LENTHALL, late of Bursord, Es{que} He departed this Life on the 8th Day of November, 1681. in the 57 Year of his AGE.
This Stone was layed by Dame Katherine Lenthall, his Widow, Daughter of Eusebius Andrew, Es{que} late of Edmonton, in the County of Middlesex.

DIV2.P: On a small Diamond Marble Escotcheon, within the North Wall, is this Inscription.

Q.P:
Near this Place lyes the Body of Mrs. WINEFRID THOMPSON,
Daughter to RICHD THOMPSON, Doct. of Divinity, & Dean of Bristoll, She departed this Life the 21 of March, 170/9.
Additions to St. GEORGE's CHAPEL, &c. within the Castle of WINDSOR.

DIV2.P: On a Black Marble Grave-stone, near the East End of the South Ile, is the fol∣lowing Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Mrs. Susanna Wickart, the Wife of Dr. Wickart, Dean of Winchester, and Canon of Windsor, Ob. Jan. the 8. 1717. She was the Daughter of Sir John Colladon, and by her Mother's Side Grand Neice to Sir Theodore Mayern.
DIV2.P:
Over the Gate leading into the Mansion See Vol. III. pag. 203. House of Samuel Pratt, D. D. Dean of Rochester, and Canon of this Church, si∣tuate
against one of the North Doors of this Chapel is the following lnscription.
DIV2.Q: Edes pro sacellanorum et Choristarum conviviis extructe, A° Xti 1519.
DIV2.P: In the middle almost of the lnner Square, at the East End of the Pedestal which supports the Equestrian Statue of King Charles II. mentioned hereafterSee page 115. of the Third Volume. following Inscription.
DIV2.Q: CAROLO SECUNDO REGUM OPTIMO, Domino suo Clementissimo; Tobias Rustat, hanc Effigiem humillimè dedit et dedicavit, Anno Dom. MDCLXXX.
DIV2.P: To the Pictures mentioned in page 116. of the third Volume, add those in the Gallery of King James 1. and Queen Anne, Admiral Van Tromp, his present Imperial Majesty, a Piece of Christ's Nativity, Battle of Spurrs, and King Henry VIII. by Hans Holbein; William Henry late Duke of Glou∣cester, George Prince of Denmark.

In another Room are the Pictures of the most celebrated Beauties of their Age, as the Countess of Sunderland, Wilmot Coun∣tess of Rochester, Countess of Falmouth, Lady Denham, Lady Middleton, Lady Biron, utchesses of Richmond, Northum∣berland and Cleaveland; Lady Gramnt, Lady Whitmore, Countess of Ossory, Mrs. Lawson, Mrs. Nott, Queen Catherine, Henrietta Maria Consort to K. Charles I. Anne Dutchess of York, first Wife of King James II. Mary Queen of England, Daugh∣ter to James II. Villars first Duke of Buckingham, Sir Kenelme Digby, and James Duke of Hamilton, beheaded in 1649. On the Cieling of one Room is the truest and best Picture of King Charles II. In two other Rooms are the Pictures of James Duke of York, drawn soon after his Escape from the Shipwreck of the Glouce∣ster Frigot; two Ladies of the Brunswick Family, and a full length of Mary Queen of Scots, Mother to King James I.
At the West End of the Royal Chapel is this Inscription, in Capitals, over the Gallery.
DIV2.Q:
Antonius Verrio Neopolitanus, Non ignobili stirpe ortus, ad Honorem Dei,
Augustissimi Regis Caroli secundi, et Sancti Georgii molem hanc foelicissimâ manu decoravit.
DIV2.P: About half a Mile from Windsor, to∣wards the Foreest is a Mineral Purging Spring, formerly much frequented, and known by the Name of ELIAS'S SPITTLE now St. PETER'S Well, where is also said to have stood a small Religious House, per∣haps an Hermitage, for the Entertainment of Travellers. It is now part of the Pos∣sessions of the Provost and Fellows of St▪ Mary's College at Eton in Buckingham∣shire.

DIV1.HEAD: ADDITIONS TO ASHBURY, OR AYSHBURY,

Mentioned in Page 196 of the Second Volume, taken from a fair MS. wrote on Velom in Folio, once belonging to Sir Henry Spelman, Kt. now in the Li∣brary of THOMAS RAWLINSON, of the Middle Temple, Es{que} and F. R. S. It contains also the Terriers of several Places in Wiltshire.
DIV1.P:
TErrarium omnium terrarum & tenementorum,Fol. 114. una cum finibus, redditibus & herietis ejusdem Manerii factum ibi∣dem Mense Maii, Anno Regni Regis Henrici octavi undecimo, & Anno Domini Ricardi Beerer, Abbatis vicesimo sexto, coram Fratre Thomae Sutton, Cellerario sorinseco
per Sacramentum Thome Percy, Prepositi ibidem, Nicholai Smyth, Johannus Besseley, Thome Horton, Roberti Harton, & Johanna Yong de Ayshbury, Ricardi Eyre, Roberti Bovetonn, Johannis Ffrenshe, Willielmi Bunce, Alexandri Wilmott de Edwyne∣stann, ceterorumque tenencium Cur ibidem ad idem terrarium vocatorum & distincte Exami∣natorum propter specialem perambulacionem & mensuracionem factam ibidem atque probatam.
Procinctus Manerii ibidem existens tempore seisine Metarum & bundarum sequencium.

[Fol. 115.] Bundarium: Dominus Abbas Gla∣ston, habet infra precinctum predictum plenam returnam brevium Domini Regis, habet etiam ibidem turnum Vice Comitis bis per Annum tenendum, viz, semel ad festum Sancti Martini, & iterum ad Hock, & liberum Hundredum de tribus septimanis in tres septimanas tenendum & continuandum & veniunt & venire debent ad predictum turnum bis per Annum, ad termi∣nos predictos omnes liberi residentes infra pre∣cinctum Hundredi predicti, & ulterius de tribus septimanis in tres septimanas de priso aut brevi Domini Regis vel in diem positum fuit in affors. Et in eodem turno & Hundredo potest Dominus placitare placita de vetito nam eo & omnia alia placita Vice Comitalia sequitur etiam ad eun∣dum Turnum bis per Annum decenne subscript. Presentantur in eodem omnia que pro pace & assisis observandis pertinent presentand. Et ve∣nient ipse decenne cum omnibus de etate xii Annorum & amplius, viz.
Decenna de Edwynstonn reddens ad utrumque turnum. Xs.
Decenna de Ayshbury, reddens simili modo ad utrumque turnum XS.
[Fol. 116] Divisio, Curia cum Bartonâ & Crotâ inferiori continent ii Acras & reservata pro Domino & Scolaribus Oxonie studentibus.
Curia exterior cum grangiâ & bovaria modo in manibus firmarii contin. dimid. acr. unde va∣lor non extenditur hic quia in procinctu firme ut postea.

Firma Terrarum dominicalium ibidem, Cle∣mens Northe, alias Hardyng, tenet firmam domi∣nicalem, viz. Grangiam, Bovariam, Bartonam, & Dominium in curia exteriori exist. ac lv Acras prati jacentes in North Mede, Up Mede, & West∣howke, ii Acras prati in perpetuum pertin. pre∣positi voc. Roveacr. & Roveholme, i Acram Pasture vocatam Lynche Acre quolibet alterno Anno sepa∣ral. & Pasturam ad grossandam animalia in Oldmershe, Ayshen Parke, & alibi prout Dominus habuit tempore quo firmam predictam in mani∣bus suis propriis tenuit, ac Pasturam montanam ad cccc bidentum nee non opaca loca & tonsu∣ram bidentum Domini Custumarii ibidem, &c.

Item, Tenet Crostam in Curia interiori contin. iii Acras reservand. Domino sufficientem Pa∣sturam pro omnibus exituris, & infra dominium istud de cetero capiend. per ii Dies immediate post seisinam earundem.

Item, Tenet ccccxv Acras terre Arabilis in ii campis unde in campo orientali in Darks∣fyld, vii Acras apud Whele Acre, quinque Acras in Burycrofte, xiiii Acras desuper Clyve Acre, vii Acras Bytweene Townes, xviii Acras in Over∣londs, xiiii Acras desuper Ecclesiam, v Acras
in the Wayte, xii Acras itineris in alio Furlongo, xiiii Acras in Ryggewey Furlong, vii Acras in parte Australi de Ryggewey, xiiii Acras in Myd∣delfurl, xiiii Acras in Grenebaroghfurl, xviii Acras in Rewthorneful, alias Haylesfurl, xviii Acras apud Honybytts, & Hardyngs Bore, x Acras in La Deane, juxta Hales, x Acras in Mawneden, xviii Acras & in campo occidentali apud Puddlehey, vii Acras in Myddelwey, & Malwey, ix Acras in Lortwell, & Hedlond ibidem, vii Acras in parte Boreali vie de Ykelyngwey, xx Acras desuper Ec∣clesiam, vii Acras in Lockelond, quinque Acras in Horselade, lx Acras in Haylefurl, xl Acras in Laweyfurl, v Acras in Threthornfurl. xviii Acras in Blakelonds, xii Acras in Kyngestonnisfyld, in iii furl, xx Acras.

Boscus—Est ibidem quidem Boscus vocatus Ayshem-Parke, coopertus quercubus, raxinis, & subboscis continens cclxxv Acras, unde Do∣minus vendere possit quolibet tertio Anno xxxvi acr. ultra allocationem Clerici & feod. Firmarii & tunc valet Acra cum vetustis arboribus vend. xviii s.

Continet ibidem cxii Acras pasture montane in orientali parte Bosci de Ayshbury, in quibus su∣stentari possint D. Multon, salvam communa∣riis communam sufficientem, viz. Domino Regi pro terra quondam Com. Hertford, ad cc Bidentes, xii Boves, & quatuor affer. & Johan∣nem Hardyngs ad sex Boves & ci Bidentes, ac Parsona Ecclesie de Ayshbury cum viii Bobus. Et ulterius firmarius Presidentis Collegii Beate Marie, Oxon. intrat & occupat Communiam predictam cum [Fol. 117.] cxx Bidentibus a longo tempore ubi nulla inde fit mentio in an∣tiquo
custumario nisi solummodo cum xvii Bo∣bus, & in eodem parco communicare possint omnes tenentes tam liberi quam villani de Ayshbury, & Edwynstonn, nisi in copis ibidem tempore defens. viz. quilibet eorum pro inte∣gra virgata terre cum ii Bobus.

DIV2.HEAD: Pastura Montana pertinens ad Tenentes de AYSHBURY.
DIV2.P: Continentur ibidem lxvi Acre pasture mon∣tane circa precinctum de Ayshen Parke, in qui∣bus omnes tenentes Dominii custumarii de Aysh∣bury, communicare possint cum Bidentibus suis prout ab antiquo.

DIV2.HEAD: Pastura Montana de EDWYNSTONN.
DIV2.P: Pastura ibidem montana vocatur Blakenhyll & Hardestone continet cccxx Acras, in quibus te∣nentes Dominii tam liberi, quam custumarii de Edwynstonn communicare possint cum bidenti∣bus suis.

DIV2.HEAD: Pastura de OLDEMERSHE.
DIV2.P: In Pastura de Oldemershe continentur xlviii Acre, in quibus communarii intrare possint cum eorum extent. Et tenentes Domini de Ayshbury & Edwynstonn, communicare possint ibidem cum Averiis suis, & eciam in Ʋp-Mede & North-Mede inter Festum sancti Martini, & Festum Purificationis Beate Marie Virginis, pro quibus solvuntur annuatim iiiis.

DIV2.HEAD: ESTMERSHE.
DIV2.P: In Estmershe continentur xl Acre, i perticata in quibus omnes tenentes Domini de Ayshbury communicare possint cum Averiis suis.

DIV2.HEAD: WYKELAYNE.
DIV2.P: Est ibidem quedam communa dimissa inter Firmariun de Stayneswyke, & tenentes Domini de Edwynstonn unde pars Domini continet xii Acras iii perticulas separales protenentibus de Edwynstonn predicta.

DIV2.HEAD: WESTMERSHE.
DIV2.P: Pastura ibidem continet cxl Acras, unde Te∣nentes Episcopi Sarum usurpent & clamant cir∣citer xxx Acras, in quibus omnes tenentes Do∣minii de Edwynstonn tarn liberi, quam villani communicare possint cum eorum Averiis omni tempore anni.

Memorandum, Pro certo quod Rector Ecclesie de Ayshbury habet unum boscum in occidentali parte de Ayshen-Parke vocatum Parsoneswode, con∣tinentem quindecim acras qui quidem Boscus, ab antiquo ei allocatus fuit & assignatus, & inHoc verbum in addidit quaedam recentior manus. recompensatus decimo tocius bosci & subbosci in Ayshen Parke.

DIV2.HEAD: Pratum Dominicale.
DIV2.P: In North-Mede, Up-Mede, & West-Hoke, cont. .... que arentantur per firmarium Dominii, ut patet antea.

DIV2.HEAD: [Fol. 118.] Liberi Tenentes ibidem.
DIV2.P:
WILLIELMUS WYKS, tenet quinque Hidas terre cum pertinentiis in Kyngston Wandestlyne, juxta Ayshbury, quondam Domini Radulphi Basse de Welyndon per servicium unius feodi militis,
homagium, & scutagium & sectam curie ad ii legal, ibidem, & de iii septimanis in tres septi∣manas, &c.

Prior Sancte Frideswide tenet ii partes unius feodi militis quondam Edmundi de Bownds, & nuperi Comitis Herford, per homagium & scuta∣gium servicium ac annuatim xv s. qui annuatim solvitur per Ballivum Domini de Lambone.

Presidens Collegii Sancte Magdalene Oxon, tenet vi virgatas terre cum pertinenciis in Stanes∣wyke & Ayshbury ex perquisitis Episcopi Wintoni∣ensis, de Domino Radulpho quondam filio & he∣rede Gilberti de la Stane, pro quarta parte unius feodi militis & secte curie ad ii. legal. & de tribus septimanis in tres septimanas, &c. ac per servi∣cium xxxvis. iiii d. ad quatuor anni terminos. Ultra xiii s. iiii d. debit annuatim ad officium Coquinarii Glastonie ad finem Pasche.

JOHANNES HARDYNG, tenet iii virgatas di∣mid. terre in Ashbury, quondam Radulphi Ma∣wyng, & nuper Ricardi Clerke, pro tertia parte unius feodi militis & secte curie ut supra ac per servicium annuatim debit, xv s. iiii d. ad quatuor anni terminos.
RADULPHUS FORSTAR, tenet i feodum mi∣litis in Edwynstonn & Ayshbury, quondam Rogeri Ffolyott, & nuper Humfredi Fforstar per homa∣gium & scutagium & sectam ut supra.

Parsona Ecclesie de Ashbury tenet unum Mes∣suagium & ii virgatas terre & xii Acras terre, iii Acras praci, & vi Acras bosci cum pertinenciis in Edwynstonn, que quondam fuerant Johannis Jownderell per servicium militis sect. ut supra ac per servicium annuatim viii s.. & ulterius Do∣minus habebit homagium & relevium ad obitum cujuslibet Rectoris ibidem.

JOHANNS FETYPLACE, tenet unam acram prati quondam Willielmi Beyntonn, vocati Wyge∣nolds per fidel. & sect. curie ad ii legal. ibidem ac per servicium annuatim i d. ad festum Nativitatis Beati Johannis Baptiste.

[Fol. 119.] Nota ubi ista rubea Littera (#) est superscripta in quolibet loco super diversas te∣nuras in hoc terrario quod terra sub eadem lit∣tera expresse posita, & nominata in omnibus & singulis locis ejusdem terrarii est terra domini∣calis, videlicet Overlonds ultra predictam fir∣mam terrarum Dominicalium.

DIV2.HEAD: Tenentes per Consuetudines Manerii ibidem.
DIV2.P: ISABELIA RENDALL, vidua tenet unicum Messuagium & dimidium terre in Ayshbury, unde curtillagium & gardinum continent i perticam.

Item, Tenet vii Acras dimid. pertic. prati unde buytSic. Orig. contin. vi Acras per servicium an∣nuatim. iiii s. d. ad quatuor terminos. In La More i Acra per servicium xii d. In North Mede dimidium pertice.

Item, xxii Acras in pertica & i StichSic. Orig. terre Arabilis in duobus campis, unde in campo orien∣tali In Oldlond i perticam & i Stich in La Heele unam perticam in Mershfurl i Acra. In Whitelond ii Acras.

Et in campo occidentali in Sonrehyll vii Acras desuper Sanrehyll unam Acram i perticam. In Hell furl. quinque Acras, in Stanbrugge furl. unam Acram dimid. in Langfurl. unam Acram in Chal∣well furl. unam Acram apud Graffiecomb, unam
Acram, dim. in Horslade unam Acram in duo∣bus particulis. Et cum obierit dabit Domino herietam.
WILLIELMUS BRUISE, tenet unum Messua∣gium & dimidium virgate terre in Edwynstonn, unde curtillagium cum gardino continens i per∣ticam dimid.

Item, Tenet xii Acras i pertice prati in com∣munibus pratis unde in La Hivea iii Acras. In Henne-Mede unam Acram, in Batynshmere, vi Acras dim. In North-Mede unam perticam. In La More dimidium Acre. Item, juxta Ba∣tynshmere. Item, Tenet toftum unicum virgate continens, perticam & dimidium Item, Tenet xxxvi Acras i perticam terre Arabilis in duobus campis unde in campo Orientali in Batynshmere vii Acras, & dimid. subtus Pyppelake furl. unam Acram, in duabus particulis apud Rose Ayshe di∣midium Acre, apud Chollewell dimidium Acre. Item, Ibidem i Acram dimid. in duobus parti∣culis. Bytwynewayes, ii Acr. dimid. in tribus particulis in Graffecomb dimidium Acre desuper Graffecomb, dimidium Acre in Horslade iii Acras in quatuor particulis. In Threthornefurl dimi∣dium Acre. In Grendewyll unam Acram in du∣abus particulis, apud Downeendfurl dimidium Acre in Froggepanne, dimidium Acre in Rygge∣weyfurl in campo de Ayshbury unam Acram.

Et in campo occidentali in Flexeland unam Acram, in Brondereful 1 Acram iii perticas cum tribus particulis, apud Howdesforde unam Acram dimid. in duabus particulis, apud Ruysheacre i perticam, in Edcomb i perticam, in Ruggeweyfurl unam Acram, in Seynt Katerynfurl dimid. Acr. In Redelond iii perticas, in Ledefurl dimidium
Acre, apud Stubbet horn dimidium Acre, in Flynt∣furl dimidium Acre, apud Ffawkeners-Buysh unam Acram, super Odebyll ii Acras in duabus particulis, super Wynterstonn is Hyll i Acram in duabus particulis, apud Popesbutts ii Acras apud Le Wayte ii perticas in duabus particulis, & ul∣terius lanabunt & tondebunt bidentes Domini cumHere is a Vacancy in the Original MS. .....................& cum obierit da∣bit ii herietas.

[Fol. 120.] ALEXANDER WYLMOTT, alias Tailoure, tenet unum Messuagium & iii virgatas terre in Edwynstonn unde curtillagium & gardinum continent ii perticas dimidium. Item, Tenet vii Acras in pertica, & ii swathis prati in commu∣nibus pratis unde in North-Mede, iii perticas & in Mora ibidem ii swathis. Item, Ibidem ii Acras, in Les Hivea quinque Acras.

Item, Tenet lx Acras, i perticam terre Ara∣bilis, unde in Twenty Londs ii Acras in duabus particulis, in Batynshmere dimidium Acre, in Brandyron dimidium Acre, in Lakefurl unam Acram dimid. in duabus particulis, in Les Gores unam Acram subtus villam, dimid. Acre in Longefurl, iii perticata in duabus particulis. In Littewellefurl dimidium Acre. In Plotteaker unam Acram, in Choldewellefurl dimidium Acre, in Tenaker iii Acras in tribus particulis, apus Bessylls unam Acram dimid. in duabus particulis, apud Le Quarre unam Acram, Greffecomb dimidium Acram, Upon the Wayte, iii Acras dimid. subtus Ryggeway dimid. Acre, desuper Ryggeway i Acram, in Est-Horslade dim. Acre in duabus parti∣culis,
in West-Horslade unam Acram dimid. apud High Dyche ii Acras dimid. in tribus particulis, in Threthornefurl unam Acram in duabus parti∣culis, desuper High Dyche dimidium Acre, in Odehill unam Acram in duabus particulis, in Froggepanne unam Acram dim▪ in tribus particu∣lis, in Oldebury unam Acram in duabus particulis, in Twynleyfurl unam Acram in duabus par∣ticulis, & in campo occidentali in Flexelond unam Acram, in Hodeford dimidium Acre, in Hole∣forgh dimidium acre, in Marwellfurl i Acram, in Shydellesdown ii Acras, apud Woodeway unam Acram, in Edcomb unam Acram, in duabus particulis, apud Heggeend dimidium Acre, apud Horslade unam Acram, desupper Ryggewey i Acram, in Redlond unam Acram in duabus particulis. Item, Ibidem ii Acras in Ledfurl, iii Acre dimid. in duabus particulis, in Stubthornefurl unam Acram dimid. apud High Dyche ii Acre in duabus parti∣culis, apud Odehyll unam Acram, in Lentefurl dimidium Acram, in ii Breeched # ix Acras in duabus particulis. Et ulterius lanabit & tonde∣bit bidentes Domini, & cum obierit dabit Do∣minis herietam.

RICARDUS EYRE, tenet unum Messuagium, & ii virgatas terre in Edwynstonn, unde curtilla∣gium cum gardino continet unam Acram, i perticam. Item, tenet toftum unius virgate terre ibidem quondam Carter continens unam perticam dimid.

Item, Tenet ix Acras & i Swath. prati in communibus pratis, unde in North-Mede iii per∣ticas in duabus particulis, in Wyleshmera unam Acram vocatam Chepacre, in Westhmera vi Acras, in Les Morys i acram, iii perticas in quatuor par∣ticulis.
Item, Tenet ibidem unam particulam prati continentem i swath. Item, Tenet lii acras dimid. terre arabilis in duobus campis ibidem, unam in campo Orientali in les Twenty Acres unam acram, in Lakefurl unam acram dimid. in duabus particulis, in Langfurl dimi∣dium acre, apud Rose Ayshe dimidium acre, sub∣tus Villam i perticam, in Lottewellsfurl dimidium acre, in Plotts dimidium acre, in Les Ten Acres, ii acras in tribus particulis, apud Graffecomb i acre dimid. in duabus particulis, in Les Combes unam acram in duabus particulis. Item, Desu∣per Les [Fol. 121] Graffecombes, unam acram vocatam Brodeacre super Les Knotts unam acram apud Heggeend, di∣midium acre in Le Weyte, di∣midium acre desuper Graffecomb, dimidium acre in Rggeweyfurl, iii acras in tribus particulis, in Horslade unam acram i perticam in duabus parti∣culis, in Hye-Dyche unam acram dimidium per∣tice in tribus particulis, in Bowlonds dimidium acre, de Hedlond in Threthornefurl unam acram in duabus particulis, apus Crowndewell i acram dimid. in duabus particulis, in Blakelonds ii acras in duabus particulis, in Froxepanne dimid. acre, apud Oldebury dimid▪ acre, supper Le Downe unam acram dimid. in tribus particulis supper Odehyll dim. acre. Et in campo occidentali apud Les Breche # vi acras, in La Bottoin iii perticas, supper Odebyll iii perticas in duabus particulis, in Flynt∣furl dimidium acre, apud Les Stubbs dimidium acre, in Ofurl i perticam, apud Le Lede iii acras, in duabus particulis, in Redelonds i acram, iii perticas in duabus particulis, apud Coltsbuysh di∣midium acre, apud Wynterstone unam acram, apud Pepesbutts ii acras, apud Ryggewellsbuysh
unam acram, subtus Ryggewey i acram, in dua∣bus particulis, apud La Wayte iii perticas in du∣abus particulis, in Edcomb ii acras in tribus par∣culis, in Sydeldowne unam acram, in Westetownefurl dimidium acre, apud Westebrygge i pertice dimid. in tribus particulis, subtus Parsonisfurl i acram, apud Holeforgh unam acram, dimid. in duabus particulis, apud Brandyron i perticam. Et ulterius lanabit & tondebit bidentes Domini, & cum obierit dabit Domino ii heriettas.
JOHANNES FRENSHE, tenet unum Messua∣gium & ii virgatas terre in Edwynstonn unde curtillagium, gardinum, & pomerium conti∣nens i acras dimidium.
Item, Tenet iii clausa prati & pasture apud Wykehyll continens xi acras & pasturam Yemale de Wykehyll predicta, per precium annum xxxiiis. iiiid.

Item, Tenet viii acras, iii perticas & i swath. parti in communibus pratis unde in La Hivea # vi acras, in Hon-Mede unam acram, in Les Morys unam acram, i perticam in tribus parti∣culis. Item, Ibidem I swath, in North-Mede di∣mid. acram.
