Pierce Gaveston, and Hugh de Spencer, after whose Death Queen Isabel possess'd it, and soon quitted to her Son, Edward III. who bestowed it on his Brother, John Earl of Cornwall, upon whose Death, in 1335, it was, by Act of Parliament, annexed to the Duke of Cornwall, and in that Quali∣ty was held by the Black Prince, and his Successors, Princes of Wales, and Dukes of Cornwall. Upon a Design laid of erecting Christ Church in Oxford by Cardinal Wolsey, the true and real Foun∣der, (however that Society may call themselves Royal) this Manor and Castle was made over by Hen. VIII. to that Great Man, upon whose Attaintment, that sacrilegious Prince re-annexed it to the Crown, which he afterwards severed, and annexed to the Manor of
Ewelme in Oxfordshire. The Castle in∣deed still continued, as the Cardinal de∣signed it, in the Possession of Christ Church, as it does to this Time.

This Castle, according to Leland, was surrounded with three broad, deep En∣trenchments, and in it were contain'd several Buildings; and five Streets, cal∣led Thamesstreet, Fishstreet, Breadstreet, Woodstreet, and Goldsmiths-Row, in its antient Magnificence. By him we are also informed, Wolsey suppressed a Priory of Black Monks, here standing within the West Gate, which belonged to the Abby of St. Albans. The Suppression of this, and other small Religious Houses, was a Presage of that more general Sacrilege that soon followed, and gave a covetous Prince too just a handle for the Seizure of the rest of the Ecclesiastical Revenues of this Nation, (though Deodands, and dedica∣ted to sacred Uses) when he saw a Church Man, encouraged by the Infallible Head of his Church, not scruple at such Alienati∣ons to gratify his Vanity. In this Town were of old four Churches, viz. St. Pe∣ter's, St. Mary's, St. Leonard's, and All Saints, (the Three first of which are now united) most of which were destroyed in the late Times of Confusion. It is at pre∣sent a large, handsome Town, in which
are two principal Streets, and a handsome Guild, or Town Hall, built about 42 Years since: It is a disrinct Jurisdiction from the County, and has Quarter Sessi∣ons in it; on Friday weekly it has a Mar∣ket; and yearly, on April 5. and June 24. Fairs, and sends two Burgesses to Par∣liament.

DIV2.HEAD: St. MARY's Church.
DIV2.P: On the South Side of the Chancel, is a Monument erected in the Wall, having this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of HENRY STAMPE, who dyed at the Age of 7 Yeares, the viith of October, An. MDCXIX. whose Parents were these, His Father, MICHAEL STAMPE, son to WILLIAM STAMPE, Esq; his Mother, ISABELL, the Daughter to Sir MICHAEL MOLYNS, Knight, of Clapcot.
DIV2.P: At the South Side of the Chancel, near the Entrance, is a fair Monument erected against the Wall, with this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of WALTER BIGG, Esq; Alderman of the City of London, and (to his great Honour be it spoken) a faithful Servant of the Lord, a worthy Patron of learned, godly, and faithful Ministers. A great Lover of his native Place, and Country; as some Testimony whereof, he bequeathed the Sum of 20 l. yearely to the Borough of Wallingford; that is to say, 10 l. towards a Free Schoole, and 10 l. towards the Reliefe of Ten of the Poor of the said Borough. Having run his Race, and served his Generation with much Fidelity, constancy, and Sincerity, full of a lively Faith and Hope, He departed from this Lyfe to a better, from the Society of the Creatures to the Creator, of Christians to Christ, of Men to Angels, of Sinners to Saints, and the Spirits of just Men made perfect, August V. An. Dom. MDCLIX. Aetatis suoe 53.
DIV2.P: In a Church Yard, belonging to the Church of All Saints, (destroyed in the Civil Wars,) is preserved an old Stone, whereon an Inhabitant of this Town hath put this inscription.
DIV2.Q: This is the Monument of Thomas Bennet, of Chapcot, Esq; who had Yssue Thomas Bennet, Knight, Citizen, and Alderman of London, his third Sonne, who gave Twenty Pounds yearely for ever, to Fiftene poor People of the Town of Wallingford.
On the Banks of the River Thames lyes BRIGHTWELL, or Brettwell.
DIV2.P: Near to, or in which, stood formerly a Castle, which was demolished by King Henry II. towards the Conclusion of the Troubles between him and Stephen. The Rectory is of a considerable Value, and is in the Gift of the Bishop of Winchester for the Time being. Anthony Alsop, B. D. pre∣sent Incumbent.
Engraven on a Stone lying in the mid∣dle of the Chancel.
DIV2.Q:
Here resteth the Body of CHRISTIAN, Daughter of ANTHONY GODWYN of Wokey, in the County of Somerset, Gent. first the Wife of EDWARD HUISH, of Wells, in the County of Somerset, Gent.
afterwards the Wife of ADRIAN BOWER, of the same, Gent. She died Sept. the xvth. MDCXL.
DIV2.P: On another Marble Grave-stone ad∣joyning, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Depositum THOMAE GOODWYN, S. T. P. Viri Integerrimi Pietate, Literatura, morum suavitate, spectabilis Rectoris, hujus Ecclesioe vigilantissimi; cujus merita melius poster is transmittent scripta, quam Marmor.
Hunc Lapidem, Uxor ejus Phelipps Goodwyn, amor is ergo moerens posuit, obiit Martii xx. Anno Dom. MDCXLII

DIV2.P: In the Body of the Church, near the Chancel, are the Figures of a Man in a Gown, and a Woman in her usual Ha∣bit, engraven in Brass Plates, and fixed to a Marble Grave-stone, and under their Feet this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Pray for the Soules of Robert Court, sometyme Auditor to Prince Artour, and Jane his Wyfe: The whiche Robert decesyd the XXVIII Day of June, in the Yere of our Lord, ML CIX. on whose Soules Jhusu have Mercy. Amen.
DIV2.P: On another Grave-stone lying at the Head of the former, whereon are the like Figures engraved, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Pray for the Sowles of Richard Bampden, and Jane his Wyfe; the whych Jane decessyd the XXIII Day of Februarius, the Yere of our Lord, MCCCCCXII. On whose Sowles Jhesu have Mercy. Amen.
DIV2.P: In the South Isle lies a Grave stone, and thereon a Plate of Brass, whereon is engra∣ved Priest in his Habit, and this Epitaph.
DIV2.Q: HicSic. Orig. jacet corpora Magistri Johan∣nis Scolffyld, qui obiit XV Die mensis, Maii, An Dom. Millimo, VcVII. Cujus anime propici∣etur Deus. Amen.

DIV2.HEAD: North MORTON,
DIV2.P: Is in the Hundred of the same Name, in the Deanery of Abington, a Vicaridge.
In the middle of the Cahpel, situate on the South Side of the Chancel, is a fair Marble Stone, some what raised from the Ground, and thereon fastened a Brass Plate, bearing this Inscription.

Q.P: Here lyeth buried the Body of JAMES LEAVER, who departed this mortall Lyfe the viii Day of Aprill, Anne Domini, MDCXXIX. being of the Age of 46 Tears; who had Yssue by KATHARINE his Wife, 9 Children, viz. 5 Sons and 4 Daughters, being all Living at the Tyme of his Death; in Memory of whose loving Husband, the said Katharine, his dear Wife, at her owne Charge, caused this Memo∣rial to be made.
The Righteous shall be had in everlast∣ing Remembrance, and the Memory of the Just is blessed.

DIV2.P: On a Brass Plate fixed on a Grave-stone, laid in the Body of the Church, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Pray for the Sowllys of Thomas Randolff, and Cecily his Wife, and all their Yssue, Anno Domini, MCCCCLXXIV. Obierunt Do∣minus Thomas A Cecilia, Thomas Mens. Marc. Cecilia Septemb.
DIV2.P: On a Brass Plate on a Grave-stone lying in the South Isle, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of THOMAS HILL, who was buried the xxth of January, MDCXII.

Q.L: As I was, so are you,
As I am, so shall you be.

DIV2.HEAD: South MORTON,
DIV2.P: In the South Isle of the Church, en∣graved on a Blue Marble, under the East Window, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyes the Body of MARGARET, second Daughter of WILLIAM TIPPINGE, of Dracott, in the County of Oxon, Esq; Wife of RICHARD POYNT, of South Morton, in the County of Berks, Gent. who departed this Life the xth Day of May, An. Dom. MDCLVI.
DIV2.P: Lower in the said Isle is another Grave∣stone, where on a Brass Plate is this In∣scription.
DIV2.Q: Sub jacet ecce pede Ricardus Morus, in eve Kene, qui discreius suit ampla pace quietus. E quater & Mille, quates & his sex obit ille, Luceque serta ter Junii, sit hujus sibi mater, Fecit plura loco, bona sunt sussaragia pro quo. Post Christiana sua vita subit ad relevamen, Ques Mas alma tua salvet precor, O Deus!

DIV2.HEAD: West HAGBORNE
DIV2.P: Is a Vicaridge in the Hundred of Mor∣ton, and Deanery of Abington. Patron and Incumbent, Mr. White.
On a Grave-stone lying in the North Side of the Chancel, in a Plate of Brass, is insculped the Picture of a Woman, be∣neath whose Feet is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Claricia Wyndefore, quon∣dam Domina de Westhakborn, & Vxor Johannis Yooke, que fieri fe∣cit istam Capellam; que obiit XXII die Marcii, Anno Domini MCCCCIII. Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: In the middle of the Chancel lyes a Marble Grave-stone, whereon is the Fi∣gure of a Man in a Gown, and his Wife dress'd in the Fashion of her Times, and under them this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Of your Charite pray for the Soulles of JOHN ANGYER, and Alys his Wife, which depar∣ted this present Life, to the Mer∣cy of Almighty God, the XXXIst
Yeare of the Reigne of our Sove∣raigne Lord. King Henry the VIIIth. On whose Soulle Jhesu have Mercy.
DIV2.P: In the South Wall of the Chancel is a small Monument set, and therein a Brass Plate, engraved with a Man in Armour, kneeling before a Desk. Opposite to him is his Wife also kneeling; and behind him are represented four Sons, and behind her 4 Daughters; under which is this Epitaph.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth buried the Body of CHRIS∣TIAN KEATE, the Wife and Widdow of HUGH KEATE, of Hodcott, in the County of Berks, Gent. who had Yssue betweene them 4 Sons and 4 Daugh∣ters, viz. HUGH, JOHN, FRANCIS, and WILLIAM; MARY, MARGARETT, CHRISTIAN and ELENOR. He de∣parted this Lyfe the xxiiid Day of March, Anno Domini, MDCXXIII. and was buried in the Parish Chancel of West Ilderly, in the County afore∣said. She departed this Life the xivth Day of August, Anno Domini, MDXXVII.
DIV2.P: Before his Monument (in the middle of the Chancel, lyes a little Grave-stone, with this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyes the Body of CHRISTIAN KEATE, for whose Memory, in the Wall, is erected a large Monument. She was Daughter of JOHN UPPERTON, of Brightwell, in the County of Berks, Gent. and of MARGARET his Wife. She died MDCXXVII. August the xivth.

DIV2.HEAD: HARWELL,
DIV2.P: A Vicaridge in the Hundred of Mor∣ton, and Deanery of Abington; Patron Sir Jemmatt Raymond, and Incumbent Mr. Jefferies.
In the middle Isle of the Church is en∣graven upon a Brass Plate, fixed in a Grave-stone, the Figure of a Man in a Cloak, and his Wife in her usual Hibit, under whom is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of JOHN JENNENS, who deceased the XXVIIth Day of November, An Dom. MDXCIX. who had Yssue by Margaret his Wife 6 Sons and 5 Daughters

Q.L: Good Wife and Children agree,
Serve the Lord, and come to me.

DIV2.P: Under the Man are represented the Fi∣gures of his Six Sons, and under the Wo∣man Five Daughters.

DIV2.HEAD: OKE Hundred. Little WITTENHAM,
DIV2.P: Is in Oke Hundred, in the Deanery of Abington; a Manor belonging to the an∣tient Family of Dunch, who are patrons of the Vicaridge, of which Mr. Cook is Incumbent.
The following Monuments are erected in a Chapel situate on the South Side of the Chancel, under which is a Vault, made for the Interment of the Family of the Dunches.
Against the East Wall is erected a Mo∣nument, having this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Hic in Domino obdormit GUALTERUS DUNCH, Armiger, filius GULIELMI DUNCH, Armigeri, ex MARIA Uxore, qui in Jure Anglioe Municipali diu multumque versatus, & in numerum
seniorum Hospitii de Graies Inn cooptatus, libentissime pauperum causas promovit, & carissimus ominibus vixit, in Uxorum accepit DEBORAM paterno genere ex PILKINGTONIS, materno ex KINGSMELLIS oriundam, quoe illi peperit filium, & quatuor filias. Obiit An. Aet. suoe 42. An. Christi, MDXCIV. [Die 4. Junii. MARIA mater moestissima filio carissimo, Hoc posuit.

Q.L: Te put at oeternum tumulo posuisse sub isto
Mors inimica bonis, fallitur illa tamen.
Te tua firma fides Christo, pietasque probata
Inseruit coelis, hinc tibi vita Deo.
Te Virtus, Candor, probitas, Prudentia Juris
Concelebrant terris, vivis & inde viris.

DIV2.P: Against the South Wall is a fair Monu∣ment erected, on which is fastened a Plate of Brass, and thereon engraved the Fi∣gures of a Man and his Wife kneeling be∣fore Desk; behind the Man are his two Sons also kneeling, and over their Heads this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Here lyeth William Dunch, Esq: Auditor of the Minte to our late Soveraigne Lord King Henry the Eight and King Edward the Sixt, and Esquire sworn extraordinary
for the Body of our Soveraigne Lady Elizabeth. He married Ma∣ry Barnes; they ahd Yssue between them, two Sonnes, Edmund the eldest, and Walter the younger; which William deceased the XI Day of May, in the Yeare of our Lord God, MDXCVII.
DIV2.P: On the west side of the said Chapel is a large Monument erected against the Wall, where within a fair Arch, lyes the pourtraiture of a Knight on his right Side, in compleat Armour, supporting his Head with his right Hand. Beneath him lyes also his Lady, adorned in the Habit and Fashion of the Times, wherein she lived. Lower, towards the Foot of the Monument, are the Pourtraitures of 4 Sons and 3 Daughters kneeling; as also of two Infants drest up in swaddling Clothes and laid by them. Within the Arch is the following Inscription.
DIV2.Q: GULIELMO DUNCIO, Equiti aurato, viro famoe integerrimoe, fidei spectatissimoe, spei expectatissimoe, cum magno suorum damno, & dolore defuncto, Januarii xxii. MDCXI, Aetatis vero suoe 33. Uxor MARIA, moestissima Pie posuit.

Q.L: Hic qui dormit Eques; rem spe superavit, & Annos
Consilio, juvenis tempore, mente senex.
Conjuge qui foelix, numerosâ prole Beatus,
Qui lumen patrioe, qui columenque Domus.
Hunc pietas, virtus, gravitas celebraevit honore,
Quas animi doles fama fuisse refert
Berchia te luget, te gens Cromwellia luget,
Illam consilio, hanc juvit amore frui.
Cum nondum patrioe, naturoe, nec sat amicis
Vixerat, at Domino vixerat ille satis.

DIV2.P: Against the North Wall is a fair Mo∣nument erected, bearing this following Inscription.
DIV2.Q: HOSANNA, Sic superest in exemplar ANNA DUNCH, Cujus dictio benedictio, vita beneficentia fuit, In Eleemosynis assidua, pernox in Devotione, filia hoeresque NIC. FETIPLACK, ex Avo GUIL. Abavo Ric. per FRIDES∣WED hredem JOHANNIS KENTWOOD Militis, Atavo JACOBO, ab Atavo THO. FETIPLACE, per Uxorem BEATRICEM Filiam REGIS PORTUGALIAE oriund. EDM. DUNCH, Armig. clariss. Vidua.

Q.L: Ille vel illamagis redamat, dat numen adorat,
Aedihus in sacris, ille vel illa magis.
Prole beat, ditatque, & nomen adornat uterque
Pauperis attenta percipit aure preces.
Aequanec Edmundi transibit fama, nec Annae,
Sic in honore pares, sicut amore pares.

DIV2.Q: Obiit, Decimo nono Die Januarii, Anno Domini, MDCXXVII. Aetatis vero suoe 71.
DIV2.P: On a Grave-stone on the North Side of the Chancel, is this Epitaph.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet EDMUNDUS DUNCHE, filius EDMUNDI DUNCH, Ar. & ANNE ejus Uxoris, qui decimum tertium natus annum, vita defunctus est Aprilis, An. Domini, MDXCV.
DIV2.P: At the Head of the same Stone are these Verses.

Q.L: Vita Deus, Deus est, vitam qui terminat, omnes
Arhitrio summi stantque cadunt que Dei.
Certa Des nostroe mensurat at tempor a vitoe,
Hic citius moritur, vivit & ille diu.
Vita sit illa satis tibi, quam Deus esse volebat,
Quoe sequitur mortem, vita perennis erit.

DIV2.P: Upon another Grave-stone, under a Person engraved in a Brass Plate, holding up his Hands in a praying Posture, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet David Kid welly Hostiari∣us aule Regis Henrici vi qui obiit VI die Januarii, Anno Domini, MCCCCLIV. Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen
DIV2.P: Upon another Grave-stone is this fol∣lowing Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Under this Stone lyeth Margaret Barnes, who died the iiid Day of December, Anno Domini, MDLXVIII.
DIV2.P: Upon another Stone near the former, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Here lyeth buried John Barnes, Esq; sometime Gentleman Porter of the Cower, and Castle of Guys∣nes in France, when it was Eng∣lish, and one of the Privy conncell of that Estate; who to this Vil∣lage, and to the Cownes of Abing∣ton and Wallingford, in this Coun∣ty, did of Christian Charitie,
leave divers Stocks of Money for the Releife of the Poor of those Places. He had only one Sister. named MARY BARNES, married unto William Dunche, Esq; by whome we had Yssue only two Sons; Edmund Dunche the eldest, Walter Dunche the youngest. He dyed at London the xxivth of May, Anno Domini, MDLXXXVIII.
DIV2.P: Upon another Grave-stone laid near the Entrance into the Chancel, is the follow∣ing Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth buried ELIZABETH, Second Daughter of EDMUND DUNCHE, of Wittenham, Esq; Relict of JOHN ISHAM, of Pickly, in the County of Northampton, Esquire; who departed this Lyfe, August vi. MDCLVII.

Q.L: What Wisdome, Prudence, Life speakes, Mortalls have,
Lyes here intombed, and layd up in this Grave,
Death having had his due, removed her hence,
And here immur'd her by god's Providence.

DIV2.P: Upon a Stone adjoining to the former follows this Inscription.

Q.P: In honour of good Mrs. ANNE DUNCHE the Charitable, Wife to good Mr. EDMUND DUNCHE the Hospitable.

DIV2.P: Upon a Grave-stone in the middle of the Chancel, bearing a Priest in his Habit, en∣graven on a Plate, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Dominus Johannes Thur∣mund, quondant Rector istius Ec∣clesie, qui obiit XII Die Mensis Maii, Anno Domini, MCCCCXXXIII. Cujus anime propictetur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: On the South Side of the Chancel, on a Brass Plate, fixed to a Grave-stone, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
In Memory of her loving Husband, WIL∣LIAM WINCHECOMBE, Son and Heire to FRANCIS WINCHECOMBE, Esq; of Bucklebury, who dyed in the 38 Yeare of his Age, on the xxixth of July,
MDCXIV. Mary, the eldest Daugh∣ter of EDMUND DUNCH, bestowed this Monument.

Q.L: I loved Thee living, and lament Thee dead,
But in what Measure cannot be exprest;
Yet Love and Sorrow, both will needs be reade,
Even in this Marble (Deare) they do their best.
And' tis for others too I putt this Stone;
To me thy Tombe shall be my Heart alone.
Twice Eighteene Yeares he viewed Heavens Day,
Sixteene he spent in happy Wedlocks Bands,
The Graces, Mses, and the Fates did lay,
Untimely on his Webb their fatal Hands:
Of Heire his House, of all their Hopes his Friends,
Of Progenie his Wife bereft, he ends.

DIV2.P: Upon another Grave-stone adjoyning, is this Epitaph.
DIV2.Q:
MARY, eldest Daughter of EDMUND, DUNCH, of Wittenham, esq; married to WILLIAM WINCHECOMBE, of Bucklebury, in Berks, Esq; After to sir EDWARD CLARKE, of Ardington, in the same County, Knight. Having lived 16 Yeares
in Widdowhood piously towarde God, and conscientiously to Man, departed this Life October the xviii. MDCXLVI.
DIV2.P: Upon a Plate on a Grave-stone laid un∣der the Communion Table, is the Figure of a Child, and under it this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Pere lyeth John Dunch, the Son of Edmund Dunch, Esq; and Anne his Wife; this Child being of the Age of one Yeare, deceased the XIIth of May, MDLXXXIX.

Q.L: As God hath well determined,
Even soe our Life is limited;
He measureth the Days of Man,
Of some by Ell, of some by Span;
As pleaseth God, let this suffice,
And hope from Death to Lyfe to rise.

DIV2.P: On the North Side of the Church, un∣der the Figure of a Man, kneeling at a Faldstool, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Blessed are the Dead which here∣after dye in the Lord, even so saith the Spirit, for they rest from their Labours, and their Works fol∣low
them. Revelations the 14th Chap. the 13th Verse. JOHN BARNES.

DIV2.HEAD: Epitaphium Mariae Barnes.
DIV2.L: The Touchstone of our Lyfe, is Death, as I discerne.
For by the present passing hence, the former Lyfe we learne;
And so through Worlds Report, they live that lye full low,
Grave can claim no more of Right, then Flesh and Blood ye know;
The People steies the same behinde, for Causes good,
By which Devise the honest Name is knowne and understood,
Then to this Widow here, a Farington by Birth,
Must have they praise that she hath wonne, whilst here she was on Earth;
Her sober Manners, mild, and upright Dealing just,
In mind of Man shall shined be, though Barnes be torned to Dust.
By Marriage Barnes she hight, by Lyfe a Matron called,
And so among the gravest Sort, in Seat she shall be stalled;
Well liked of Poor and Rich, her Works so vertuous were,
That mich good Will, and Neighbour's Love, therefore hence did she beare.
Of right these Verses sure she claimes, I say no more,
And you that read them, after must, for she is gone before.
The Heavens do bold her Ghost, the Earth Account must make,
Of every Thing it hath received, when God shall Reckoning take;
Then lo the Wormes shall yield her Body whole againe,
And she with us, and we with her, in endles Joy remaine.
DIV2.P: On a Grave-stone lying in the Body of the Church, is a Brass Plate, and thereon drawn the Figure of a Woman, with a Vail over her Head, and under her this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Elena; nuper Vxor Gal∣fridi Kidwelly, que obiit penulti∣mo Die Mensis Maii, Anno Dont. MCCCCLXXII. Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: On a Monument on the North Side of the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Galfridus Kidwelly, Ar∣miger, qui obiit tertio decimo Die Martii, Anno Domini, MCCCCLXXXIII. & Anno Reg∣ni Regis Ricardi tertii, post Con∣questun Anglie, primo. Cujus a∣nime propicietur Deus. Amen.

DIV2.HEAD: Long WITTENHAM,
DIV2.P: Is a Rectory in the Deanery of Abing∣ton, and in the Patronage of Exeter Col∣lege, though St. John's College, in Oxford, are Lords of this Manor, where annual∣ly, in October, they hold Courts Leet, and Baron. Mr. Fair is Incumbent.
Under the King's Arms, placed over the Rood-Loft, is this Distich.
DIV2.Q: Qui Leo de Juda est, & flos de Jesse, Leones Protegat, & Flores Carole magne tuos.
DIV2.P: Under the Picture of Death are these Verses.

Q.L: Man is a Glass, Life is as Water, weakely walled about,
Sin brought in Death, Death breakes the Glass, so runs this Water out.

DIV2.P: In the East Window of the North Isle, the right Hand Pane of Glass, is a Man in Armour kneeling.
In the left Hand Pane is a Woman in a Green Gown, and Yellow Mantle, holding an Escutcheon, but the Arms broken out.

Under the South Window of the South Isle, called St. Thomas's Isle, is a Monu∣ment bearing the Portraiture of a Person cut cross legged in Stone, about Three Quar∣ters of a Yard long, and fixed in the Wall.

DIV2.HEAD: SUTTON COURTNEY,
DIV2.P: A Vicaridge, in the Deanery of Abing∣ton, and Manor, belonging to the Church of Windsor, who are Patrons also, at whose Presentation Mr. Dalby is Incumbent.
Painted on the North Wall of the Chan∣cel is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Sir Richard Hyde, Knight, late of Blagrave, in the County of Berks, antiently descend∣ed from the Worthy Family of the Hydes of Denchworth; which Manor still continuing in the same Lyne and Name, even unto this Day, was bestowed upon the first Advancer thereof, for his Vertue and Valour, by Canutus, the first Danish King, who by Con∣quest obteyned this Kingdom in the Yeare of our Lord,....... This worthy Knight, a Branch of that Stock, deceased the xxivth Day of Aprill, in the Yeare of our Lord God, MDCXV. and in the Yeare of his Age 69.
DIV2.P: On a fair Black Marble, laid upon a Monument raised against the said Wall, is this inscription.

Q.P: Neare this Place lyeth the Body of GEORGE HYDE, Es{que} he dyed September the first, Anno Domini, MDCLXI.
This Tombe was erected by ELIZABETH, his sorrowful Widdow.

DIV2.P: Engraven upon a Plate of Brass, nailed on a Grave-stone lying in the Body of the Church, is this Inscription.

Q.P: THOMAS TRULOKE the Elder, buried the xxivth of Aprill, Anno, MDXCV.
THOMAS TRULOKE, his Son, buried the....... THOMAS TRULOKE, the Son of THOMAS TRULOKE the Younger, buried the xixth of November, Anno, MDXV.

DIV2.P: On another Grave-stone is this Inscrip∣tion.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of ELIZABETH, the Wife of.......TREVEROK, of Apleford, she dyed the xth Day of February, MDXCV.
DIV2.P: On a Grave-stone laid in the Church-Yard, under the South Window of the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Mrs. Dorothy Hyde, Virgin, Daughter of Sir Richard Hyde, Knight. She was buried the ivth of May, Anno Domini, MDCLVIII.
DIV2.P: Between Two Bones laid cross Ways, and a Death's Head, are these Words.
DIV2.Q: Imago Mortis.

DIV2.HEAD: STEVENTON,
DIV2.P: Is in the Deanery of Abington, a Manor belonging to the Church of Westminster, who presented Mr. Pyle, the present Vicar.
In the South Side of the Chancel is a raised Monument, whereon, in a Plate of Brass, are cut the Figures of a Man in Armour, and his Wife lying by him, drest in her usual Habit.
Under the Man are likewise engraved the Figures of 4 Sons, and under the Wo∣man 4 Daughters, with this Inscription under both.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth buried the Bodies of Edmund Wiseman, in the County of Berks, Es{que} a younger Son to Thomas Wiseman, of Thornehame, in the County of Suffolk, Es{que} who was Son and Heire to Sir John Wiseman, Kt. and Anne his Wife, one of the Daughters, and Heires of William Hawkins, late of London, Es{que} which said Edmond, and Anne, had Yssue 4 Sonns and 4 Daughters. She deceased the xxviith Day of Ja∣nuary, in the xxviith Yeare of the Reigne of our Soveraigne Lady, Queene Elizabeth, MDLXXXIV. The which said Edmond, dyed the....... Day of.....

Q.L: Quae charo fuerat perchara marita marito,
Wisemanni conjux hoc jacet Anna loco,
Quae Wisemanna fuit frugi, pia, casta, be∣nigna,
Digna viro conjux, dignior illa Deo.
Spiritus aethereas per Christum scandit in Au∣ras,
Jungitur atque Deo, quae fuit ante Dei.

DIV2.P: On the same Stone is added since.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of William Wiseman, Esq; who departed this Life November the viith, AnnoSic. Orig. Domnie, MDCCXIII. Aged 61 Years.
DIV2.P: On a Plate of Brass fixed to a Grave-stone in the middle of the Chancel, is engraved the Figure of a Man lying be∣tween his two Wives, and this Inscrip∣tion.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Ricardus, Do qui obiit v Die Mens. Febr. Anno Domini, MCCCCLXXVI. & Agneta, & Jo∣hanna, Vxores. Quorum anima∣bus propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: In a Chapel on the South Side of the Church, lyes a black Marble, and on it, cut upon white Marble, is the following Epitaph.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of DULCIBELLA, Wife of EDMUND WISEMAN, Es{que} Second Daughter of SAMUEL DUNCH, of Pusey, Es{que} She had Issue four sons, and three Daughters; who deceased the xth of November, MDCLVI. aged 37.
DIV2.P: On the Black Marble is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: H. S. J. Pii cineres Edmundi Wiseman, Armig. Qui haud sero satis cuiquam non nisi sibimet violenti vomitus laboribus, debilisque corporis purgationibus, die Omnium Sanctorum ut vere sanctus occubuit, Aerae. Christi, MDCLXXXIX. Aetatis suae 68. His second Wife was Susanna, the Daughter of John Clerk, of Ardington, whom he left surviving, and by whom he had three Sons, and four Daughters.
DIV2.P: Within the Rails, near the Altar, on a Rude Ragg Stone, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body ofSic. Orig. Henery Smalbon, andSic. Orig. Phlis his Wife, who was baptized the xviiith Day of April, MDCLIV. and departed this Life the xxixth of September, Anno Domini, MDCCV.
DIV2.P: The Dean and Chapter of Westminster gave a plain Wainscot Altar Piece about a Year or two since.

DIV2.HEAD: West HANNY,
DIV2.P: On a Plate of Brass fixed upon a Blue Marble Grave-stone; in the middle of the Chancel, is drawn the Figure of a Priest habited in a Posture of Devotion, and upon the Verge of the said Stone cut like∣wise in Brass, is this Epitaph.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Dominus Johannes Seys, quondam Rector Ecclesie de... ...... obiit II die...... Dom. Millimo CCC....... Cujus ani∣me.
DIV2.P: At the East End of the Chancel, under the South Wall, lies a Grave-stone, upon which, in a Brass Plate, is the Pourtrai∣ture of a Knight compleatly armed, and underneath him this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Under this Stone lyeth the Corpes of Sir CHRISTOPHER LYTCOTT, Kt. Twyce High Sheriff of the County of Berks, (Husband of two Wives, both in the said County; the former, JANE ESSEX, Widow of THOMAS ESSEX, of Becket-house, Es{que} the later KATHERINE YOUNGE, Wid∣dow of WILLIAM YOUNG, of Bastledon, Es{que}) Knighted in the Campe before Roan the xvith of November, MDXCI. by the Hands of the French King, Henry the Fourth of that Name, and King of Navarre, who after his Tra∣vailes in Germany, Italy, and France, and the Execution of Justice of the Glory of God, and the good of his Coun∣trye, ended this Pil∣grimage at Bastle∣don, the xxvth of April, MDXCIX.
DIV2.P: At the Head of the aforesaid Grave-stone lies another, whereon is engraven in Brass, a Figure of a Man in Armour, his Head Piece lying in the Place of a Pillow for his Head, and about the Verge of the Stone is written.
DIV2.Q: I am sure that my Redeemer li∣veth, and that I shall rise out of the Earth in the last Day, and I shall be covered again with my Skin, and see God in my Flesh, whome I my selfe shall behold, not with other, but with these same Eyes. This my Hope is put up in my Bosome, Job. 19.

Q.L: Syth stable Ioyes of Lysse, thou knowst ryght few or none,
Thy flytting Daies the, not long to may endurez
This Earth to be but a Pylgrimage, Heaven our only home.
Let passe all Thoughte, that to Danytye thee shall allure,
And on me, Humfrey Cheynie, staye and Muse a while,
To John Cheynie of West Woodday, sometyme second Son,
Who dying without Yssue, Anno, MCCCCLVII. the XV of Aprill,
May warne thee of thy Lot haplye not farre to come.
And therefore lyke as for they thou woudest other to pray
God to be mercifull, aud not ryghtfull in his Dome:
Soe I beseke the have in Mynd alway,
To ved for me, as often as thou hether come.

DIV2.P: On a Marble next adjoyning, are the Figures of a Man in a Gown, lying be∣twixt his two Wives, drest in the Fashion of their Times, graved in Brass; with the Figures of ten Sons, and this Inscrip∣tion under all their Feet.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth buried the Body of JOHN AYSHCOMBE, of Lyford, Gent. who had 2 Wives; by the first he had no Yssue. The second Wife was MARGERY WELSBORNE, one of the Daughters of OLIVER WELSBORNE, of this Parish, Es{que} by whome he had 10 Sons; and 4 Daugh∣ters; which Margery was here buried, the xxvith Day of June, Anno Domini, MDXCI. and the said John Ayshcombe dyed the viith Day of September, Anno, MDXCII.
DIV2.P: Circumscribed on the four Sides of the said Grave-stone.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth buried the Body of JOHN AYSHCOMBE, of Lyford, Gent. who had two Wives; by the first he had no Yssue. The second was MARGERY WELSBORNE, the Daughter of OLIVER WELSBORNE, by whome he had 10 Sons and 4 Daughters. She dyed the xxvith of June, MDXCI. and he the viith of Sept. MDXCVII.
DIV2.P: Engraven of a Brass Plate fixed in a Marble, laid under the High Altar, the Figures of a Man and Woman, at whose Feet is engraved the following Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth buried the Bodies of OLIVER AYSHCOMBE, of Lyford, Gent. and MARTHA his Wife, that was one of the Daughters of THOMAS YEATE, of Lyford, Es{que} who had betweene them four Sons and two Daughters. She dyed the Ninth of November, Anno Domini, MDCXI. and he the Thirteenth Day of December, Anno Dom. MDCXI. and gave by his Will a very liberal and bountiful Gift to the Poore of this Parish.
DIV2.P: On the Verge of a Grave-stone under∣neath, is the same Inscription as the former.
On a Marble Grave-stone on the North Side of the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of JOHN AYSHECOMBE, of Lyford, in the County of Berks, Esquire, Justice of the Peace, and sometyme High Sheriff for the said County. He dyed, and was buried, the xxvth Day of December, An. Dom. MDCLV. Aetatis suae 97.
DIV2.P: On a Marble Grave-stone adjoyning to the former, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of JOHN AYSHECOMBE, of Lyford, in the County of Berks, Es{que} who departed this Lyfe the xviith Day of March, MDCLXII. in the Yeare of his Age 64. leaving behind him 2 Sons and 2 Daughters, viz. JOHN, OLIVER; MARGARET, ELIZABETH.
DIV2.P: Cut on a Grave-stone lying in the Chapel, at the East End of the South Isle, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of ANDREW HOBBIS, of East Hanney, Gent. who deceased the xiiith of Aug. An. Domini, MDCLIV. And BRIDGET his Wife, late Daughter to RALPH BENNET, of West Challow, Es{que} who deceased the xiiith Day of December, Anno Domini, MDCXLIV.
DIV2.P: Cut on a Grave-stone lying in the said Chapel, is this Epitaph.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of ANTHONY AYLWORTH, Gent. Second Sonne of Dr. ANTHONY AYLWORTH, who deceased the xviith Day of August, Anno Domini, MDCLXII.
DIV2.P: At the North East End of this Chapel, stands a raised Monument, whereon, in Brass Plates, are graved the Effigies of a Man in Armour, lying between his two Wives, habited in the Fashion of the Times they lived in, under their Feet are these Verses.

Q.L: Stay thou that passest by this Waye, this Grave-stone to beholde,
Here under lyeth the Corps of one, who made was of thy Moulde;
As he is dead, so must thou dye, in Heaven to live againe,
(If as e did, so thou dye well) or els in endles payne.

DIV2.Q: MORS PIA, CHRISTO VIA.
DIV2.P: Lower are the Pourtraitures of his Three Daughters.
In a Ledge of Brass, set round the up∣per Stone of the said Monument, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Here lyeth the Body of Francis Wel∣lesborne, ............
This is covered by a Pew.

............ namely Alice and Elianor, which Alice deceased without Yssue; and by Elia∣nor, Daughter to Thomas Stafford, of Broadfield, in the said County, Es{que} he had Yssue Three Daughters, Frances, (Katharine deceased) and Anne. He dyed the vth Day of December, Anno, MDCII. Aetatis suae 76.

DIV2.P: On a Marble laid in the Body of the Church, whence the Brass Inscription is taken away, there remains, engraven on other Pieces of Brass, the Figure of a Man in compleat Armour, and a Woman lying by him.
On a Brass Plate, lately on a Grave-stone, in the North Isle, now preserved in a Chest in the Church, bearing two Fi∣gures of a Man and Woman, is this In∣scription.

Q.P:
Pray for the Soules of John Fe∣typlace, and Margaret his Wife; which John decessid the Second Day of August, An. Dom. MCCCCCX.
and the said Margaret the VIth Day of January, An. Dom. MCCCCCXI. On there Soul God have......

DIV2.P: In one of the Pews, on a plain square Stone, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: D. O. M. Hic immunitur Pace tibi Monitor, Humilitesque acquievit (Dei atque Parentum deliciae) Sara Champion. Septendecenaria in Eternalia, Quae Fide faeliciter mutavit spe Numini se offert Charitate consecrat. D. D. Q.
DIV2.P: On the Wall, on a white Marble Tablet, enchased in Black, is this Inscription.

Q.P:
D. O. M. Here, in Hope of a joyful Resur∣rection to Everlasting Life, resteth the Body of John Yate, of Lyford, in the County of Berks, Es{que} whose entire Catholike Faith, Love to God, Charity towards all, may safely ground that Hope. He departed
this Life on the xxvith Day of January, in the Yeare of our Lord, MDCLXXI.
Hoc in Memoriam Pii Conjugis Uxor Maerens poni curavit. Tu qui hac transis Lector, illum diligenter Imitate & de tuo priter itinere ad faelicem Aeternitatem frequenter cogita.

DIV2.P: Near this, on the Ground, on a plain Stone, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lieth the Body of Thomas Yate, Infant, the Sonne of Charles Yate, and Grandson of John Yate, of Lyford, who departed this Life the xxvth Day of Aprill, Anno Domini, MDCXCV.
DIV2.P: On another Grave-stone near the for∣mer, is this Inscription.
On another Grave-stone near the for∣mer, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here in Hope of a joyful Resurrection to Everlasting Life, resteth the Body of Charles Yate, of Lyford, in the County of Berks, Es{que} whose entire Catholick Faith, Love to God, Charity towards all, may safely ground that Hope. He departed this Life on the xth Day of April, in the Year of our Lord, MDCXCVI. aged 37 Years.
DIV2.P: In the Body of the Church, on a square White Marble Stone, bearing a Death's Head, with Two Bones crossing it, and this Inscription.

Q.P: Hodie mihi, Cras tibi.
Here lieth the Body of Thomas Weedon, of West Hanney, who departed this Life the xixth Day of September, Annoque Dom. MDCCIV. Aetatis suae 37.

DIV2.P: On a Black Marble in the South Isle, is this Inscription.

Q.P: In Memory of Thomas Hayward, of East Hanny, who was buried the xviith Day of August, MDCCII. aged 57. Also Thomas, the eldest Son of Thomas Hay ward, was buried October the xiith. A. D. MDXCIII.
Francis, the 2d Son of Tho. Hayward, was buried July the vth, A. D. MDCCI. Aged 31.
Here lieth Paul Hayward, the youngest, Son of Thomas Hay ward, who departed this Life June the xith, A. D. MDCCVI. Aged 24.
Priscilla, the Wife of Tho. Hayward, Senior, and Daughter of Richard Wan∣cell, of East Hanny, was buried Octo∣ber the xxixth An. Do. MDCCI. Aged 62.

DIV2.P: Upon the Wall in the North Cross.
Given by the Worshipful Lady Ledcott, One Pound to East Hanny, to be paid at Whitsontide.
The Rent of One Acre of Land given by William Brookes to East Hanny.
Given by Richard Richards, of East Han∣ny, Ten Pounds to East Hanny, and Ten Pounds to West Hanny; the Interest to re∣main to the Poor for ever, An. Dom. 1696.

Given by the Worshipful Family of Ayshcombs, of Lyford, Butt Closs, the Rent to be given to the Poor of this Parish the Sunday before Christmas, the 13th Part, and 5th Part to Lyford; to the Use of Cul∣ham 10 l. to the Two Hannies four Pounds; the Rent of Houses and Lands to the Poor of this Parish; Five Pounds in James Cox's Hands in East Hanny, and Five Pounds of the Posseffion of James Cox of West Han∣ny; the Use to the Poor of Church Hanny; the one Five Pounds given by Thomas Cox; and the other Five Pounds given by John Cox, his Son.

DIV2.HEAD: MARCHAM,
DIV2.P: Is a Vicaridge in the Deanery of Abing∣ton, in the Patronage of Christ Church, in Oxford, who presented Mr. David Jones, M. A. late Student there.
Near the North Wall, in the Chancel lies a Grave-stone, having the Figure of a Man in Armour, cut on a Brass Plate, and at his Feet this Epitaph.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Willielmus Corbet, de Haddeley, Miles, qui obiit VI Die Decembris, Anno Domini, MCCCCIII. & Beatrix Vxor ejus. Duorum animabus propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: Against the North Wall is a Monu∣ment erected of Grey Marble, whereon are Brass Plates nailed, and thereon the Picture of a Man in Armour, kneeling be∣fore a Faldstoole, with Four Sons in like manner clad in Gowns kneeling behind him. Opposite to the Man is his Wife likewise kneeling, and behind her six Daughters in the same Posture, and un∣der them this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth buried Edmund Fety∣place, Esquire, and Margaret his Wife; whych Edmund departed this present Lyfe the First Day of Aprill, in the Yere of our Lord God, MCCCCCXL. Of there Soulles, and all Chrrsten Soulles, Ihesu have Mercy. Amen.
DIV2.P: At the Foot of the aforesaid Monument lyes a Grave-stone bearing this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyes the Body of THOMAS HAL, late Vicar of Marcham, which MDCXLIX. Aged 70.
DIV2.P: In the upper South Window of the Church is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hugo......Guy, Rector Ecclesie qui hanc fenestram fieri......

DIV2.HEAD: KINGSTON BAKEPUZE,
DIV2.P: Alias Kingston Baptist, alias Kingston Inn, is in the Deanery of Abington, and Hundred of Oke. This Manor was given to St. John's College in Oxford, by their Founder, Sir Thomas White, Kt. Alder∣man of London; and confirmed to them by Letters Patents, dated May I. 1555. They are also Patrons of this Rectory, of which, the present Incumbent is Richard Bleching∣don, L. L. D. Provost of Worcester Col∣lege in Oxford, Rector of Newnham Court∣ney in Oxfordshire, and Prebendary of Glou∣cester. In it is the Seat of..... Bland, Es{que} who married the Heiress of Fety-Place.

Near his House stands the Church, where against the South Wall is a Mo∣nument, on which were the Statues of a Man and Woman, kneeling at a Desk, but these are now destroyed, and only this Inscription remains.
DIV2.Q: GEORGIUS RAINSBEE, Vir summae Eruditionis, Doctrinae approbatae, spe∣ctatae probitatis, famae integrae, muni∣ficentiae plusquam vulgaris, Sanctae Theologiae Baccalaureus, Coll. Divi. J. Baptist Olim socius, & hujus Eccle∣siae Rector vigilantissimus; qui obiit vi∣cesimo, Decem. MDCXXIV. Hic jacet sepultus, una cum FRANCISCA dilectissima Conjuge, quae non diu ante fato functa moestum reliquit.

Q.L: Indicat hic tumulus periturae tempora vitae,
Vertor ut in cineres, sic Monumenta cadunt.
Viximus & quoniam concordi pace ligati,
Me doluit tecum non potuisse Mori.
Sponte sequor, metamque hilares proper amus ad istam
Ad quam te ducet (qui legis ista) dies.
GEORGIUS LYNNET, nepos maerens posuit.

DIV2.P: In the North Wall of the Chancel re∣mains an old Arch, wherein a Body hath been laid, but now has no Inscription.
Under an Arch over against Mr. Rains∣bee's Monument, is this Inscription.
Arthur Aubrey, buried December 24. MDCVII. Coelum Patria, Mundus exilium.
In a Chapel on the South Side of the Church is a raised Stone, under which lyes one of the Lattons.
Nigh it lye the Bowels of Judge Willi∣ams, (who, I presume, died here in a Jour∣ney) but his Body was carried into Wales.
In the Window over it are Latton's Arms with Quarterings.
In the Hall Window of the House of Mr. Tho. Latton, afterwards Mr. Fetyplace; now belonging to Mr. Blandy, who mar∣ried one of the Fetyplace's (the Manor House) are these Arms.
Parted per Pale Sable, and Argent, a Saltire ingrail per Pale Ermin, Lotton Quartering.
(1.) Argent, on a Saltier Bend between 4 Griffins Heads erased, Gules, a Lion's Face between 4 Lozenges, Or. Alford.
(2.) Argent, 3 Bends Wavy, Sable. Isbury.
(3.) Argent, 3 Fusils in Fess, Sable. Percy.
(4.) Ermin, 3 Bowes bent in Pale, Or. Chewecher.
(5.) Gules, 3 Gates, Or. Yate.
(6.) Or, a chief Checquy, Gules, and, Or, a Griffin Rampant, Or: Over all, a Bend Ermin. Wellsborne, or Welsbury.
Latton Quartering Percy, Isbury and Alford, impaling, blazoned 3 Demi Lions Passant, Gard. or Quartering.
(1.) Blazoned 3 Roses Argent.
(2.) Argent, 2 Bends Sable.
(3.) Argent, 2 Barrs Gules, Quarter∣ing.
(1.) Per Pale Argent, Sable, a Fess per Pale Gules, Or.
(2.) Quarterly, Sable, Argent, 4 Grif∣fins Heads erased, counterchanged.
(3.) Checquy, Or, blazoned on a Fess Gules, 3 Lions Rampant Argent.
(4.) The same as the Second; and, Or, on a Bend Sable, 3 Unicorns Argent.
(5.) Or, on a Fess Gules, between 10 Cross Crosslets Sable, 3 Lions Heads era∣sed, Argent.
(6.) Gules, a Cheveron between 3 Ro∣ses Argent.
(7.) Or, on a Cheveron Gules, 3 Mart∣lets Argent.
(8.) Argent, On a Chief Gules, 3 Bucks Heads cabossed, Or.
(9.) Gules, a Cheveron Argent between 9 Bezants.
(10.) Sable, 3 Lions Rampant, Gard. Or.
(11.) Argent, 4 Barrs, over all an Eagle Gules.
(12.) Argent, a Chief Vert. over all a Bend Gules.
(13.) A Lion Rampant, Argent.
(14.) Gules, a Bend Lozenge Ermin.
(15.) Argent, a Cheveron between 3 Escallops Sable.
(16.) A Lion Rampant between Escallops, Gules.
(17.) Sable, a Lion Rampant, Gules, between Bezants.
(18.) Argent, on a Bend Sable 3 Be∣zants.
(19.) Argent, on a Cheveron, Gules, 3 Fleurs de lis.
The Crest a Bow beut in Pales, Or. Welsbury, Quartering.
