(2.) Argent, 3 Cups covered, on a Chief Gules, a Tower, Or, between 2 Lions Passant Argent.
(3.) Per Fess Ermin, Argent, on a Cant∣ton, Gules, an Owle Argent.
Latton impaling Isbury.
(1.) Impaling Percy.
(2.) Impaling Alford.
(3.) Impaling Yate.
(4.) Wellsbury.
(5.) Chevecher.
About a Mile from this Place lyes the small Village of

DIV2.HEAD: FYFYDE, alias FYFEILD,
DIV2.P: Which is situated in the Hundred of Oke, and Deanery of Abington.

This Manor was formerly in the Pos∣session of the Golafre's, a Family of no small Note in this County, and the ad∣joining County of Oxford; where I find them particularly mentioned in the larger Register of Einsham Abby, cap. 159. that one Hugh Golafre, who lived in 1181. with the consent of Sybella, and his Sons and Heirs, Roger and Thomas, gave to the Monks of Einsham his Chapel of Serchesdune,
(Saresden) with all its Appurtenances, as well the Tythes of Hay, as the Tythes of his Mill there, and unum borderium quod Alardus tenuit, quod jacet juxta terram Ecclesie in dextera exitus ville, teste Ra∣dulpho de Cheisne. About the time of the Reformation, it was bought by Sir Thomas White, Kt. Lord Mayor of the City of Lon∣don, in 1555. and Founder of St. John Bap∣tist College in Oxford, on which Founda∣tion he settled it; at first Leasing it out to his Brother, in whose Family, in a di∣rect Line, it has continued to this Day, and is now vested in Francis White, Es{que} St. John's College are Lords of the Ma∣nor, and Patrons of the Advowson, and out of the great Tythes of this Vicaridge, in 1711. settled 30 £. Annum, on the Vicar, who is, at present, Moses Wiles, D. D. and Fellow of that College.

Near the Church is the old Manor House, belonging to Mr. White. The Chancel of this Church belongs to the Fa∣mily of Perrott, of North Leigh in Ox∣fordshire, an antient and genteel Family, who are obliged to keep it in constant Re∣pair.
In the North Isle, on a Black Marble Grave-stone, is the following Inscription.

Q.P: Depositum ROBERTI SALTERN, A. M. Coll. Di. Jo. Bapt. Oxonii, olin Socii, & Rectoris Ecclesiae Parochialis de Kingston Bagpuze; quod hic reconodi voluit Juxta Uxorem suam dilectissimam MARGARETAM; Atneptim RADULPHI WHITE, Fratris THOMAE WHITE, Mil. & Coll. Di. JO. Bapt. Oxonii, Fundatoris.

DIV2.P: In the middle of the South Wall of the Chancel, is a fair Monument, bearing the Figure of a Man to his middle, in a Gown, holding a Death's Head under his Right Hand, and at the bottom the fol∣lowing Inscription.

DIV2.HEAD: MEMORIAE SACRUM.
DIV2.Q:
GEORGII DALE, nati antiqua & illustri Familia in agro Somerset, quondam Coll. Oriel, Oxon. Socii, Academiae Procuratoris, Aulae B. Mariae Virg. Praafecti, & L. L. Doctoris, Viri literis & moribus ornatissimi, qui senio tandem confectus,
animam placide Coelo reddidit, Novemb. xxvi. MDCXXV. Aet. suae 66. Uxor MARIA, filia GULIEL. & Amit. LEECH, Proneptis THOMAE WHITE, Mil. Fundat. Coll. D. Joan. Bapt. Oxon. Pii affectus ergo, superstes pofuit.
DIV2.P: On the North Side of the Chancel is a large hollow Square cut in the Wall, arch∣ed at the Top, and in the middle is a Ledge of Stone. The Pillars on either Side, as also the Arch, are wrought with antient Tabernacle Work, being also painted with a deep Blue Colour, and Gilt.
This is called the Lady Gorgon's Mo∣nument.
In the East End of the Chancel, towards the North, upon a Grave-stone, is this In∣scription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of ROSE BAGESHOT, Wife of GEORGE BAGESHOT, Es{que} who deceased the vth of Decemb. MDCXXVIII.
DIV2.P: In the Chancel, on a North Wall, is a very large, beautiful, White Marble Tablet, whereon is the following Inscription.

Q.P: M. S. Incomparabilis Viri, CAROLI PERROTT, L. L. D. Et COLL. DI. JO. BAPT. OXON, nuper Socii.

DIV2.P:
Qui Virtute Consanguinitatis, qua Fundatorem quam proxime attigerat, In Istius Collegii Socium ascitus; Per XXX plus minus Annos & Collegii, & Academiae, Ornamentum vixit, Et moriens utrisque triste sui desiderium reliquit. Vir bono humani generis promovendo natus, Cui ad singularem Prudentiam, Integritatem, & in negotiis obeundis peritiam,
accessit intemerata in Regem & Ecclesiam Fides, Animus in cunctos, ad omnia humanitatis officia promptus: Qui ad summa Reipubl. & Academiae munera obeunda accersitus, Nimirum ter unanimi omnium Saffragio in BURGENSEM Academicum Electus, Ad haec IRENARCHA tum in Comit. Berks, tum in Civit. Oxon, Constitutus Vice Cancellarii, denique in Curia ASSESSOR. In his tot tantisque muneribus ita se gessit, Ut omnium in se admirationem concitaret, nullius invidiam, Si quidem ut non meruit, ita nec habuit inimicum. Ea morum suavitate, & candore, ea animi aequabilitate praeditus, ut nemo non amicitiam ejus coleret. Ea porro prudentia & probitate ornatus, Ut nemo, etiam si cuperet, quicquam quod in eo reprehenderet, reperire posset,
Verum licet in tamarduis negotiis assidue fuerit occupatus, Nunquam tamen aut Collegio, aut amicis consilium ejus vel opera defuit, In Rebus secundis decus nostrum, & delicae, in Difficultatibus tutela & perfugium, Et quasi parum esset Collegio, dum vixerat, profuisse, Ejus commodis in Aeternum cupiens consulere C. LIBRAS Bibliothecae Testamento legavit.

Neque vero intra hos limites se continere potuit tam largus animus; Verum ad omnes homines se extendit, & beneficia sua quaquàversus diffudit; Quantum Pietati, Concordiae, Felicitati inter homines prmovendae incubuerit, Populum Ecclesiae conformem praestando, Litibus componendis, Pauperibus sublevandis Cum, omnis circumjecta Vicinia, tum haec Parochia abunde testatur Sed O praeproperum & immaturum tanti Viri fatum!
Has tot tamque proeclaras virtutes Violenta Febris quatuor dierum spatio sustulit, Damnum vix totidem saeculis reparandum, Postquam vixisset, An. XLIII. Junii X. A. D. MDCLXXXVI.
Sed nimium debebat hoc viro adeo supra vulgus mortalium constituto, Ut ad Coelum quasi evocatus, citius aliis immortalitate donaretur.
Vir lacrymis in Aeternum prosequendus, Nisi quod etiam tum cum lamentamur, qúod abstulerit.
Non possumus, non summas DEO. OPT. MAX. gratias agere, quod dederit, Et quod novissimo die redonaturus sit.
LUGE, LECTOR, Mirare, &, si possis, IMITARE.
Upon another Grave-stone in the Chan∣cel, are the Figures of a Man and his Wife insculped on a Brass Plate, and fixed upon a Grave-stone, underneath whom is this defective Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Armiger, & Elizabeth Vxor ejus, nuper de Padworth, qui obiit... Dni. MCCCC. tricesimo; quorum animabus propicietur Deus. Amen
DIV2.P: In the East Window of the Chancel.
Quart....... and Gules, in the 2d and 3d a Fret, Or.
DIV2.Q: In the South Windows.
DIV2.P: Barry of Nebule, 6 Argent and Gules, on a Bend Sable, 3 Bezants, which is the Coat of Golafre. Gules, a Pale, Or.
DIV2.Q: In the Windows of a South Side Chapel.
DIV2.P: Barry of Nebule, 6 Argent and Gules, on a Bend Sable, 3 Bezants—Golafre, Gules, a Pale, Or.
Upon another Grave-stone is the fol∣lowing Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of GEORGE BAGESHOT, of Presber, in the County of Gloucest. Es{que} who lived 78 Yeares, and dyed the xxxth of May, MDCXII.
DIV2.P: On a Grave-stone lying in the Body of the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of SUSANNA LANE, Wife of WILLIAM LANE, of Bradley, Gentleman, Daughter of WILLIAM LEECH, Gent, interred the vith Day of December, MDCL.
DIV2.P: In a Chapel on the South-Side of the Church, lyes a Marble, whereon is en∣graved in Brass, the Figure of a Man in the Habit of the Times, and under his Feet this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Pray for the Soul of Thomas Nyoollis, the which deceasyd the XXVIIIth Day of March, in the Yeare of our Lord MDI. on whole Soul Ihesu have MerCy.
DIV2.P: On another Grave-stone in the same Chapel, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of JAMES HAZELL, who deceased the xxviiith of October, MDCLV. Aged 65.
DIV2.P: On the North Side of the Church, in a fair Chapel, is an open arched Monument, in which lyes the Pourtraiture of Sir John Golafre in Armour, and underneath, the Figure of a Skeleton upon a Shroud, his Feet resting upon a Hound.
DIV2.Q: At the Head.
DIV2.P: Gules, 2 Bars, Or, Quartering.
(1.) A Fess Dauncetty between Billets.
Over all, an Escutcheon of Pretence, and thereon a Lion Rampant.
DIV2.Q: On the Side.
DIV2.P: On a Fess Argent, between 3 Lions Faces, Or, an Annulet Sable. Barry Ne∣bule, of 6 on a Bend Sable, 3 Bezants. Golafre.
Quarterly, Or, and Gules, a Bordure ingrailed, Sable.
Gules, a Cross Argent.
Parted per Pale, indented, Or, and Gules, impaling Sable, a Bend, Or, be∣tween 9 Bezants.
Lozenge, Argent and Gules.
DIV2.Q: At the Feet.
DIV2.P: Argent, a Fess Danc. Sable, between 3 Mullets, Sable...................
DIV2.Q: In a North Window of the Church.
DIV2.P: Lozengy, Or, and Azure.
Parted per Fess, the upper Part, par∣ted per Pale, indented, Or, and Gules, and the lower Part is Ermin, which im∣pales quarterly, Ermin, and Gules; in the 2d and 3d a Frett, Or.

DIV2.HEAD: APPLETON,
DIV2.P: Is a Rectory in Oke Hundred, in the Deanery of Abington, and in the Gift of St. Mary Magdalen College, in Oxford. Mr. Cripps Incumbent.
On a Grave-stone in the Chancel, ha∣ving the Figure of a Skeleton lying in a Shroud, cut in Brass, is this Inscrip∣tion.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth John Goodrington, Gen∣tleman, which deceased the last Day of December, An. Domini, MDXVIII. Of your Charitie pray for his Soule, and for Dorothy his Wife, which af∣ter his Death, toke Religion in the Monastery of Syon.
DIV2.P: Against the South Wall of the Chancel is erected a Monument of Free-Stone, and encompassed with Iron Pallisadoes, where lyes the Pourtraiture (at full length) of a Knight in compleat Armour, and on the side of the Wall this following In∣scription.

Q.P:
Jacet hic, optime lector, sub spe beatoe Resurrectionis, repositum Corpus JO∣HANNIS FETIPLACE, Militis; quo, ut Patrioe non fuit studiosior, it a nee ca∣rior alter, bis Matrimonio junctus fu∣it, ex prima conjuge ELIZABETHA, fi∣lia ANTONII HUNGERFORD, Militis, quatuor suscepit filios, & tres filias, BESILIUM, RICARDUM, ROBERTUM, EGIDIUM, DOROTHEAM, MARGA∣RETAM, atque JANAM. BESILIUS, filius natu maximus in uxorem duxit HELINORAM filiam RICHARDI CO∣VERT, Armigeri, ex qua genuit sex filios & quinque filias, RICARDUM, EDVARDUM, THOMAM, MICHAELEM, JOHANNEM, GULIELMUM, JANAM, MARCAM, EDITHAM, ELIZABETHAM, at que CECILIAM, RICARDUS, BESI∣LII filius duxit in Uxorem HELINORAM. Filiam HENRICI POOLE, Militis, ex∣qua genuit filium JOHANNEM, jam qua∣tuor annos natum, MARIA & ELI∣ZABETHA obiere Infantes, reliqui, BE∣SILII proles ac RICARDUS eorum Pa∣truus vivunt, adhuc coeteri JOHANNIS Liberi obiere coelibes; & plerique pueri ex secunda conjuge JANA, filia JO∣HANNIS COVERT, Armigeri, unicam genuit filiolam MARGARETAM, cujus,
intactum Corpus hic quoque sepultum; jacet ipse JOHANNES FETIPLACE, ex hac vita decessit xxviii°. Die De∣cemb. MDLXXX. Insigne relin∣quens Trophoeum posteris suis, famoe pu∣roe, vitoe integroe, & amoris in patri∣am, cujus subitam atque intempesti∣vam mortem accusat vicinus, lacryma∣tur vidua, deplorat pauper, queruntur omnes, BESILIUS FETIPLACE, filius ejus, hoc illi de se optime merito, & pio parenti pietatis ergo Monumentune posuit, Anno Domini, MDXCIII.
Mihi est Christus, & in Vita, & in Morte Lucrum.
Tempora qui longoe speras foelicia vitoe, Spes tua frustrata est, en tibi, testis Ego.

DIV2.HEAD: HORMER Hundred. ABINGTON Town.
DIV2.P:
About five Miles from the City of Ox∣ford lyes Abington, a neat Town, very antient and remarkable for its famous Ab∣by, one of the Glories of England, and Reproaches of Sacrilege. This Place was formerly known by the Name of Sheove∣sham; or according to Leland, Seusham or Seukesham; which last Way of writing has been confirmed by a M. S. in the Cot∣tonian Library, in Claudius, B. VI. Some have taken this Place to be the Cloveshoe, so famous for several Synods, or Councils. To proceed, the Monastery of the Bene∣dictine Order in this Town, was found∣ed by Heane, Nephew to Cissa, Father to King Ina, about 675. In the Days of King Alfred, Restorer of the University of Ox∣ford, the Danish Inundation drove the Monks a way, who returned again upon the Encouragement of King Eldred 955, and Ethelwoldus their Abbot, Bishop of Winchester. Soon after the Norman Con∣quest, the Abbey was in so flourishing a State, as to be able in 1084. to receive Wil∣liam I. at Easter; when he left his youngest
Son Henry to be educated here, under the Tuition of Robert d' Oyly, a great Be∣nefactor to this Place. Many Men emi∣nent for their Quality, Learning, and Virtue, lye interred in the Church of this Abby; but all Memorials of them were destroyed by the Enthusiastick Fury of the Times of Reformation, when this Mona∣stery fell a Sacrifice to Lust and Avarice, and was rated at 1876 l. 10 s. 9d. Dug∣dale, at 2042 l. 2 s. 8 d. ob. Burton. This Town was made a Free Borough and Cor∣poration, by Queen Mary, at the Request of Sir John Mason, a Native of this Place; and by its Charter it consists of twelve principal Burgesses, viz. a Mayor, 2 Bai∣liffs, and Nine Aldermen, who only, and their Successors, have Votes in an Electi∣on in Parliament. The Manor, Lord∣ship, &c. were formerly Demesnes of the Abbey, and are now vested in the Cor∣poration. In this Town is a Free School, founded in 1563. by John Royse, which has produced some eminent Men. Leland and Camden both take Notice of a Cross formerly in this Town, built of Free-Stone, and not inferior in Workmanship to any in England; but Triumphant Rebellion has left us no Remains of it. Henry the Sixth, by his Charter dated 20 October, Anno Regni 20..... under the Great Seal of
England, authorized William, Bishop of Sarum, William Earl of Suffolk, Thomas Bekinton, Clerk, John Golafre, John Notes, Esquires, Thomas Plesance, Philip Ripe, Hugh Mayn, and Nicholas Goulde, or any 7, 6, 5, or 4 of them, Associating to themselves others Men or Women, to the Honour of God and the Holy Cross, to make and ordain a Brother∣hood, or Gylde in the Parish Church of St. Elyn, in Abingdon, which should be called the Matter, Brethren and Sisters of the Fraternity, or Gylde of the Holy Cross of Abingdon. By the same Charter an Authority was given of purchasing of Lands of 40 Pounds yearly Rent, for the Repair of the Road between Dorchester and Abington, for the Main∣tenance of 13 poor Men and Women for ever, and for a Chaplain to officiate in St. Helen's Church. To them, as ap∣peared from the Arms of the Trustees of this Charity, was owing the stately Cross mentioned before.
In this Town are two Churches; the first dedicated to St. HELEN, has in it the following Monuments.

In the middle of the Chancel lies a Mar∣ble Stone, and thereupon is fixed a Plate
of Brass, on which is engraved the Fi∣gure of a Man habited in a Gown and Hood, at whose Feet is this Inscrip∣tion.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Willielmus Hey ward, Sa∣cre Cheologie Doctor, quondam illius Ecclesie Uicarius, qui obiit XIV Die Junii, Anno Domini, MVc. primo. Cujus anime pro∣picietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: Cut upon a Grave-stone near the Entrance into the Chancel, is this Inscrip∣tion.
DIV2.Q: ANNA DOD, Cestren. Ortu & Virtute Nobiliss. Lectissima, Piissima, ac Fidelissima, THO. DOD, Sacr. Theolog. Prof. Decani Ecclesioe de Rippon, Uxor. Obdormivit in Domino, Apr. xxviii. An. Sui Jesus MDCXXXVI. Resurgam.
DIV2.P: On a Monument fixed in the Wall Southward of the Chancel, is this Inscrip∣tion.

Q.P: THOMAS MAYOTT, Gent, sometyme a principal Burgess of this Borrough, and a Governour of the Hospitall, and often chosen chief Officer of both these Incorporations, which to governe well he made his chiefest Care: And vallued their Wellfaire as his owne, for as he was truly Religious, so was he truly Honest. In his Lyfe, his Purse was the Poore Mans Exchequer, and at his Death he gave Perpetuities to the Church and Poore. He married ELIZABETH, eldest Daughter of THOMAS LYDALL, of Redding, Gent, and had Yssue foure Sons and 5 Daughters, and dyed the last of May, Anno Domini, MDCXXVII. aged 63, and lyeth buried in this Chancel.
The Memory of the Just is Blessed.
Virtus post funera vivit.

DIV2.P: Engraven on a Brass Plate fixed on a Grave-stone lying before the said Monu∣ment, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of THOMAS MAYOTT, Gent, who was twice Maior of this Towne. He dyed the xxxth Day of May, Anno Domini, MDCXXVII. Aged 63 Yeares.
DIV2.P: At the East End of the aforesaid South Wall, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: In obitum & exequias generosi juvenis & optimoe spei adolescentis EDMUNDI BOSTOCK, filii natu maximi LIONELLI BOSTOCK, generosi nuper de Abbington villa hac: in qua nati ambo & denati.

Q.L: Pulvere qui denso in tumulo hoc nunc conditur imo,
Heu Bostokus erat, juvenis pulcherrimus, omni
Naturoe, Generis, Virtutum, Flore beatus.
Ast nil terrigenum, quin natum, ex parte beatum,
Extitit & perstat, Lex hoec mortalibus oevi,
Sit potior Coelo: Corpus tamen occidit omne.

DIV2.Q: Obiit Aug. tertio, A. D. MDCV. Aet. suoe. 24.

Q.P: Lionellus Bostock frater vere germanns & unice dilectissimus, maerens moerenti (Quicquid potis erat mortuo) posuit & Sanctissimi frater in maximeque Individuus, oeternam in amoris Memoriam reliquit.
JOHANNES TICHBORNUS Presbiter & Satroe Thelogioe Professor, deflevit.

DIV2.P: In a Tablet hanging on the said South Wall, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Juxta hunc locum reposita sint ossa OLIVERI HYDE, Armigeri, tertio Idus Febr. An. Salutis, MDLV. & THOMASINAE Ux ejus. Idibus Jan. An. MDLXVIII.
DIV2.P: Upon a Brass Plate fixed on a Grave∣stone, towards the West End of the South Isle, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Nic jacet Glafridus Barbur, Mexca∣tor D' Abendon, quondam Balli∣ous Bristollie, qui oviit xxi Die Mensis Aprilis, Anno Domini, MCCCCXVII. Cujus anime pro. Picietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: Engraved on a Black Marble, fixed on a Pillar in the middle of the South Isle, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Depositum sui in Spem Resurrectionis, Huic terroe crediderunt.

Q.P: ROBERTUS PAYNE, de Villa de Wanting, oriundus, Vir Religione, Fide Probitate Antiquis. Ob Vitoe Integritatem & Candidos Mores, bonis omnibus multum dielectus. Proetoris. Officio in hoc Oppido quater functus.
MARTHA, Uxor ejus, filia GULIEL BRANCH de Abingdun, Foemina Pietate, Pudicitia, cultu Ingenuis. Animo In viram obsquenti: In prolem provido, In egenos facili, In omnes benigno.

DIV2.Q: R. P. (Vixit Annos LXXV. Obiit IIII. Id. Febr. Anno a partu Virg. MDCXXVII.
M. P. Vixit Annos LVIII°. Obiit V. Id Decemb. Anno a partu Virg. MDCXXVI.

Q.P: ROBERTUS PAYNE, Filius.
P. M. P.
On a Pillar on the North Side of the Chancel, hangs a Tablet, containing a Genealogical Tree branched with the Descendants from Mr. William Lee, and at the Foot thereof this Inscription.

Neere unto this Place lyeth interred the Body of WILLIAM LEE, late of this Borough of Abington, principal Burgess, and five Times Mayor. He continued a principal Burgess 53 Yeares, and a Governor of Christ's Ho∣spital in Abington, aforesaid, 52 Yeares. He was Master of the said Hospital 6 Tymes, and continued senior Governour thereof 36 Yeares. He was zealous in Religion, just in his Deal∣ing loving to his Children, charitable to the Poore, and Courteous to all. He departed this Lyfe upon the vth Day of Nov. Ano. Domini, MDCXXXVII. Aetat. suoe 92.
He had in his Lyfe Tyme Yssue from his Loynes, 200 lacking but 3.

DIV2.P: Upon a Brass Plate set in a Grave-stone, near the West Door of the Church, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth FRANCES, the Wife of THO. GODWIN, Rector of Brightwell: She died Novemb. the iiid. MDCXXIX. in the 31st Yeare of her Age.
DIV2.P: Upon another, not far from the former, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of JANE GODWIN, who departed the xxist of May, An. Domini, MDCXVI.
DIV2.P: At the West End of the North Isle is a Marble Stone, supported with four Mar∣ble Pillars, having a square Stone laid under it, with this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: This Tombe is honoured with the Bones of our pious Bene∣factor, RICHARD CUR∣TAINE, Gent. a principall Magistrate of this Corporation. He was buried July the xviiith. Anno Domini, MDCXLIII.

Q.L: Our Cuttaine in this lower Press,
Rests folded up in Natures Dress;
His Dust perfumes his Urne, and Hee,
This Towne, with Liberalitie.

DIV2.P: On a Plate of Brass fixed on a Grave-stone, lying at the West End of the Body of the Church, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Heere lyeth the Bodies of THOMAS KENT, who departed the ixth of June, MDCI. and KATHERINE, his Wife, who departed the xxivth of June, Anno Domini, MDCXVIII.
St. NICHOLAS Church,

DIV2.P: Is said to have been built by one of the Abbots, upon the great Encrease of this Town.
Engraved on a Grave-stone lying in the middle of the Chancel, is this Inscrip∣tion.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Mr. RICHARD CHANY, who was buried The xviiith of July, MDCLIX.
DIV2.P: On a Marble Stone fixed to the South Wall of the Church, is this Inscription.

Q.P: Here rests, in Assurance of a joyfull Resurrection, the Bodies of JOHN BLACKNALL, Esq; and JANE his Wife, who both of them finished a happy Course upon Earth, and ended their Dayes in Peace on the xxist of August, in the Yeare of Grace, MDCXXV.
He was a bountiful 'Benefactour to this Church, gave many Benevolences to the Poore, to the Glory of God, and the Example of future Ages.

Q.L: When once they lived on Earthy one Bed did hold
Their Bodies, which one Minute turned to Mould;
Being Dead, one Grave is trusted with that Prize,
Untill the Trump doth sound, and all must rise.
Here Death struck even, yet did not part this Paire,
But by his Stroke they more united were.
And what left they behind, you plainly see,
One only Daughter, and their Charity.
What though the first by Death's Command did leave us,
The second (we are sure) will ne'er deceive us.

DIV2.P: Upon a Marble fixed in the North Wall of the Church, is this Inscription.

Q.P: A Memorial of WALTER DAIRELL, Esq; deceased June xxi, MDCXXVIII. in the 63 Yeare if his Age, at Graies Inn, where he was some Tyme an ap∣proved Reader, and here entred, where he was the carefull Recorder of the Towne.

Lillingstone, the Seat of the antient Family De Hairell, vulgarly Dairell, was honoured with his Birth, but this Church is trusted with the Treasure of his Bones; his Worth claimes Fame for his Trumpet, and Memory it self for his Monument. In the famous U∣niversity of Oxford he was hopefull, in the Innes of Court compleate. The Barr found him not meerely Tongue deep, or a verball Lawyer, for be was eminent, as well for soundness of Judge∣ment, as flourish of Speech: His Law was not opposite to the Gospell; the Advancement of the Clergy being his Joy, and the Beauty of God's House his Delight. He was a Man of an even Temper, abhorring the licentious Libertine, and yet not encouraging the undisciplined Disciplinarian. His Wife was ALICE, the Daughter of THO. MAYOT, of Abingdon, Gent, with whome he perfected the Circle of 26
Yeares Marriage so happily, that no Division was knowne betwixt them, but his Death. The Yssue he had by her was 3 Sons and 3 Daughters, the lively Modells of himself, in whome he yet out lives Mortality.
Ad Viatorem. Ne quoeras Tumuli faslum, nam Memphida vincit Marmor, quod Dairell indicat hic situs est.
Posterity doth owe the Memoriall, to the Piety of Alice, his loving Wife.

DIV2.P: Written upon the Frames of several Pictures hanging in the Hall of Christ's Hospital, in Abington, these Inscriptions.

Q.P: In Memory of Jeoffry Barbur, and John Houchion, Benefactors.

DIV2.P: Francis Little, one of the Governours of this Hospitall, gave this Table, A°. Domini, MDCVII.
Petro Bessiles, Militit, Benefactori.
Gulielmus Bostock, cognationis ergo donavit, Henricus Sextus.
Johannes Masonus, Eques auratus.
Gulielmus Bostock, hanc tabulam posuit, Edwardus Sextus.
Effigies Rob. Orpwood, quondam Ci∣vis & Aurifabri London; qui natus in hac Villa de Abingdon, legavit elemo∣sinam pauperibus hujus Hospitalis per∣petuo duraturum, An°. Domini, MDCXV.
John Perkins Benefactor to this Hospitall.
Lyonell Bostock.
Maudlen Tisden.
In Memory of Richard Curtaine, Gent. a Governor of this Hospitall, and a pious Benefactor to the same, James Curtaine, one of the Governours of this House, gave this Picture, MDCXLV.

In this Hall, on a Tablet, are the following Verses, being a Description of the Building of Culham Bridge, whereby the great Road from London was turned through this Town; and a Detail of the Benefactors.
DIV2.L: Henrici quinti Regis quarto revoluto
Anno Rex idem pontem fundavit utrumque,
Supra locum binum Borford dictumque Culham-ford.
Inter eos namque via Regia tendit alta
Annis adjunctis dat iter gradientibus amplum;
Principium cujus Abendoniae situatur.
Annis tuncPotius demu. donum M quater C numeratis,
Et sexto deno cum fecit opus Pietatis.
Vos qui transitis hujus Memores bene sitis
Et vestris precibus fundator sit relevatus.
Off alle Werks in this Worlde that ever were wrought,
Holy Chirche is chefe, there Children been chersyd,
For be Baptism these Barnes to Blisse been I brought,
Thorough the Grace of God, and Fayre refresshed.
Another blissed Besiness is Briggges to make
There, that the Pepul may not passe after greet Showers,
Dole it is to drawe a deed Body oute of a Lake,
That was falled in a Fount Stoon, and a Fellow of oures.
King Henry the Fifte, in his fourthe Yere,
He hath I found for his Folke a Brige in Berkeschure,
For Cartis with Cariage may goo and come clere.
That many Wynters afore were marred in he Myre;
And som oute of her Sadels flette to the Grounde,
Went forthe in the Water wist no Man whare,
Fyve Wekys after, or, they were I founde,
Her Kyn and her Knowlech caught hem uppe with Care.
Then the Commons of Abendon cryed on the Kynge,
Upon Dukes and Lordes that were in this Londe
The Kynge had hem begynne upon Goddes Blissinge,
And make it also stronge as they couthe with Stone, Lyme, or Sonde.
Apon the Day of Seynt Albon they began this Game,
And John Huchyns layde the firste Stoon in the Kynges Name;
Sir Peris Besillis, Knight, curteys and heend,
For his Fadir Soule, and his Frendes, he dyd as he scholde,
Ne gaf hem Stonys i now he into the Wekys ende,
Also Mony as they nedid, feche them if they wolde.
Than Crafti Men for the Querry made Crows of Yre,
Weges, and Wayes, and mony hard Nowys;
Jeffray Barbour had pay hem her Nyre.
Then must they have Mooldes to make on the bowys.
They cokid for Cartes, and cast for herChisying. Chusyng,
They founde oute the Fundement, and layde in large Stones,
They reysid up the Archeys be Geometre in rysing,
With xi Laborers labyng at onys.
Ther was Mater I nowhe, Stone, Lyme and Gravel,
Werkement als wise as they coude fynde any,
And ever had the Barbour pay for her travel,
Til a M. Marke be spende eche a Peny.
Then the strenghe of the Streme astoned hem stronge,
In Labor, and lavyng moche Money was lore;
There loved hem a Ladde was a Waterman longe,
He helpe stop the Streme til the Werke were afore.
It was a Solace to see in a Somer Sesonn,
C. C. C. I wysse working at onys,
iiii. and iiii. revlyd be Resonn,
To wete who wrought best were set for the nonce.
The Peple preved her Power with the pecoyse
The Mattok was Mann handeled right welle a whyle;
With Spades and Schovelts they made suche a Noyse,
That Men myght here hem thens a Myle.
Wyves went oute to wite how they wrought,
V. Score in a Flok, it was a fayre sight;
In bord Clothes bright, white Brede they brought,
Chees and Chekenes clerelych a dyght.
These weren the Dyches, i diged in ful harde Grounde,
And i cast up to arere with the wey,
Se then they were i set with a quyk Mownde
To holde in the Bunkes for ever and ay.
The gode Lord of Abendon, of his Londe,
For the breed of the Brige fote large,
It was a greet Socour of Erthe and of Sonde,
And that he a bated the Kent of the Barge.
An C. Pownde, and xvli. was truly payed,
Be the Bondes of John Huchyns and Banbery also.
For the Waye and the Barge, thus it must be sayed,
Therto Witnesse al Abendon, and many oon moo.
For now is Culham Hithe, i com to an ende,
An al the Contre the better, and no Man the worse;
Few Folke there were coude that wey mende,
But they waged a wed, or payed of her Purse.
And if it were a Begger had Breed in his Bagge,
He schulde be ryght soone i did for to goo aboute;
And of the Pore penyles the hiere ward wold habbe,
A Hood, or a Girdel, and let hem good withoute.
Many moo Myscheves there were I say,
Culham Hithe hath causid many a Curse;
I blyssed be our Helpers, we have a better Waye,
Withoute any Peny for Cart and for Horse.
Thus accordid the Kynge and the Covent,
And the Commones of Abendonn, as the Abbot wolde;
Thus they were eased, and set al in oon Assent,
That al the Brekynges of the Brige, the Towne here schulde.
This was preved Acte also in Perlement,
In perpetual Pees to have and to holde;
This Tale is i tolde in noonn other entent,
But for Myrthe, and in Memory to yonge and to olde;
Now every good Body that gothe on this Brige,
Bid for the Barbour jentil Jeffray,
That clothed many a pore Man to Bed and to Rige,
And hathe holpe to Rentis to holde up this Waye:
The wiche Rentes right trewe Men have i take on Honde,
And Maciusly governed vem hereafter with Pewahe but he stonde.
It schal be knowen openly, he dothe hymselfe begyle,
I councel every Creature to kepe him from the Curse,
For of this Cretis wil I no more telle,
And be not to covetuous to your own Purse.
For Peril of the Peyns in the Pit of Helle.
Now God geve us Grace to folowe Treuthe even,
That we may have a Place in the Blysse of Heven. AMEN.
DIV2.Q: V. A. B. I. N. D. O. N. R. F. I.
DIV2.P: Take the first Letter of youre foure Fader, with A, the worker of Wer, and I. and N. the Colore of an Asse; set them togeder, and tel me yf you can, what it is than. Richard Fannade, Frenmonger, hathe made this Cabul, and set it here in the Yere of King Herry the Sexte, XXVIte.

DIV2.HEAD: SUNNINGWELL,
DIV2.P: Is a Vicaridge in the Hundred of Hor∣mer, and Deanery of Abington, lyes South East of Besills Leigh, and is in the Gift of Mr. Baskerfield. Incumbent Mr. Pen∣ningstone.
Engraved on a Blue Stone laid near the Altar, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: MARGARET FELL, Wife to Dr. FELL, late Deane of Christ Church, and Rector of this Church, was buried on the xxiid Day of Aprill, in the Yeare of Christ, MDCLIII. Aetatis suae 56.
DIV2.P: Underneath the former Inscription is the following Memorial.

Q.P: THOMAS FELL dyed Aug. xxxi. MDCXXXII.
ELIZABETH FELL dyed Dec. xix. MDCXXXIV.
MARTHA FELL dyed Dec. xxiii. MDCXXXVII.
THOMAS WASHBORNE dyed Aug. x. MDCXLIV.

DIV2.P: On another Blue Stone adjoyning to the former, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: DEPOSITUM. S. F. February, MDCXLVIII.
DIV2.P: In this Parish was born the Learned, and Loyal Dr. John Fell, Bishop of Ox∣ford. And the late Incumbent was the Reverend Mr. Henry Jones, who gave se∣veral valuable MSS. to the Bodleian Library in Oxford.

DIV2.HEAD: RADLEY,
DIV2.P: Is in the Hundred of Hormer, Deanery of Abington, and is a Donative in the Gift of Sir John Stonehouse, Bar. who in the latter End of 1716. presented Nathaniel Thompson, L. L. D. and Fellow of St. John Baptists College in Oxford, the present Incumbent.

Against the South Wall of the Chan∣cel is a very fair arched Monument raised, whereon lyes the Pourtraiture of Sir Wil∣liam Stonehouse in Armour, with his La∣dy
in the same Posture near him. At the Head of the Monument is the Fi∣gure of a Man in Armour; on the Sides are Sons in long Mourning Cloaks; four young Children in their swadling Clothes, and five Daughters.
On the Side of the South Wall, above the Pourtaiture, is the following In∣scription.
DIV2.Q:
Lector Academice, sive quisquis es, qui huc accesseris, Quam iniquo pede senectutis parietes, ac juventoe flores, Mors pulsat, hoc (si libet) in speculo contemplare: Gulielmus Stonehouse, Baronettus, Antiqua & Generosa Stonehousiorum de Radley, prosapia oriundus, Vir ob singularem probitatem, & eximium ingenii acumen. Majoribus par negotiis, quam propria Modestia sinebat post adolescentiam in literis ac transmarina Peregrinatione feliciter emensam, procul urbano tumultu & ultra a vestigiis maluit in salutari Patrimonii sui glebâ sibi & Virtuti vacare, ubi animo in egenos Munificio, in caeteros Hospitali, erga omnes comi, & Candido satis Laudatus, eâ qua Irenarcham, qua Comitatus sui Vice-comitem, qua Patrem Familias decuit prudentia publica munia sic Administravit, ut una privati Laris splendori consuleret,
donec Anima diutin chiragraâcorporis afflicti nodis, soluta fugam sursum capesseret morbo eodem ac vitae periodo imposita, Feb. v. A. D. MDCXXXI. Cujus exuviis hic depositis (ut missi fiant qui ad Coelum praemissI sunt 4 Infantes) Johannes, Georgius, Gulielmus, Elizabetha, Maria, Ursula, Anna, Dyonysia, liberi superstites debito fletu parentarunt, Nec tamen omnes diu superstites quippe (Proh dolor!) lectissimus agri Bercheriensis flos commune amicorum delicium, paterni fundi & virtutem haeres, JOHANNES STONEHOUSE, Eq. Aur. & Baronettus, Olim in Coll. S S. Trinit Oxon. Educatus:
delinde Graiens, Hosp. Socius, Gallia, & Belgio, tanti Viri peragratione illustra1tis, tandem ob insignem Corporis ac Animi decorem jussu CAROLI R. in privatae Camerae sodalitium adscitus, haud sustinuit paterno funeri diu interesse, sed loci pariter ac parentis amore tactus, postquam luctui quatuor menses indulserat paterna nimis propero gressu premens vestigia,
coelebs hinc concessit, & terrenam haereditatem Coelesti commutavit, Junii 14°. Anno Dom. MDCXXXII. Aetat. 31. Elizabetha filia unica & haeres Johannis Powell, Armigeri, Gulielmi, Relicta, quo cum 40 Annos suavissimo conjugii nexu, vixerat. H. M. fieri curavit. Alex. Gill. flevit.
DIV2.P: In a Glass Window on the South Side of the Church, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Orate pro bono statu Johannis Sant. Orate pro bono statu Adam Maude & Denys Vxoris ejus.

DIV2.HEAD: WITHAM,
DIV2.P: Is a Vicaridge in Homer Hundred, in the Deanery of Abington, and in the Gift of the Earl of Abington. Present Incum∣bent is Mr. Lydal, Fellow of St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxford.

In the Chancel of this Church lies a Grave-stone, whereon is the Pourtraiture in Brass of a Man in Armour, and also of his Wife. The Circumscription (cut like∣wise upon Brass) is much defaced, where∣of only thus much of the Writing remains.
DIV2.Q: .................. siia dicti Ricardi Wygtham, que obiit.............. Quorum animabus propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: Over the Entrance into the Chapel, on the North Side, is painted the Arms of Norris, and Fifteen Quarterings, impaled with the Arms of Williams, and Eleven Quarterings. The Crest is an Eagle Sable. The Supporters are a Talbot and a Grey∣hound.
Westward of this Church is an antient Seat belonging to the Earl of Abington.

DIV2.HEAD: CUMNOR,
DIV2.P: Is a Vicaridge in the Hundred of Hor∣mer, and Deanery of Abington; Patron is the Earl of Abington; Incumbent Mr. Pecock.

In the North Wall of the Chancel is a Monument of Grey Marble, where∣on, in Brass Plates, are engraved a Man in Armour, and his Wife in the Habit of her Times, both kneeling before a Fald∣stoole, together with the Figures of three Sons kneeling behind their Mother. Under the Figure of the Man is this Inscription.

Q.L: ANTONIUS FORSTBR, generis generosa propago
Cumnerae Dominus Bercherinesis erat.
Armiger Armigero prognatus patre Ricardo,
Qui quondam Iphlethae Salopinesis erat.
Quatuor ex isto fluxerunt stemmate mati,
Ex isto Antonius stemmate quartus erat.
Mente saga, animo pcecellens, corpore promptus;
Cloquii ducis, ore disertus erat.
In factis probitas; fuit in sermone venustas,
In vultu grabitas, relligione fides,
In patriam pietas, in egenos grata voluntas,
Accedunt reliquis annumeranda bonis.
Si quod cuncta rapit, rapuit non omnia Lethum,
Si quod Mors rapuit, vivida fama dedit.

DIV2.P: Under the Woman is the following In∣scription.

Q.L: ANNA RAINOLDO WILLIAMS fuit orta parente,
Evasit meritis Armiger ille suis,
Sed minor huic frater, prestante laude Baronis.
Thamensis viguit gloria magua soli.
Armiger ergo pater, Dominus sed A vunculus Annae,
Ciara erat his meritis claruit Anna suis,
Casta viro, studiosa Dei, dilecta propinquis,
Stirpe beata satis, prole beata satis.
Mater Joannis, mediaque etate Roberti,
Et demum Henrici nobilis ille Parens
Cynthia Penelope tumulo clauduntur in isto
Anna; sed hoc tumulo sola sepulta jacet.

DIV2.P: These Verses following are writ at length, two by two, in Praise of him.

Q.L: Argute resonas, Cithare pretendere chordas
Novit, & Aouia concrepuisse Lyra.
Gaudebat terre teneras defigere plantas;
Et mira pulchras construere arte domos,
Composita varias lingua formare loquelas
Doctus, & edocta scribere multa manu.

DIV2.P:
The Arms over it thus,
Quart.
I. 3 Hunter's Horns stringed.
II. 3 Pinions with their Points upwards.
The Crest is a Stag Couchant, vul∣nerated through the Neck by a broad Arrow; on his Side is a Martlett for a difference.
The Arms over her Head are as follow.

LIST.ITEM:
Quart.
I. 2 Organ Pipes in Saltier between 4 Crosses Pale.
II. A Raven.
III. A Cheveron erased between 3 Lions Heads erased within a Bordure of Roundells, and on a Chief Bar Nebule, a Pale charg'd with a Pelican.
IV. The same as the first.

DIV2.P: In the Chancel, on a flat Marble, is the Pourtraiture of a Woman, having 3 Sons and 2 Daughters under her; the first of the Sons hath on a Divine's Gown, all on a Brass Plate, and this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here Iyeth the Body of Katherine, sometime the Wyfe of Henry Staverton, Gent. and Daughter of Raynold Williams, of Borfield, in the County of Berks, Es{que} who died a good Christian the xxii Day of December, in the Yere of our Lord God, MDLXXVII.
DIV2.P: A Cheveron between 3 Maunches. The rest the same with the former Coat just mentioned before.

On a Marble adjoyning to the former, is the Effigies of a Man Togated, and a Woman, with the foremention'd Arms, but the Inscription underneath them is torn off. There yet remaineth a small Inscription under their Arms, viz.
In the Body of the Church is a Brass Plate fixt in the Wall, with this Inscription on it.
DIV2.Q: An Epitaph upon the Death of Jeames Welch.
DIV2.L: The Body of Jeames Welch lyeth buried here,
Who left this mortal Life at Fourscore Yeare;
One Thousand and Six Hundred Twelve he dyed,
And for the Poor did christianly provide,
According to the Talent God had lent,
Five Pounds he gave, of Zeale and good Intent:
The Fruit makes known the Nature of the Tree,
Good Life the Christian, even so was he;
Whose Time well spent, unto his Soule did gain
The heavenly Rest, where holy Saints remain.
This Memory a lovynge Wife, unto her Husband gave,
To shew her Hart remembers him, though Death inclosed his Grave;
The Gift he gave unto the Poor, she hath enlarged the same,
With Five Pounds added to the Five, unto her Christian Fame,
Hath placed them both to the Churchmen here, no wise to be delay'd,
But that yearly to the Poor of Cumnor, be a Mark of Silver paid;
Which is the full appointed Rent of the whole bequeathed Somme,
In Cumnor, for the Poores Relief, Margery Welsh doth will
The Charge of this, when she is dead, may be performed still.
DIV2.P: On the South Side of the Church is an Isle, and therin are 2 Arches m the Wall, which I suppose were the Sepultures of the ancient Lords hereof.
The North Isle is dedicated to St. Tho∣mas, and the South Isle to St. Catherine.

At the West End of the Church is the Ruins of a Manor anciently belonging (as a Cell, or Place of Removal, as some re∣port) to the Monks of Abington. At the Dissolution, the said Manor, or Lordship, was conveyed to one......Owen (I believe) the Possessor of Godstow then.

In the Hall over the Chimney I find Abington Arms cut in Stone, viz. A Patonee between 4 Martletts; and also another Escotcheon, viz. A Lion Ram∣pant, and several Miters cut in Stone a∣bout the House. There is also in the said House, a Chamber called Dudley's Chamber, where the Earl of Leicester's Wife was murder'd; of which this is the Story following.

Robert Dudley, Earl of Leicester, a ve∣ry goodly Personage, and singularly well Featur'd, being a great Favourite to Queen Elizabeth, it was thought, and commonly reportted, that had he been a Batchelor, or Widower, the Queen would
have made him her Husband; to this End, to free himself of all Obstacles, he commands, or perhaps, with fair flatter∣ing Intreaties, desires his Wife to repose her self here, at his Servant, Anthony For∣ster's House, who then lived in the afore∣said Manor House; and also prescribed to Sir Richard Varney, (a prompter to this Design) at his coming hither, that he should first attempt to poison her, and if that did not take effect, then by any other Way whatsoever to dispatch her. This, it seems, was proved by the Report of Dr. Walter Bayly, sometime Fellow of New College, then living in Oxford, and Professor of Physick in that University; who, because he would not consent to take away her Life by Poison, the Earl endeavour'd to displace him from the Court. This Man, it seems, reported for most certain, that there was a Practice in Cumnor among the Conspirators, to have poisoned this poor innocent Lady, a little before she was killed, which was attempt∣ed after this manner. They seeing the good Lady sad and heavy (as one that well knew by her other handling, that her Death was not far off) began to perswade her, that her present Disease was abun∣dance of Melancholy, and other Humours, &c. and therefore would needs counsel
her to take some Potion, which she abso∣lutely refusing to do, as still suspecting the worst; whereupon they sent a Messenger on a Day (unawares to her) for Dr. Bayly, and intreated him to perswade her to take some little Potion by his Di∣rection, and they would fetch the same at Oxford, meaning to have added some∣thing of their own for her Comfort, as the Doctor, upon just Cause and Considerati∣on did suspect, seeing their great Impor∣tunity, and the small need the Lady had of Physick, and therefore he peremptori∣ly denied their Request, misdoubting (as he afterwards reported) least if they had poison'd her under the Name of his Poti∣on, he might after have been hanged for a Colour of their Sin; and the Doctor remain'd still well assured, that this Way taking no Effect, she would not long escape their Violence, which afterwards happened thus. For Sir Richard Varney abovesaid (the chief Projector in this De∣sign) who by the Earl's Order remain'd that Day of her Death alone with her, with one Man only, and Forster, who had that Day forcibly sent away all her Servants from her to Abington Market, about 3 Miles distant from this Place, they (I say, whether first stifling her, or else strangling her) afterwards flung her down
a pair of Stairs, and broke her Neck, using much Violence upon her; but however, though it was vulgarly reported that she by chance fell down Stairs (but yet with∣out hurting her Hood that was upon her Head) yet the Inhabitants will tell you there, that she was conveyed from her usual Chamber where she lay, to another where the Beds Head of the Chamber stood close to a privy Postern Door, where they in the Night came and stifled her in her Bed, bruised her Head very much, broke her Neck, and at length flung her down Stairs, thereby believing the World would have thought it a mischance, and so have blinded their Villany. But be∣hold the Mercy and Justice of God, in re∣venging and discovering this Lady's Mur∣der; for one of the Persons, that was a Coadjutor in this Murder, was after∣wards taken for a Felony in the Marches of Wales, and offering to publish the Man∣ner of the aforesaid Murder, was private∣ly made away in the Prison by the Earl's appointment. And Sir Richard Varney, the other, dying about the same Time in London, cried miserably, and blasphemed God, and said to a Person of Note (who hath related the same to others since) not long before his Death, that all the De∣vils in Hell did tear him in Pieces. For∣ster
likewise after this Fact, being a Man formerly addicted to Hospitality, Com∣pany, Mirth, and Musick, was after∣wards observed to forsake all this with much Melancholy and Pensiveness (some say with Madness) pin'd and droop'd a∣way. The Wife also, of Bald Butter, Kinsman to the Earl, gave out the whole Fact a little before her Death. Neither are these following Passages to be forgot∣ten, That as soon as ever she was mur∣dered, they made great hast to bury her, before the Coroner had given in his In∣quest, (which the Earl himself condemn∣ed as not done advisedly) which her Fa∣ther, or Sir John Robertsett (as I suppose) hearing of, came with all speed hither, caused her Corps to be taken up, the Co∣roner to sit upon her, and further Enqui∣ry to be made concerning this Business to the full, but it was generally thought, that the Earl stopped his Mouth, and made up the Business betwixt them, and the good Earl, to make plain to the World, the great Love he bare to her while alive, what a Grief the Loss of so Virtuous a Lady was to his tender Heart; caused (though the Thing by these, and other means, was beaten into the Heads of the principal Men of the University of Ox∣ford) her Body to be re-buried in, St.Ma∣ries
Church in Oxford, with great Pomp, and Solemnity. It is remarkable, when Dr. Babington (the Earl's Chaplain) did preach the Funeral Sermon, he tript once or twice in his Speech, by recommending to their Memories that virtuous Lady so pitifully murder'd, instead of saying piti∣fully slain. This Earl, after all his Mur∣ders and Poisonings, was himself poison∣ed by that which was prepared for others (some say by his Wife) at Cornbury Lodge, before mention'd (though Baker in his Chronicle would have it at Killingworth) Anno 1588.

DIV2.HEAD: South HINXSEY,
DIV2.P: So called to distinguish it from Laurence Hinxsey adjoyning, is a Chapel of Ease to Cumnor, and lyes on the Borders of this County, about 2 Miles from Oxford.
In the Chancel, on a fair Monument, is this Epitaph.

Q.P:
Reader, look to thy Feet, For good and just Men must fall. Here lyes William Finmore, L. L. B. and Fellow of St. John's College in Oxon.
who in the Yeare
of his Age 87.
of our Lord 46.
When Loyalty and the Church fainted, lay down and died.

Here lyes William, his only Child, who married first Katherine, by whom he had Ann, John, Mary, William, and Richard deceased; and after a 5 Years Widdowhood, He marryed Martha Mayot, of Abingdon, Widdow, of the antient Family of the Wicchams, who brought him Elianor and Thomas, and built him this Monument. He dyed June the iiid, MDCLXXVII, aged about 83 Years. Goe Reader and prepare to follow.

DIV2.HEAD: BESSILS-LEIGH,
DIV2.P:
Lyes about a Mile from Cumnor, in the same Hundred and Deanery, and is so called from the antient Family of the Be∣sills, joyned to the antient Name of Leigh, one of whom was High-Sheriff of this County in 1431. Upon failure of Male Issue of this Line, it came to the Fetiplaces, one of which Line, Besill Fetiplace, was High-Sheriff of this County in 1583. Ma∣ny Years after it was purchased by that weak Tool of a rebellious Parliament-William
Lenthall, Esq; Speaker,) who at his Death was an eminent Instance of sin∣cere Repentance, when he signed a Re∣cantation and Abhorrence of his former Errors, which in some Measure may be rather imputed to his Folly, than any ill Design: From him in the Third Genera∣tion, it came to the present Possessor, and Lord of the Manor, John Lenthall, Es{que} In this House was preserved a Picture of Sir Thomas More, Kt. and his Family, drawn by the Hand of the celebrated Hans Holben, which is now removed to his Seat, the Priory of Burford, in Oxfordshire, and is by length of Time, and Negligence, much decayed. Of this Family hangs the fol∣lowing Pedigree on the South Side of the Altar in St. George's Church in Southwark.

ROW.CELL: Frances, Daughter of Sir Richard Southwell, Widow of William Lenthall, Es{que} Father and Mother of Sir John Lenthall. She was here buried the 20th of May, 1643.
Sir John Lenthall, of this Parish, Kt. and Marshall of the King's Bench, who hath Issue by his Wife 6 Sonnes and 8 Daughters, both living, An. 1643.
Bridget, Daughter of Sir Tho∣mas Temple, of Stow in Com. Bucks, Kt. and Baronet, Wife to Sir John Lenthall, Kt. is now living.
Edmund Lenthall, Es{que} Son and Heir of Sir John, marr. Elizab. Daughter of Sir Will. Wade, Kt. Lieutnant of the Tower, and are both living, An. 1643.
Tho. Lenthall, second Son of Sir John Lenthall, is living, 1643.
William Lenthall, 3d Son of Sir John Len∣thall, was here buried, Octob. 11. 1636.
Peever, and John Len∣thall, Twins, Sons of Sir John Lenthall, Kt. di∣ed in their Childhood.
John Lenthall, 6th Son of Sir John Lenthall, Kt. was buried Sept. 7. 1643.
Helter, eldest Daugh∣ter of Sir John Len∣thall, Kt. is living, 1643.
Katheren, 2d Daugh∣ter of Sir John Len∣thall, Kt. is living, 1643.
Elizabeth, 3d Daughter of Sir John Lenthall, Kt. Wife to Hen∣ry Gylburne, of Woledge in Kent. Es{que} and are living, 1643.
Frances, 4th Daughter of Sir John Lenthall, Kt. is living, 1643.
Bridget, 5th Daughter of Sir John Lenthall, Kt. was here buried, Feb. 9. l635.
Martha, 6th Daughter of Sir John Lenthall, Kt. Wife to Rich. Wel∣bore, of London, living, 1643.
Susan, 7th Daugh. of Sir John Lenthall, Kt. Wife to Leon. Lydcott, Es{que} living, An. 1643.
Mary, the youngest Daugh∣ter of Sir John Lenthall, Kt. is living, 1643.
John, the 2d Son of Ed∣mund Lenthall, Es{que} was here buried, May, 14. 1641.
Bridget, the Daughter of Ed∣mond Lenthall, Es{que} here buried, Aug. 7. 1641.
Katherine, the Daugh∣ter of Hen. Gylburne, Es{que} was here buried.

DIV2.P: Upon the South Wall of the Chancel is this Epitaph.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet GULIELMUS LENTHALL, filius tertius GULIELMI LENTHALL, Armigeri, obiit 3°. Julii, An°. Domini, MDCXXXIX.
DIV2.P: Over the Entrance into the Chancel is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: This Church was restored in the Yeare MDCXXXII. and repaired by the Ho∣nourable William Lenthall, Master of the Rolls, MDCLVII.
DIV2.P: This is a Vicaridge, and the Incumbent is the Reverend Mr. Bromwich.

DIV2.HEAD: GANFEILD Hundred. LONGWORTH,
DIV2.P: Is a Rectory in the Deanery of Abing∣ton, and the Advowson was purchased by Jesus College in Oxford.
In the middle of the Chancel, under the Figure of a Man in the Habit of the Times, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Magister Johannes He∣nele, apud Henele oriundus, Rec∣tor nuper istius Ecclesie de Long∣worth, qui obiit secundo die Men∣lis Novembr. An°. Domini, MCCCCXXII. Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: On another Brass Plate set in a Grave∣stone, lying on the South Side of the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Of your Charity pray for the Soule of John Yate, Merchant of the Stapull at Calais, and Johanne his Wife, the which John deceased the..... day of...... in the Yeare of our Lord, MD..... The said Johan decessyd the XIVth Day of Aprill, MDIX.
DIV2.P: Vnder this Inscription are the Fi∣gures of Seven Sons and Eight Daughters in winding Sheets.
On the North Side of the High Altar is a Marble, and thereon a Brass Plate, having the Figure of a Woman, with this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Under this Stone lyes buried Elynur Goodolphyn, Gentylwo∣man, who departed out of thys wretched Worlde, the XIIth Day of January, Anno MDLXVI. to whom wee beseech thee blessed Trinity grant a joyfull Resurrec∣tion.
DIV2.P: In the Chapel, on the North Side of the Chancel, is a Monument erected against the Wall, bearing this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Sir HENRY MARTEN, Knight. Dr. of the Lawes, Judge of the High Court of Admirallty, and of the Prerogative Court of Canterbury, and twice Deane of the Arches, who departed this Lyfe the xxvith of September, A°. Domini, MDCXLI. in the Yeare of his Age 81.
DIV2.P: Written at the bottom of this Monu∣ment.
DIV2.Q: For whose Memory Mrs. MARGARET MARTEN hath erected this Monument over her deceased Father in Law's Grave.
DIV2.P: In the East Wall of the said Chapel, is another Monument erected, bearing the Pourtraiture of a Woman kneeling at a Desk, and under her the Statues of two Sons and three Daughters kneeling also before another Desk, and above her Head is the following Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Dominae ELIZABETHAE MARTIN, Ux∣ori HENRICI MARTIN, Militis, Pa∣troni hujus Ecclesiae, & Domini hujus Manerii, Faemina in Deum pietate, in omnes morum suavitate, in virum a∣more singulari, quo cum conjunctissime vixit viginti annos & decem menses, & ex eo peperit duos filios HENRICUM & GEORGIUM, & tres filias, ELIZA∣BETHAM, JANAM, & MARIAM. HENRICUS MARTIN. N. H. M. L. M. Q. P.
DIV2.P: Written under the Pourtraitures of the Children this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Obiit anno aetatis suae 44. decimo nono die mensis Junii, MDCXVIII. Cujus memoriae hoc sacrum Elogium, H. filius merito maerens consecravit.

Q.L: Stay Passenger, and if thou art not Stone,
Weepe with Eurania, whose Nymph is gone,
A Nymph, whome thou wouldst sweare had been the same,
Divine Eurania, but for her Name.
And yet her Name, her Nature well exprest,
That in God's Temple built her carefull Nest,
Thither to fly, that shee the easier may
Her young ones teach, her self (loe) leades the way.

DIV2.P: On a Brass Plate, in a Grave-stone at the West End of the aforesaid North Isle, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of Mrs. DOROTHY WILSON, the Wife of TIMOTHY WILSON, who dyed in Childbirth the xxiith of June, MDCXXII.
DIV2.P:
In the Body of the Church is a Grave-stone laid, whereon in a Brass Plate, are
the Representations of a Man and Wo∣man in Winding Sheets open at the Head, and at their Feet the following Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth Ricard Yate, and Johane hys Wyfe, the which Richard de∣ceased the xiith Day of March, in the Yeare of our Lord, MCCCCXCVIII. And the said Johane decessyd the viith Day of March, in the Yere of our Lord, MD. On whose Soules God have Mercy. Amen.
DIV2.P: Under the Epitaph are the Figures of seven Sons and seven Daughters, repre∣sented also in Winding Sheets.
Present Incumbent is Mr. David Gwynne.

DIV2.HEAD: BUCKLAND,
DIV2.P: Is a Vicaridge in the Deanery of A∣bington, and Mr. H. Barrow is Incumbent.
In the North and South Windows of the Chancel are these Coats of Arms, viz.
Or, on a Cross, Gules, 5 Roses Argent.
Gules, 3Lions Pass. Argent.
Vert. 6 Fleurs de lis, Or.
Erm. 2 Barrs, Gules, on a chief of the second, a Lion Pass. Guard. Or.

About the middle of the Chancel there is a fair Arch cut in the North Wall, in which lies a raised Grave-stone, and there∣on a Cross embossed.
Opposite thereunto, is a like Arch cut in the South Wall, but the Grave-stone laid therein is plain, and without a Cross.
Engraven on a Marble Stone, set in the Wall under the South Window of the South Cross:

DIV2.Q: Credimus quod spiritus ejus qui suscita∣vit Jesum, &c. Rom. 8.

Q.P: Ecce ego dominus aperiam tumulos, ve∣stros, &c. Ezech. 37.
Omnis qui vidit filium, &c. credit in eum, Joh.
Credimus quod Redemptor, &c. surrecturi sumus in carne nostra, &c. Job 19.

DIV2.P: In a Monument raised in the middle of the North Cross, are the Pourtraitures in Plates of Brass, of a Man in a Gown, and his Wife in the Habit of her Times, under whose Feet is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Bodies of John Yate, Esquire, late Lord of this Towne; and of Mary his Wife, Daughter and Heire to William Justice, late of Reading, in the County of Berkshire, Es{que} which John and Mary had betweene them 5 Sons and 7 Daughters, and the said John being of the Age of 66▪ changed this Lyfe the xxvith of January, An°. Domini, MDLXXVIII. And Mary his Wife decessed the......... of ......MD......
DIV2.P: Underneath are the Pourtraitures in Gowns of the five Sons and seven Daugh∣ters.
At the four Corners of this Monument are these Arms.
1. Yate impal. a Chev. Verney between 3 Cressents.
2. Yate impal. 2 Chev. on the first a Spot or Point of Erm. quartering a Goat's Head eras. between 3 Cocks.
3. Yate quartering the Chev. and Cress. impaling on a Fess ingr. between 2 Bar∣rulets 3 Cressents.
4. Yate quart. the Chev. and Cress. im∣pal. 2 Chev. in Fess a Cress.
Under this is a large Blue Marble Stone, round the Verge thereof is a French In∣scription in a Saxon Character, but most part of it is hidden by the last mentioned.
Under the Window, in the North Cross, is a Black and White Marble Monument erected, bearing this Inscription.

Q.P: In pious Memory of Sir EDWARD YATE, Baronet, Patron of this Church, and Lord of this Mannor, here with his Auncestors, the Lady KATHERINE his Wife, and ELIZABETH their Daugh∣ter enterred. He took to Wife KA∣THERINE Daughter of Sir JOHN BA∣KER of Sisinghurst, in the County of Kent, Knight; both lived Examples of conjugall, paternall, maternall, and religious Vertues, died Christianly. Were blest with Children worthy such Parents.
Sir JOHN YATE, Knight and Baronet, who married MARY, Daughter and Coheire of JOHN PAKINGTON, of Chadsey-Corbet in the County of Wor∣cester, Es{que}
This small Monument, instead of a great∣ter deserved, further presents thee with his Praise and thy Instruction, in these following Lines.

Q.L: Eccle∣siastes. The Fame of them who just and righteous live, c. 7.
Eccle∣siastes. Excells the Odor sweetest Ointments give. v. 1.

DIV2.HEAD: At the bottom of the Monument.

Q.P:
And,
In this black Marble, that each Sex may finde
White and faire Presidents to guide the Minde. Men, Women, know, remember.
The Baronet was particularly honoured for moral, Oeconomicall, prudentiall Meritt.
The Lady was reverenced for sanctimonious Zeale, humble and constant Patience, aboundant Charity and admirable Justice.
Their Daughter Elizabeth (who dyed a Maid, her Parents living) beloved, admired for devote, chast, modest and discreete demeanour, and fervent Charitie. Reader depart, imitate. MDCXLVIII.

DIV2.P: Over all, Yate quartering, 1. a Chev. between 3 Cressants. 2. A Fess ingrail. 2 Barrulets, over all a impal. 3 Swans Heads erased; the Crest is a Goat's Head erased, issuing out of a Crown; about his Neck .

WISEMAN, of Stevention, in the County of Berks, Es{que} THOMAS, who married MARY the Daughter of Sir WILL. GARDINER of....... in the County of Surry, Knight. ANNE, the Wife of ED∣WARD YEARBURIE, of Troobridge, in the County of Wilts, Es{que} JANE the Wife of WILLIAM FISHER, of Liding∣ton, in the County of Wilts, Es{que} and CHRISTIAN, the Wife of CHARLES TOOKER, of Abingdon, in the County of Berks, Doctor of the Civil Laws. RICHARD deceased the xvith of June, in the first Yeare of King James, and JANE deceased the ivth of September, MDCXLVIII.

Q.P: M. S.

Maijor Dunch, Armiger, duabus haud minus antiquis, quam Generosis oriun∣dus families: Altera Dunchiorum hoc in Comitatu, in vicino Hampton Mai∣jorum altera, utraque longum tam ani∣mi dotibus quam fortunae donis specta∣bilis: quarem nec alteri facultates saeculi vitus imminuit, nec alterutri∣morum elegantia concessit; sed & utri∣usque virtutes ultra provexit: Literis politioribus, Latinis, Graecis, Hebraeis, aliisque Orientalibus, instituente Hum∣fredo Guntero & Rob. Lancaster Conquisitis; Historiae, Legumque pro∣vinciis proprio Marte superatis, utram∣que
que ornatiorem reddidit, & conjugio cum Honor atissimi Philippi Dom. Whar∣ton Baronis filia natu secunda (tantis vere digna natalibus) contracto, pa∣ternam domum posteris nobilitatam tra∣didit. Heroinam istam binis licet na∣tabus iisque formosissimis; filio etiam parvulo amplissimi plane patrimonii haerede, gaudentem tam tum matrem, atque altero etiamnum feracis uteri onere gravidam, quo sponsa tamen a∣mantior fuerat chariorque, maestiorem eo viauam reliquit amantissimus pari∣terque ac charissimus conjux: quippe quem majore multo suffragiorum numero dilectum, ut celebris municipii Aben∣donensis vice, de arduis regni negotiis, in proximo Parliamento consuleret, Deo Opt. Max. amicis solum malignae, fa∣ventioris ipsimet febris praecepto, in au∣gustiorem longe conventum, universa∣lem scilicet primogenitorum, qui in coelis conscribuntur (nunquam dirimendum prorogandum nunquam) concionem, se∣ligere visum est, & vocare XXVII. die Sept. An°. Aerae Christianae, MDCLXXIX. Aetatis XXIX. Monumentum Marito Optimae Maestissima Condidit vidua, M. D. Epitaphium moriens posuit. T. G.

DIV2.P: Over the outside Door leading into the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: WILLIAM WHITE. God that sent him into the World, May xxi. MDCLI. said, May x. MDCLV. returne thou Son of Sorry∣man, Psalm 90. 3.
DIV2.P: On the South Side of the Church-yard stands a raised Monument of Free Stone, to the Side whereof is fixed a Brass Plate, and thereon the following Inscription.
DIV2.Q: RICHARD PUSEY, alias PEASEY, PESCOD, PECOD, having in his Lyfe Time received whole Christ, that is, not only as a Prophet and Priest, but as Lord and King too, in this true justi∣fying Faith, dyed most comfortably, Aug. the iid. A. D. MDLIII. Aetat..... Relicta PJunii 30mo. MDCLVI.

DIV2.HEAD: HATFORD,
DIV2.P: Is a Rectory in the Hundred of Ganfield, and Deanery of Abington, Patron John Jennings, Es{que} Incumbent Mr. Col∣lier.

Within an Arch cut into the North Wall, lyes a Statue of a Man of Free Stone, holding an Heart between his Hands, and his Feet resting upon a Hound. He is habited in a short Coat, reaching but to his Knees, and the Sleeves thereof no lower than his Elbows.
Near to the aforesaid Monument lyes a Blue Marble Grave-stone, and thereon fixed a Brass Plate, containing the follow∣ing Epitaph.
DIV2.Q: Here lies buried the Body of FRANCIS PIGGOTT, Esquire, Son and Heir of ROBERT PIGGOTT, of Colwick in the County of Bucks, Esquire. He mar∣ried MARGARET, one of the Daugh∣ters of ALBAN BUTLER, of Aston in the Woldes, in the County of Nor∣thampton, Esq; by whome he had Yssue 7 Sonns and 3 Daughters. He decea∣sed the 3d Day of December, An°. Domini, MDCXIV. Aetatis suae 68.
DIV2.P: On another Grave-stone adjoyning to the former, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: MARGARET, Wife of FRANCIS PIGGOTT, Es{que} was buried, Jan. xxx. MDCXXXVII.
DIV2.P: On another Grave-stone next the lat∣ter, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: MARTHA, Wife of ALBAN PIGGOTT, Es{que} buried, Febr. xii. MDCXXIX.

DIV2.HEAD: STANFORD,
DIV2.P: Is in the Hundred of Ganfield, and Deanery of Abington, in the Patronage of the Dean and Chapter of Westminster. Incumbent Mr. Hutton.
Upon the South Wall of the Chancel is erected a Monument, with this follow∣ing Epitaph on it.
DIV2.Q: Neere to this Place lyeth the Body of Captain FRANCIS KNOLLYS, Son of RICHARD KNOLLYS, Esq; Brother to the late Earle of Banbury, who first married one of the Daughters of Sir Charles wiseman, of this County, and after her decease, ALICE, Sister of Sir WILLIAM BEECHER, of Middlesex, by whome he left one Daughter and two Sons; and was, by Death, taken from the Command of the Traine Band of Abingdon Division, and here inter∣red the ivth of Aug. MDCXL.

Q.L: When Stones breake Sylence, and Attention crave,
Well may't be thought some wonder in the Grave.
Reader, then stay, and marvel not if I
[Though Stone] relate what rare thing here doth lye.
That noble Name was his thou readest before,
Able it self to guild the Title o'er.
That Valour does but sleepe within the Bed,
Which never [but by Death] was captive lead;
Whose lingring, slow, and coward like delay,
Argued her feare of loosing of the Day.
Since when, this Place, more then a Grave shall be,
Where his Bones are, 'tis an Artillery.
Thus I him praise, whose Merit might deny
The poor Applause of funeral Obsequie;
But Custome so prevailes, it is but just
To pollish Diamonds with their owne Dust.

DIV2.P: On a fair Black Marble laid over a raised Monument, erected against the a∣foresaid South Wall of the Chancel, is this Inscription.

Q.P: JOHN HEIGHAM, Esquire; late Mar∣shall of the Hall to King James, and King Charles, Son of JOHN HEIGHAM, of Suffolke, departed this Lyfe the twentyth Day of March, MDCXXXII.

He was a Man respective to his Superiours, courteous, kinde, and loving to his Inferiours, and affable to all Men, and a good Benefactor to the Poore
of the Parish of Stanford, where he lived, and where he now is interred.

Q.L: Not that he needed Monument of Stone,
For his well gotten Fame to rest upon;
But this was rear'd, to testifie that he
Lives in their loves, that yet surviving be;
For unto Vertue, who first raised his Name,
He left the Presentation of the same;
And to Posterity remaine it shall,
When Brass, and Marble Monuments shall fall.

DIV2.P: Near the middle of the Chancel lies a Blue Marble, bearing the Figure of an Ecclesiastick, Breast high, in his Priestly Habit, under which is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Rogerus Campden, quondam Rector hujus Gcclesse, qui obiit tertio die Mensis Junii, Anno Domini, MCCCXCVIII. Cujus anime propicietur Deus. Amen.
DIV2.P: At the Four Corners of this Grave-stone are fixed Brass Plates, whereon are engraven the Emblematical Resemblan∣ces of the four Evangelists.

DIV2.HEAD: SHILLINGFORD,
DIV2.P: Is a Rectory in the Hundred of Gan∣field, and Deanery of Abington Patron is Mr. Packer; and Incumbent Mr. Carter.
In the Body of the Church, near the entrance into the Chancel, lyes a Grave-stone, whereon have been fixed the Fi∣gures of a Man and a Woman in Brass (now stollen away) at whose Feet is this Epitaph.

Q.L: William Blebury, & Isabel sa feme giserit ici,
Dieu pour sa grace de leurs ame eit merci:
Qui pont lour almes et lour enfantz prieront,
Mil et trent jours de pardon averont.

DIV2.P: Under the North Window of the Chan∣cel is a Monument somewhat raised from the Ground, whereon is laid a very fair and large Stone, upon which, in Brass Plates, is the Figure of a Priest, vested in his Habit, within an Arch of Ta∣bernacle Work very curiously wrought. The Verge of the Marble is also lined with Brass, and thereon is circumscribed this Epitaph.

Q.L: De terre fu feat et fourme, Johan.
de Bleobury, jadys nome, Et entere su retourne,
L'an grace bien accompte, Mil trois cent
Septante seconde, en mois de Marz
qui bien lesponde le vint et septisme jour prove.
Que Dieu de salme eit pitie. Amen.

DIV2.P: In the Glass Window over the said Mo∣nument, is the Picture of the said John Bleobury, in a Red Gown, and Purple Hood, Kneeling, and under this, Pro Anima Johannis Bleburi Pater noster.
In the said North Wall of the Chan∣cel is a Monument erected with this In∣scription.
DIV2.Q:
M. S. D. EDOVARDI NEVILL, Armig. ex flexuosa stemmatis Nobiliter vetusti serie Progerminati: cui pater D. HENRICUS NEVILL, Eques, Auratus, extraordinaria Reginae Elizab. ad Henricum IV. Gall. Regem Legatione perhonorifice functus aliam Musarum & Encyclopaeaicam Nobilitatem, adserentis inter Regalis Collegii Cantabrigiensis
sodales, unius quondam meritissimi ad blandiorem prolificamque Conjugii sodalitatem, prolecti tandem festivo cuniculo ad Augustiorem adhuc atque insolubilem beatae aeternitatis Societatem evecti. Anno Aetatis 30 Christi, MDCXXXII. Hoc Uxoriae & obstinatae posthumiae Charitatis symbolum devotissimum maerens maerenti, P. ALICIA Uxor ejus.
DIV2.P: In the Church-yard, on the South Side of the Chancel, is a raised Monument of Free Stone, on the Side whereof is this Epitaph engraven.
DIV2.Q: ALICIA CLAYTON, the loving Wife of RICHARD CLAY∣TON, Rector of this Church, to whome she left 2 Sons, JOHN and THOMAS, having given a good example of Chri∣stian Piety, of conjugal Affection, and of neighbourly Charity, lyeth hereby interred, expecting for Christ's sake a Resurrection to Glory. Dum nos intestino bello cruciamur, pacatam mortem illi donavit, quem semper coluit crucifixus. Sept. v. MDCXLIII.
DIV2.P: Engraven on the other Side of the Tomb this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Remains of Mrs. DOROTHY CLAYTON, who governed her Brother's House 15 Yeares discreetely, shewed a Mother-like Care and Love to his Children; for her Piety, Courtesie, Modesty, Humility, she was beloved of God, and of all that knew her. She departed this Lyfe in the true Faith of Christ, Oct. viii. MDCLVIII.
DIV2.P: At the Foot of the Monument is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: John Clayton, optimae spei Juvenis Richardi filius innocentem Animam suo reddidit Coelo, Oxonii Quintilis duodecimo, An°. Salutis, MDCLXI. Aetatis vicesimo.
DIV2.P: On a Stone lying at the Foot of the said Monument is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: JOHANNES CLAYTON, Artium Baccalaureus, MDCLXI. Terrae, Terrae, fide Caeli.

DIV2.HEAD: FARINGDON Hundred.
DIV2.Q: On the Western Side of this County lyes FARINGDON, or Farrendon,
DIV2.P: Which is pleasantly situated on an Eminence. In it was formerly a Fortress built by Robert Earl of Gloucester, during the Usurpation of Stephen Earl of Bloys, who after some Opposition' took it, and levelled it with the Ground. In 1202. The Usurper founded a Priory of Cisterti∣an Monks, subject to the Abby of Bealieu in Hampshire. This, with the Castle, are entirely ruined; nor are there remaining the smallest Relicts of their former Gran∣deur. This Church is a large, handsome Structure, in which are the several follow∣ing Monuments.
In an Isle, or Chapel on the North Side, commonly called Unton's Isle, under which is a Vault where several of the Family have been interred.

On a Marble Grave-stone lying in the middle of the said Isle, are Three Figures in Brass Plates, of a Man armed, and two
Women holding up their Hands in a de∣votional Posture, and under their Feet is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Orate pro animabus Thome Ffa∣ryndon, Armigeri, quondam Do∣mini de Farneham, & de Lusteshull, qui obiit secundo die Febr. An°. Domini, MCCCXCVI. Marga∣rete Vxoris ejus que obiit secundo die Maii, Anno Domini, MCCCCII. & Katerine Pynchepole, filie & her▪. predictorum Thome & Margarete, que obiit XI die Decemb. A°. Dom. MCCCCXLIII. Quorum ani∣mabus propicietur Deus. We pray you in the Worchip of the Trinity for our Sowles sey Pa∣ter and Ave.
DIV2.P: In the same Chapel, under the North Window, is a fair railed Monument of Grey Marble, on which is fastened a Brass Place with this following Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Here under lyeth Sir Alexander Unton, Knight; Mary, and Ladye Cecill his Wyfes, which Alexander decessed the XVI Day of December, MDXLVII. in the first Yeare of our Soveraigne Lord King Ed∣ward
the Sixt. On whose Soule, and all Cristen Soules, Ihesu have Mercy. Amen.
DIV2.P: Over it a Man kneeling between two Women; on each of their Vests their Coats of Armour.
DIV2.Q: On the Man's are,
DIV2.P: Bl. on a Fess ingr. Or, a Greyhound cur∣rent Sab. between 3 half Lances, with their Points upwards, Arg.—Unton quartering, Gules. 2 Chev. Arg. on the first a Point of Erm. a Martlet for a differ.
DIV2.Q: On one Woman's Coat,
DIV2.P: —Unton quartering Feteplace, im∣paling Arg. a Cross ingrail. Gul. between 4 Water Bougets, quartering Gules, Billety and a Fess, Or.
DIV2.Q: On the other Wife's Coat,
DIV2.P: —Unton quart. Feteplace, impaling Bulstrode, quartering, (1.) Erm. 2 Horse Barnacles, Gules, a Chief Paly. (2.) On a Chev. Gul. between 3 Squirrells Sab.

Behind the Man are the Figures of 7 Sons; and behind one of the Wives are three Daughters. At the Corners,
Bouchier impaling, Gules, a Bend be∣tween 6 Cross Croslets Arg.
Unton impaling Bouchier.
Unton quartering Feteplace.
The same as the last again.

Under the aforesaid Light, near the for∣mer, on a raised Alabaster Mnument, are the Proportions of a Man and Woman lying along, holding up their Hands in a devout Posture of Prayer, and on the Verge is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth Sir THOMAS UNTON, Knight, and Dame ELIZABETH his Wife.
At the Bottom are these Arms,
DIV2.P: Unton quartering Feteplace, impal. bl. 3 Griffins Ramp. Arg.
Unton quartering Feteplace.
Against the East Wall of the said Cha∣pel is erected a very fair arched Monument of Marble, at the Bottom of which is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Here lyeth Sir EDWARD UNTON, Knight of the Noble Order of the Bath, who married ANNE, Countess of War∣wick, Daughter to EDWARD SEY∣MER, Duke of Somerset, and Protector
of England, by whome he had five Sons, whereof 3 died young in the Life of their father; 2, namely, EDWARD and HEN∣RY, only survived, and succeded him, the one after the other, in their Father's Inheritance: And two Daughters, ANNE married to Sir VALENTINE KNIGHTLEY, Knight; and SCISSILL married to JOHN WENTWORTH, Esq;

DIV2.HEAD: Over it are these Arms.
DIV2.P: Unton impaling Bulstrode.
Unton impaling Bouchier.

Unton quartering, (1.) Feteplace. (2.) Bl. 3 Griffins Ramp. Arg. (3.) Gul. on a Bend Arg. 5 Birds Sable. (4.) Gules, a Fess between 3 Right Hands couped, Arg. (5.) The same as the first, impaling Sey∣mer, a Pale with Lyons and Fleurs de Lis, quartering, (1.) Gules, 2 Wings, Or, (2.) Verry, Arg. bl. (3.) Arg. 3 Demy Lions, Ramp. Gules. (4.) Per Bend Arg. and Gul. 3 Roses in Bend counter changed. (5.) Arg. on a Bend, Gul. 3 Lions Faces, Or.
Oudley with quarterings impaling Sey∣mer with quarterings, as before.

Seymer with quarterings, impaling quar∣terly.... quartering, (1.) Vert. 3 Grey∣hounds current, Or. (2.) Sab. a Bend
between 6 Cross Crosslets, Arg. (3.) Arg. 3 Saltiers ingrail. Sab. a Cress. in Fess Point.
Over it in a Lozenge, Seymer with quar∣terings.
On one side, Unton impaling bl. a Chev. between 3 Lozenges, Or.
On the other side, Seymer impaling Went∣worth.
Over all Unton with quarterings, and Crest.
At the Sides of the Monuments are Supporters, viz. an Unicorn Arg. and a Bull bl. gorged with a Crown, Or.
On a Tablet hanging on the West Wall of the same Chapel, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Virtuti & Honori Sacrum HENRICO UNTONO Equiti aurato, EDWARDI UNTONI Equitis aurati filio, ex ANNA Comitissa Warwici, filia EDOVARDI, de Sco. MAURO Ducis Somersetti, & Anglioe Protectoris. qui optimarum artium studiis, a prima aetate, in Academia Oxon enutritus, magnam Orbis Christiani partem perlustravit, ob Virtutem bellicam in Zutphaniae obsidione, dignitate Equestri donatus, propter singularem
prudentiam, spectatam fidem, & multiplicem rerum usum, iterum Legatus a Serenissima Angliae Regina, ad Christianissimum Regem missus in Galliam, a qua ad Coelestem patriam emigravit 23 die Martii, Anno Salutis, MDXCVI. DOROTHEA Uxor charissima filia charissimi viri THOMAE WROUGHTON ex Equestri ordine, quae maximo cum luctu Corpus huc transferrendum curavit, in mutui amoris, & conjugalis fidei Testimonium hoc Monumentum maestissima posuit, MDCVI.
DIV2.P: In the Year 1658. this last Stone was put up, because the former was pulled down in the Civil Wars, about the Year 1643.

DIV2.HEAD: Over it are these Arms.
DIV2.P: Unton impaling, Arg. a Chev. Gules, between 3 Boars Heads couped, Sab.— Wroughton.
On a Brass Plate fixed to a Grave-stone placed in the middle of the Chancel, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Ricardus Lenton, quon∣dam hujus Ecclesie Wicarius, qut plura bona huic Ecclese appropri∣ari fecit & procurabit, & obiit II die Mensis Septemb. A°. Domini, MCCCCX. Orate pro anima ejus.
DIV2.P: On a Shield hung up here are three Coats parted per Pale, viz.
(1.) Unton. (2.) Wroughton. (3.) Shirley, with the diff. of a Baronet.
On a larger Marble Grave-stone, in the East Part of the North Isle, (called Playdell's Isle) is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet TOBIAS PLAYDELL, Armiger, & ELIANORA, Uxor ejus, qu quidem Tobias obiit decimo octavo die Octobris, Anno Domini, Millessimo Quingentssimo octogesimo tertio. Beati qui moriuntur in Domino.
DIV2.P: In the North Wall of the Isle is a fair Black Marble Monument, and thereon is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Nescis qua hora, vigila.
DIV2.P: On a Tablet hung up is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: William Lee, late of Abingdon, Berks, Gent. by Indentures dated Aprill xvi, in the 7 Yeare of King Charles, gave several Things to this Church.
DIV2.P: On another Tablet is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Elizabeth Willet, Widdow, now Wife of William Boulton, of London, June xxiv, MDCXL. was a Benefactour to this Church.
DIV2.P: On a Brass Plate, on the Ground in the South Isle, under the Pourtraitures of a Man and Woman, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Hic jacet Magister David Cops, qui obiit XXV die Mensis Aprilis, An. Dom. MCCCCVIII. & Alicia Wxor ejus, quorum animabus, &c.
DIV2.P: At the Head of a Grave on the South Side of the Church-yard is a Stone erect∣ed, and thereon is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q:
Hic jacet JOHANNES SHEPHARD Maritus MARGARETAE,
Qui quidem obiit secundo die Februarii, Anno Salutis nostrae millesimo sexentesimo sexagesimo Annoque Regni Domini nostri Caroli secundi, Dei gratia, Angliae, Scotiae, Franciae, & Hiberniae, Regis, Fidei Defensoris, &c duodecimo.
DIV2.P: On the Back side of the Stone.
DIV2.Q: Serius aut citius metam proper amus ad unam.

DIV2.HEAD: Great COXHULL, alias Coxwell,
DIV2.P: Is a Vicaridge in the Deanery of Abing∣ton, and Patronage of the Bishop of Sa∣rum.

In the Body of the Church, near the Entrance into the Chancel, lies a little Marble, and thereon a Brass Plate, having the Figure of a Man in a short Gown, with Pouch hanging at his Girdle, and under his Feet this Epitaph.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth William Morys, sum∣tyme Fermer of Cokyswell, on whose Soule Ihesu have Mercy. Amen.
DIV2.P: Adjoyning to the former lyes another Marble, with the Figure of a Woman in her usual Habit, having this Epitaph.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth Johane, the Wife of William Morys; on whose Soule Ihesu have Mercy. Amen.
DIV2.P: Engraved on a Marble lying in the Chancel is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of ANNE MORES, late Wife to THOMAS MORES, jun. Esq; who departed thys Lyfe the xxth of February, MDCXXXII. who had Issue then living, GEORGE a Son, and ANNE and DOWSABELLA, her Daughters.
DIV2.P: On another Marble Grave-stone lying under the South Wall, is this Inscription.
DIV2.Q: Here lyeth the Body of ROBERT RUSSELL, Gent. Sometymes Citizen and Draper of London, who departed this Lyfe the xviiith of August, MDCXXX.
DIV2.P: Incumbent the Reverend Mr. Collier.
